Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey said he disagreed with Gow on Irish issues but considered him ``a man of honor, of integrity and of deep conviction.'' Ian Geldard, editor of the publication Terror Update, said he believed Gow would have been one of the IRA's leading targets ``because of his closeness to the prime minister and his outspokenness.'' ``It would be easy for terrorists to get to him,'' said Gow's neighbor, Jane Birch. ``There did not seem to be any obvious security. The gate to the drive was often open. They didn't seem to make any point of guarding the house.'' The IRA has exploded several bombs in England this year, killing one person before today. On May 16, Sgt. Charles Chapman was killed by an IRA bomb outside a British army recruiting office in Wembley, north London, and on June 1, British army Pvt. William Davies was shot to death at Lichfield railway station. In the most recent attack, no one was injured by an explosion at London's Stock Exchange on July 20. On June 25 an IRA bomb exploded at the Carlton Club in London injuring two men severely and nearly 20 people less seriously. On June 21, an IRA bomb destroyed a building at a Royal Air Force base at Stanmore, northwest London. On June 13, an IRA bomb caused extensive damage to a home recently vacated by a former Conservative Party official. An IRA bomb killed a Conservative parliamentarian and four other people on Oct. 12, 1984 at the Grand Hotel in Brighton, where the party was holding a conference.

DOC.HEAD: Police In Linden Say Asian Gang Shooting May Presage More Warfare
DOC.TEXT: The shooting of seven people at a murdered Asian gang member's burial likely will mean an escalation in the violent power struggle between New York City's Vietnamese and Chinese gangs, authorities say. ``It looks like it's definitely going to spill over here,'' Linden police Capt. Robert Gerbounka said Sunday. ``There's no doubt in my mind that there will be retaliation.'' At least three gunmen posing as mourners dropped flowers they were carrying and opened fire with Uzi submachine guns Saturday on about 100 mourners attending the burial of a Vietnamese man who was shot to death last week. Seven people were wounded by gunfire and seven others were injured in the ensuing panic at Rosedale Memorial Park in Linden, a suburb five miles southwest of Newark. Police said they found signs that mourners, most of them members of the Vietnamese gang Born to Kill, shot back at the attackers, The New York Times reported in today's editions. More than 100 New York police officers patrolled Manhattan's Chinatown section following the shooting to guard against violence between the gangs, Gerbounka said. The man being buried, 21-year-old Vinh Vuv, was shot four times in the chest Wednesday in a drive-by shooting in Chinatown, police said. A man with him was wounded, police said. New York police said Vuv operated a group known as the Canal Street Boys, one of several that make up Born to Kill, a Vietnamese gang with members in Houston, Boston, Los Angeles and other cities. ``What's occurring in New York is these Canal Street Boys have been doing a lot of extorting and robberies in the Canal Street section,'' Gerbounka said. ``They're getting Chinese gangs angry at them. They've got the label of being a fringe gang, which is one of the reasons they're taking a beating right now.'' The Born to Kill gang has been a force on Canal Street, a Chinatown thoroughfare, for at least a year, said Gerald McKelvey, a spokesman in the Manhattan district attorney's office. ``There have been organized gangs of one kind or another in Chinatown for at least the past 15 years,'' dominated by the Ghost Shadows and the Flying Dragons, he said. ``We began to see them put out of commission either because they killed each other off or were put in jail,'' McKelvey said. Born to Kill members have filled part of that void, extorting money from shop owners and trafficking in heroin, he said. He declined to speculate on what may have touched off Saturday's violence because the case is still under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Cemetery Attacked in England
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf with 3 grafs to UPDATE with further desecrations in France, CLARIFY that cemetery desecration in Carpentras; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Vandals painted swastikas and anti-Semitic slogans on some headstones in a Jewish cemetery and smashed others over the weekend in what police said appeared the work of neo-Nazis. Police said today that the attack may have been carried out by a traveling gang of supporters of the National Front, which advocates the expulsion of racial minorities from Britain. The attack in the northern city of Manchester was linked with two others within the last six weeks, at Edmonton in north London and in Leeds, Yorkshire. In the Edmonton case, the words, ``We will rise again,'' were painted on gravestones. Police estimated the damage at $128,000 from the Manchester vandalism, which police said occurred late Saturday or early Sunday. They did not disclose what the slogans were. ``It is a terrible thing to think there are people who would do this to the resting places of the dead,'' said Rabbi Jacob Rubinstein in Manchester. ``We are extremely concerned to think that, in light of what has happened to other cemeteries, these people are crawling out from under stones again,'' he said. On Saturday, vandals in Stuttgart, West Germany, damaged more than 60 gravestones in a Jewish cemetery and spray-painted them with Nazi symbols. More than 60 gravestones were desecrated, police said. Nazi symbols and slogans like ``Jews Out'' and ``The Gassing Never Happened'' were spray-painted on some stones, they said. Police said they suspected right-wing extremists for the damage, estimated at more than $125,000. Two weeks earlier, unidentified vandals caused similar damage at a gravesite for Nazi victims in Tuebingen, about 30 miles south of Stuttgart. A similar attack occurred recently in Carpentras in France. In Paris today police said about 30 graves were desecrated at a cemetery at a catholic church near southern Toulouse. Graffiti at the cemetery _ which was not Jewish _ included ``Death to Jesus'' and ``Down with the clergy.'' Since the Carpentras desecration in May, there has been some sort of cemetery vandalism almost weekly in France, much of it at non-Jewish cemeteries and police believe most has been the work of local children.

DOC.HEAD: Move Over Tracy, Back Off Bart; Spider-Man is Here
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `Over the ...' and penultimate graf to CORRECT that Lee writes newspaper comic strip, not McFarlane. Picks up last graf, ``We're negotiating ...'
DOC.TEXT: Dick Tracy has a gang of funny-faced bad guys on the run in movie theaters and Bart Simpson rules television airwaves and T-shirt sales, but the summer belongs to Spider-Man for comic book fans. Less than two weeks after its release in June, the first issue of a new Marvel Comics series, titled simply ``Spider-Man,'' became the best-selling comic in U.S. history. And the wisecracking web-slinger snared ``favorite character'' honors in the annual Comics Buyer's Guide readers poll. The wall-crawler defeated Batman, last summer's box-office sensation and titleholder since 1985. Spidey's success has Hollywood sniffing around for a movie deal. ``When it comes right down to it, I can be pretty awesome if I want,'' Spider-Man, also known as Peter Parker, says in an introspective moment in the first comic in the new series, ``Spider-Man No. 1.'' He debuted in 1962 as an unpopular teen-ager whose life changed when he was bitten by a radioactive spider. Today, he's a graduate student in biophysics who shares a New York loft with his glamorous actress-model wife. ``He's changing with the times, but still contains a lot of the stuff that attracted (people) to the character in the first place,'' says Spider-Man's editor, Jim Salicrup. Canadian cartoon artist Todd McFarlane, 29, gets much of the credit for the new comic book series' success. Previously, he drew for ``Amazing Spider-Man,'' the title of the original comic book series. In 1988, he redesigned the costume to add a ``creepier'' feel. The new series' first run of 2.35 million copies sold out, so Marvel is printing another 400,000, said Pamela Rutt, a spokeswoman for the country's largest comic book publisher. By comparison, ``Legends of the Dark Knight,'' a Batman book introduced at the height of last year's Batmania, sold an estimated 800,000 copies to become 1989's top seller. Spider-Man continues to draw new generations into his web and Stan Lee, the writer who created him with artist Steve Ditko, says he's not surprised. ``They like Spider-Man because they can relate to him,'' Lee said. ``He has all the problems that they themselves, the readers, can empathize with.'' Over the years, Spider-Man starred on television and was featured on several record albums. Lee, now publisher at Marvel and writer of the Spider-Man newspaper comic strip, is trying to bring Spider-Man to the big screen. ``We're negotiating now,'' he said. ``If we're lucky, it might reach the theaters by the end of next year.''

DOC.HEAD: `World's Finest Emerald' _ Weighing 83.1 Carats _ Among Auction Items
DOC.TEXT: An 83.1-carat, plum-sized emerald should be quite the plum on the auction block tonight. The emerald, nicknamed ``Denise'' after the fiancee of its Los Angeles owner, is the main attraction of the sale featuring hundreds of other gemstones and Soviet artwork. The sale, expected to bring $10 million, began Sunday and resumes 7 p.m. today. But be prepared: The minimum bid for the emerald is $1.5 million. Sandy Reid, executive vice president of Greystone Galleries of Toronto, said the emerald was retrieved from the famous Muzo Mine in Colombia, considered the finest emerald mine in the world. It is ``the largest ever gotten out of the mine,'' Ms. Reid said, adding it should fetch at least $3 million. At least two people already have offered the minimum bid for the gem. But what could one do with an emerald that big? ``To be real honest with you, I don't know,'' said Shari Arnold, spokeswoman for Vikki Vines Auctioneer Co. of Houston. ``It's huge.''

DOC.HEAD: O'Connor Blocks Timber Sales
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court justice has refused to let timber companies operate on the 200,000-acre Mapleton Ranger District of the Siuslaw National Forest in Oregon, it was announced today. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, without comment, turned down an emergency request aimed at setting aside a federal appeals court order that blocks temporarily any timber sales from that district. O'Connor's action was taken Friday but not announced until today. Lawyers for the Western Forest Industries Association and various timber companies told O'Connor the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals order ``has shut down the entire timber sale program on the Mapleton District for the remainder of the fiscal year.'' The appeals court's July 5 order blocks any sales until that court studies the controversy more fully. The planned timber sales, approved by the U.S. Forest Service, were challenged by the National Wildlife Federation, the Oregon Wildlife Federation and the Siuslaw Task Force. Timber industry lawyers told O'Connor that the 9th Circuit court's order ``destroys the careful balance struck by Congress ... between the critical need for a reliable timber supply for the Pacific Northwest's timber industry in 1990 and the desire to protect ecologically significant old growth forests.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Rises to 65 in Month of Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen people drowned in flood waters Sunday, raising the death toll to 65 in a month of flooding that has also left 2 million homeless, officials said Monday. Nine of the weekend casualties were children, relief officials said. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 25 of Bangladesh's 64 districts have been inundated by monsoon rains and overflowing rivers. Floods also have destroyed crops in this agricultural nation where most people live below the poverty line. The nine children died in the northwestern Sirajganj and Bogra districts, where flooding has been worst, the officials said. Five other deaths were reported in Habiganj. Low-lying Bangladesh, a nation of river deltas emptying into the Bay of Bengal, is buffeted by floods every summer. Villages of mud-and-straw huts can be washed away after a few hours of rain.

DOC.HEAD: One-Quarter of British Youth Have Difficulty Reading
DOC.TEXT: One in four young adults in Britain has difficulty reading and writing, according to a survey published Monday. The survey of 1,000 people ranging in age from 16 to 20 years old found that 35 percent had difficulties spelling and 43 percent rarely or never read books. Nine percent rarely or never read newspapers or magazines, the government-funded Adult Literacy and Basic Skills Unit reported. It said 94 percent of adults with literacy problems had not received any help since they were 16 years old. The survey was commissioned by Director, the monthly magazine of the Institute of Directors, one of Britain's larest organizations for business people. Director said the survey showed ``an enormous waste of human resources and an unnecessary burden on the British economy.'' Last week, Education Secretary John MacGregor announced the government would investigate the reading abilities of 7-year-olds after a study by psychologists showed standards slipping back to levels of 50 years ago. Another survey on literacy _ taken among 1,700 16-year-old pupils at an unidentified college near London _ showed 39 percent could not spell ``merely'' and that ``bargain'' was a problem for a quarter of them. Only one-quarter could spell ``committee'' and fewer than a half could manage ``permanent,'' said the report, which is being sent to the Department of Education. The report said the study was based on a spelling test drafted in the 1950s. It said there had been a serious deterioration in the spelling performance of 16-year-olds in the last half of the 1980s and it accused education officials of masking the decline by lowering standards in school examinations.

DOC.HEAD: Worker Electrocuted in Channel Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: A worker on the British side of the Channel Tunnel being bored between England and France was electrocuted, police said. His was the ninth death on the project. Police said Charles McCourt, 45, died Sunday night, but they gave no further details. The death comes less than three weeks after Transmanche Link, the Anglo-French construction consortium of 10 companies building the tunnel, pledged immediate action to improve safety standards. The move came after Britain's Health and Safety Executive demanded tighter safety controls. There have been seven deaths on the project's British side and two on the French side as workers dig the 31-mile tunnel. Workers are boring three tunnels through the channel, two for trains and a smaller maintenance tunnel. They are expected to break through on a first tunnel in November.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Struggle to Halt Cigarette Smuggling
DOC.TEXT: Cigarette smuggling is dramatically increasing in China and authorities in coastal provinces seem unable to deal with the problem, an official report said Monday. In the coastal province of Fujian, authorities handled 50,000 cases of the smuggling of imported cigarettes in the first half of this year _ four times higher than during the same period last year, the Economic Daily said. Last year an estimated 600,000 to 1 million cases of cigarettes were smuggled into China, representing a tax loss of $190 million to $317 million, it said. Most male Chinese smoke, and having imported cigarettes is considered a status symbol. Ordinary Chinese cigarettes sell for about 20 cents. Imported cigarettes cost six to seven times that amount. Authorities from the Tobacco Monopoly Bureau in eastern China said at a recent meeting that it was difficult to stop smuggling because of a lack of supervision in coastal provinces. Gangs, some with links to Hong Kong and Taiwan, are increasingly active, pushing out individuals who used to make up the bulk of the cigarette smuggling trade. The new breed of smugglers are also well equipped. For example, they use 900-1,200 horsepower boats against the government's 40-100 horsepower crafts, the paper said. Some foreign boats are even equipped with satellite navigation equipment and other communications facilities, it said. Some authorities who confiscate smuggled cigarettes are also known to sell them rather than turning the goods over to the authorities, the paper said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Sentences Sudanese Man to Hang for Dealing Hashish
DOC.TEXT: A court sentenced a Sudanese man to death by hanging after finding him guilty of selling hashish, the daily newspaper al-Kuwat al-Musallaha reported Monday. Mohamed Fadlallah Osman would be the second man to die under strict anti-drugs laws introduced shortly after the June 30, 1989, military coup led by Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir. The court also sentenced al-Sadek Abdel-Maula to 20 years imprisonment for helping Osman sell hashish and three other defendants received terms of 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Jehovah's Witness Wins Religious Education Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Belgium's highest court has ruled that the government cannot force students to take courses in one of six officially recognized religions or non-confessional morals. The ruling came after authorities denied the children of a Jehovah's Witness an abstention from such courses, officials said Monday. The issue went to court and the Council of State ruled that the lack of choice violated the 1950 European human rights declaration. The six recognized religions are Roman Catholicism, Judaism, Protestantism, Anglicanism, Orthodox Christianity and Islam. There are about 20,000 Jehovah's Witnesses in this overwhelmingly Catholic nation.

DOC.HEAD: Rains, Floods Kill 27 in Northeastern Brazil
DOC.TEXT: Torrential rain burst a dam and caused dozens of homes to collapse in northeastern Brazil, killing at least 27 people, fire officials said Monday. Ten members of one family were buried alive when a mudslide hit their house on Sunday, fire department Maj. Neyff Souza said by telephone from Recife, 1,536 miles northeast of Rio de Janeiro. ``So far, we know of 24 victims buried under mud or rubble and three who drowned,'' Souza said. ``But there could be more because we haven't searched the worst area.'' A storm dumped 7 inches of rain on greater Recife Saturday night and Sunday, about one-third the city's average monthly rainfall, the weather bureau said. The rain caused five rivers to overflow in the city, which is known as ``the Venice of Brazil'' because of its many waterways. About 10,000 people were driven from their homes and put up at schools or temporary civil defense shelters, Souza said. Hardest hit were the poor shantytowns along riverbanks on the city's north side, he said. In the outlying city of Camaragibe, in greater Recife, a small dam burst and washed away dozens of homes, he said. The weather was dry Monday, and a team of 11 firemen began a house-to-house search for victims in Camaragibe.

DOC.HEAD: Military Agrees to Cease-Fire In Effort to Free American
DOC.TEXT: The military agreed today to demands by Communist rebels in an attempt to win the freedom of a U.S. Peace Corps volunteer held captive on the central island of Negros. Under a deal with the rebels, they are to release Timothy Swanson, 26, and Fumio Mizuno, a 36-year-old Japanese aid worker, on Thursday, officials said. They did not give further details on the arrangements for his release. Mizuno was abducted May 29 and Swanson, of Cheyenne, Wyo., was kidnapped June 13. The United States closed down Peace Corps operations in the Philippines last month because of reported rebel threats against volunteers. Brig. Gen. Raymundo Jarque, military commander of Negros, said he agreed to a temporary ``cessation of hostilities'' and that troops would not interfere with the release. In Manila, U.S. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said Swanson would probably be flown to the capital after his release and later sent to the United States. The Rev. Antonio Fortich, retired Roman Catholic bishop of Negros island, said the rebels asked for the truce in seven communities on Negros between Wednesday and Friday. Fortich told reporters the two were in good condition and that Mizuno was spending time playing basketball with his captors. Fortich said the letter, the second he received from the rebels, also contained demands. He refused to elaborate but said they did not include ransom. ``We are now preparing everything that they are demanding,'' Fortich told reporters. ``Unless there is a third letter saying the release will not take place, it will be all systems go.'' Bacolod is about 300 miles southeast of Manila. The New People's Army, the armed wing of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines, has been waging a 21-year-old insurgency to establish a Marxist state in the Philippines.

DOC.HEAD: Connie Chung Won't Do New Series, Wants Baby
DOC.TEXT: Connie Chung wants to have a baby before it's too late, so today she removed herself and her new ``Face to Face With Connie Chung'' interview series from CBS' Monday lineup for next fall. The 43-year-old Chung, who's married to ``A Current Affair'' anchorman Maury Povich, 51, said she will do ``Face to Face'' specials instead of her series. CBS will replace Chung's series with ``The Trials of Rosie O'Neill,'' a one-hour dramatic series starring former ``Cagney & Lacey'' star Sharon Gless as a recently divorced lawyer who becomes a public defender. Chung, in a statement explaining her decision, said she and her husband ``have reached an important point in our lives.'' ``We want very much to have a child,'' she said. ``Unfortunately, time is running out for me when it comes to childbeairng. I will be 44 next month. ``Just last week, after consulting with my doctors, I became convinced that to make this effort, I now need to take a very aggressive approach to having a baby.'' Because of that, she said, she asked CBS News to lighten her workload. She was unavailable for comment on her decision. Earlier this year, Maria Shriver left the Washington-based ``Sunday Today'' show, citing a desire to spend more time with her baby daughter in Los Angeles, where she lives. ``This was a very important decision for Connie,'' CBS Broadcast Group President Howard Stringer said. ``She has my support, respect and loyalty. ``When Connie is ready we will happily welcome `Face to Face' back to the schedule as a weekly series.'' Chung, who rejoined CBS News from NBC in April 1989, and anchored last-season's low-rated ``Saturday Night with Connie Chung,'' scored high ratings in May with her first two ``Face to Face'' specials. Her husband recently said he will leave the syndicated ``A Current Affair'' which he has anchored for Fox Broadcasting since 1986. He intends to co-produce and anchor a new nightly talk series to be syndicated by Paramount starting in the fall 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Bertha the Storm Moves Northeast Through Atlantic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Bertha regaining strength as hurricane, noontime location, speed. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Bertha, the first hurricane of the 1990 Atlantic season, churned along the Gulf Stream well east of the Carolinas today after regaining strength temporarily lost during the night. Born as a tropical depression off northeast Florida, Bertha grew quickly Saturday into a minimal hurricane with winds of 75 mph. It dropped below the 74 mph hurricane threshold Sunday night, but regained hurricane status today after its winds intensified a bit. At noon EDT today, Bertha had top sustained winds near 75 mph and was centered near latitude 35.3 north, longitude 67.4 west, or 675 miles south-southwest of Halifax, Nova Scotia, said forecasters at the National Hurricane Center near Miami. The storm was moving northeast near 13 mph and was expected to stay at the same strength, course and speed through early Tuesday, said forecaster Miles Lawrence. Earlier, Bertha kicked up the surf along Carolina beaches and sent gusts up to about 45 mph toward Bermuda. But forecasters said that because it was already edging northeastward toward the open Atlantic when it was born, it was never much of a threat. ``It's mainly a concern to marine interests at the present time,'' forecaster Hal Gerrish said. He said Bertha could reach the Canadian provinces of Nova Scotia and Newfoundland by Wednesday or Thursday. Tropical Storm Arthur, which peaked with 70 mph winds Thursday but quickly lost strength over the central Caribbean, had dissipated by late Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Sportsmen Are Game For Wild Pig Hunt
DOC.TEXT: Local sportsmen are more than game to help Channel Islands National Park officials hunt down the estimated 4,000 wild pigs ravaging this island off the southern California coast. But park officials are telling the pig hunters not to get too fired up. Park officials have been deluged with offers of help since last week, when they announced plans to eliminate the island's wild pig population so they can restore native wildlife and vegetation. ``They'll say, `I want to get on the list,''' said Fred Rodriguez, a dispatcher for the Park Service. ``They'll say, `How can I get to the island to kill pigs?''' But park officials plan to hire professionals to do the work at a cost of $200,000 to $800,000. Most of the island has been ravaged by pigs digging roots, eating acorns and plundering bird nests since European settlers abandoned the animals there in 1850, authorities said. Park officials expect the eradication of the pigs on the 53,000-acre island to take about 1{ years. Rodriguez said he receives at least 12 calls each day from hunters offering to do the job for free. Among his favorite calls was from a group at a tavern. ``You could hear the country-western music in the background,'' he said. ``It was kind of comical, actually. It was something they thought they could do in one day.''

DOC.HEAD: Divers Find Rare Silver Bell At Galleon Wreck
DOC.TEXT: Divers searching for treasure from a Spanish ship that went down in a hurricane in 1715 have found a perfectly preserved, 1{-foot-high silver bell. ``Gold coins are gold coins,'' said ship Capt. Carl Lazzeri, captain of the Rogue Wave, whose divers made the find. ``Artifacts are one of a kind. To find something in that good of condition is really exciting.'' The four-man crew of the Rogue Wave has been searching since May for gold, silver and artifacts from what appear to be the remains of the Santo Cristo de San Roman, one of an 11-ship fleet that sank during a hurricane after leaving Cuba for Spain. Since the early 1960s, eight of the ships have been found. The Rogue Wave is one of about 20 boats subcontracting this summer with treasure hunter Mel Fisher to search for treasure from Sebastian Inlet to St. Lucie Inlet on Florida's east-central coast. Diver Gary Daemer spotted the bell in 8 feet of water in Sebastian Inlet on July 23. ``Originally, I thought it was a newer bell, something from the 1800s. When we got the encrustation off, then we knew we had something great,'' Daemer said. Dated 1705, the bell bears the Latin inscription ``Soli Deo Gloria'' or ``Glory to God Alone.'' It was found alongside a small wooden beam to which it had once been attached. Daemer said the bell was probably buried under sand for years, which would have helped preserve it, and was only recently uncovered when the sand shifted.

DOC.HEAD: Novice Screenwriters Pen Work At Great American Script-athon
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 writers endured a 48-hour type-till-you-drop ``scriptathon'' in a marathon effort to pound out a movie script in two days. The writers from the Independent Writers of Southern California and a dozen passers-by willing to spend $10 for 10 minutes at a computer keyboard contributed during the weekend to a screenplay called ``Hot Property.'' The play is a romantic comedy about a crazy coot who wants to bequeath his house, the last affordable one in Los Angeles, to a deserving young couple. ``I think we can auction it to a movie studio or filmmaker,'' said Cheryl Crooks, Independent Writers president. ``We hope to create the longest line of screenwriting credits in history.' ``Everything is possible in Hollywood,'' Crooks said. The non-profit Independent Writers counts 450 members, including freelance journalists, authors, publicists and poets. A goal of the event held in a shopping center was to raise money for inner-city high school students to attend a film workshop at the University of Southern California's School of Cinema-Television.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: After the Beatles broke up, Paul McCartney hated being asked: ``Are you happy?'' But as he closed out his 102-concert world tour Sunday, he said the question no longer frightens him. ``I used to really dread that question,'' McCartney told reporters before the final stop in the 10-month tour Sunday at Soldier Field, where he played to a sold-out crowd of 53,000. But now, ``I'm really happy. I've got a great family, a great band, and we seem to be selling some tickets,'' he said. McCartney jokingly referred to his ``great venerable age'' of 48 and refuted speculation that this might be his last tour. ``I just would like to continue making music,'' the former Beatle said. ``I want to get better _ that's always been my goal. If the next album's better than the last one, that's all that really interests me.'' McCartney played to a total of 2.8 million people during the tour.

Actor Richard Widmark was in satisfactory condition Monday at New Milford Hospital, recovering from leg injuries suffered in a weekend lawn-mower accident, a hospital spokesman said. ``He picked a fight with his lawn mower,'' said Hank Fanberg. Widmark, 75, was taken to the hospital Sunday and underwent surgery on his lower left leg and foot, said Fanberg. He did not know the extent of injuries or other details of the accident. Widmark has owned a home in Roxbury for years. He has appeared in more than 30 films, including ``No Way Out,'' ``Judgement at Nuremberg'' and ``How the West Was Won.'' His more recent screen credits include ``Murder on the Orient Express,'' ``The Swarm,'' and ``Against All Odds.'' He starred in the television series ``Madigan'' in 1972.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Tennis star Jimmy Connors has found a new racket _ riverboat gambling. Connors and his brother, John, are hoping to secure construction financing for a four-level riverboat that can carry up to 2,500 gamblers. Illinois law says the design of the boat must be a replica of a 19th-century vessel. Nine other partners will be responsible for financing other portions of the project, John Connor said Monday. Construction of the boat won't begin until a license is granted by the Illinois Gaming Board, and that decision is not expected until later this year. John Connors said the boat would offer a variety of entertainment besides gambling. ``We're not just looking at it as gambling. Some people might come to the boat to see a show and not gamble,'' he said. Although riverboat gambling legally may begin Jan. 1, partner J. Thomas Long said his group probably would not start until Sept. 1, 1991 _ if they get a license.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Basketball player Mark Jackson of the New York Knicks has married Desiree Coleman, a singer and actress. Jackson, 25, was the National Basketball Association's Rookie of the Year in 1987-88, and an all-star in the 1988-89 season. But last season, Jackson went from a regular season starter to a seldom-used reserve in the playoffs, and was heartily booed by Knick fans. The bride, who is 23, is a Motown recording artist. None of Jackson's Knick teammates attended Sunday's wedding.

Jeb Magruder, who spent seven months in prison for his role in Watergate, has been chosen by the First Presbyterian Church congregation to become its senior pastor. ``I think the church in Lexington is a highly intelligent kind of congregation, full of people ready to deal with substantive issues of faith and how it relates to their everyday lives as Christians,'' Magruder said in a telephone interview from his home in Columbus, Ohio. The vote Sunday was 254-5. ``I think that's about as close to a unanimous vote as any bunch of Presbyterians ever gave a new minister,'' said the Rev. Victor Priebe, interim minister of the church founded in 1784. Magruder, 55, pleaded guilty to conspiring to obstruct justice in the Watergate scandal, which eventually led to President Nixon's resignation in 1974. Magruder graduated from the Princeton School of Divinity after his release from prison in 1975. He has been executive minister of First Community Church in Columbus since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Tries to Fight City Hall
DOC.TEXT: Don't bother trying to call Mayor John Wilson at his office. He doesn't have one. This tiny community hasn't had an office for the mayor since 1987, when the city decided to rent a portion of City Hall to a local insurance company to raise money after a devastating 1985 flood. Things have improved since then, and the City Council says Wilson can have his old office back _ for $215 a month. ``You won't find another city hall in the state of West Virginia, maybe even in the entire United States, that doesn't furnish its mayor an office,'' said Wilson, 74. ``It is a most unusual situation, wouldn't you agree?'' Councilman Earl Delaney, who led the opposition to the mayor, didn't agree or disagree. He just said the council can't afford to lose the rent on the office. ``This is the first time we've had any troubles with him,'' Delaney added, referring to the mayor.

DOC.HEAD: Prize-Winning Novelist, Scriptwriter Georges Conchon Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th pvs, `His first...' to CORRECT English title of 1959 novel.
DOC.TEXT: Georges Conchon, author of prize-winning novels and screenwriter for an Oscar-winning film, has died, his family said today. He was 65. The family said he died Sunday in a Paris-area hospital after a sudden illness. No details were released. Conchon mixed a varied literary career with long-term government service. From 1960 to 1980, he was secretary of debates at the Senate, the upper chamber of the French Parliament. His first novel was published in 1953. His 1959 novel ``La Corrida de la Victoire'' (The Corrida of Victory) won the Prix des Libraires and his 1964 novel ``L'Etat Sauvage'' (The Savage State) won the Prix Goncourt, France's most prestigious literary award. He also wrote scripts for several popular French films and was co-writer of the 1976 film ``Black and White in Color,'' along with Jean-Jacques Annaud, the director. Winner of the Oscar for best foreign film, the movie was a satirical depiction of colonial life in French West Africa in 1915. Conchon was a journalist for the newspaper France-Soir in 1959-60 and served as artistic adviser to the national television channel Antenne 2 after his retirement from the Senate in 1980. He was a member of the governing Socialist Party. Funeral services were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Darman Injured in Fall, But Back at Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts time element in graf 2, A spokeswoman.
DOC.TEXT: Budget Director Richard Darman fell on the steps of a fast-food restaurant over the weekend and had 100 stitches taken in his head, but was back at work today, his office said. A spokeswoman, Kim Gibson, said Darman was at a restaurant near his home in McLean, Va., Saturday morning when he slipped on the stairs, which she said apparently were wet. She said he drove himself to Sibley Memorial Hospital, several miles away in Washington, and was in the emergency room for more than three hours. Ms. Gibson said many of the stiches were in his face.

DOC.HEAD: White House Condemns Massacre of Liberians
DOC.TEXT: The White House today condemned the massacre of more than 200 people by government forces in Liberia as a ``senseless act of terror.'' But it said the United States was not about to send in any troops. White House deputy press secretary Stephen Hart said U.S. embassy officials had confirmed that Liberian troops slaughtered some 200 people who had sought refuge at a Lutheran Church compound in Monrovia. Witnesses said most of them were women and children. ``We abhor this senseless act of terror and call again on all sides to the conflict to refrain from inflicting violence on helpless and innocent men, women and children,'' Hart said. He said all parties should respect internationally sanctioned protections for victims of armed conflict to prevent murder and the carrying out of executions without due process. ``We renew the appeal which we have made both publicly and privately throughout this tragic conflict for both sides to forego a military solution and to follow the path of negotiations,'' Hart said. Despite the bloodshed, Hart said the United States was not committing any troops to Liberia. ``At this point,'' he said, ``we don't believe that would be a prudent course of action.'' Rebel forces seeking to overthrow President Samuel Doe were waging street battles in Monrovia with government forces and have advanced within a mile of Doe's seaside mansion. Hart said the United States remains willing to escort Doe out of the country but that he has not asked for help in leaving. Asked if the United States held Doe accountable for the massacre committed by his troops, Hart said, ``We don't know who directed the action. ... Certainly we abhor the action his forces are taking.'' About 400 Americans remain in Liberia, including 70 American officials, said Roman Popadiuk, White House deputy press secretary.

DOC.HEAD: Utah ACLU Files School Prayer Lawsuit Against Two Districts
DOC.TEXT: The American Civil Liberties Union today filed a lawsuit against two school districts that permit prayer at graduation exercises and other school functions. The ACLU, making good on legal action it had threatened for several months, named the Alpine and Granite districts and several administrators in the suit filed in U.S. District Court. The action was certain to touch off a legal battle that some, including Gov. Norm Bangerter, have suggested should be fought with state funds to ensure prayers would have a place in public schools. ``It is with reluctance that the ACLU has sponsored the filing of these lawsuits, given the shortage of funds available to the school districts for important programs and teachers salaries,'' ACLU Executive Director Michele Parish-Pixler said at a news conference. ``All of our efforts to resolve these problems out of court have been rejected. We feel we have no alternative.'' The plaintiffs include students who have graduated or are currently students in the two districts and a counselor and teacher in the Alpine District in Utah County. Parish-Pixler said earlier today that prayer in Utah schools forces minor children into religious practices. She said that, although taking such an issue to court is ``always a gamble,'' she felt confident the ACLU's Utah chapter would prevail. The filings culminate a months-long dispute over the practice of permitting prayer at graduation exercises and other school functions in Utah, where about 70 percent of its 1.7 million residents are members of the Mormon Church. In the time since graduation exercises marked the school year's end, the dispute has come to involve the ACLU, school districts, the Republican governor and a top official of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The debate began in 1989, when a student at the Jordan School District complained that a Mormon-oriented prayer at graduation violated the student's civil rights. The Jordan District later banned graduation prayer, but the issue remained active through the 1990 school year. Even so, a majority of Utahns appear to favor prayer at some school functions, according to a recent poll for The Deseret News and KSL-TV. The survey found that 72 percent of those questioned said they favored prayer at commencement ceremonies, while 69 percent said prayers should be permitted in schools. Nineteen percent said prayer at graduation should be banned, and 26 percent oppose school prayer. Of those who identified themselves as Mormons, 83 percent would accept prayer in the schools, while Protestants and Catholics were split on the issue. By political party, 76 percent of the Republicans favored school prayer, as opposed to 58 percent of the Democrats. Bangerter has said he would ask the Legislature to appropriate money to help the districts battle the lawsuit, although House Speaker Nolan Karras, R-Roy, has said he would want to study the matter before committing state money to a costly and potentially fruitless proposition. In a Sunday editorial, the church-owned Deseret News supported Bangerter's intention, saying that otherwise the school districts would be forced to bear the burden of costly litigation. The newspaper also drew a distinction between school prayer and those at graduation exercises, where most graduates and visitors are legal adults and where even those of faiths different from that of the person praying would ``hardly suffer psychological damage.'' The Salt Lake Tribune, however, opposes both school prayer and spending state money to defend it and planned an editorial for Tuesday's editions, said editorial writer Diane Cole.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Agrees To Pay Israel Compensation for Refugees
DOC.TEXT: East Germany has reversed its position and agreed to pay Israel compensation for taking in thousands of refugees from Nazi Germany after World War II, according to a letter obtained Monday. The change was reflected in a letter from East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere to World Jewish Congress President Edgar Bronfman which said that talks should be convened to discuss compensation for ``the burden caused to Israel with the absorption and integration of refugees from Germany....'' Previously, East Germany had agreed to pay reparations to Jewish organizations but not to Israel. Even with the change, East Germany cannot afford the large sum of money involved, and negotiations about the amount probably will take place next year after the East is united with wealthy West Germany, officials said. The united Germany will assume the financial responsibilities of the East once unification is completed by the end of this year. Talks on the subject between Israeli and East German officials broke down in Copenhagen on July 5 on the issue of reparations to Israel for absorption of the refugees, according to the Israel Foreign Ministry. At Israel's request, the World Jewish Congress then intervened with the office of de Maiziere, said WJC Executive Director Elan Steinberg. The letter from de Maiziere, said Steinberg, ``emerges as the voice of Germany's moral conscience.'' He said Israel and the WJC wanted an East German commitment of principle on the reparations, although talks on the sum to be repaid probably would not take place until after the union of East and West Germany. Israel has demanded an East German commitment to pay reparations based on a formula reached with West Germany in 1952 known as the Luxembourg Agreement. The agreement called for total reparations of 4.5 billion Deutsche Marks to be paid to Israel and Jewish organizations for the costs of resettling destitute survivors of the Nazi Holocaust in which 6 million Jews were killed. West Germany agreed to pay 3 billion of the total, and said East Germany would pay the other 1.5 billion. However, East Germany was under the control of the Soviets following World War II and refused to recognize responsibility for the Holocaust. Soon after throwing off communist rule in March, however, East Germany announced it would accept moral responsibility for the crimes of the Nazis. It also agreed to compensate Jewish organizations. Talks on those reparations, which began last month, have stalled pending resolution of the question of whether there should be compensation to Israel in addition to the Jewish organizations, Jewish sources said. The East Germans have now decided to compensate Israel. Only the amount to be paid has not yet been resolved.

DOC.HEAD: Latvian Officials Meet with Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Foreign Minister's name to ``Jurkns.''
DOC.TEXT: Latvian Prime Minister Ivars Godmanis and his foreign minister called on President Bush today and said they received encouragement in their quest for a gradual transition to independence from the Soviet Union. Foreign Minister Janis Jurkns said he and Godmanis told Bush that ``some countries in Europe have taken concrete steps'' to recognize Latvian independence. ``We asked the American government to do the same and we got supportive answers,'' Jurkns said. Godmanis added, however, that Latvia would seek its independence ``democratically, peacefully and gradually.'' ``We want to restore our independence 100 per cent,'' he said. ``There is no question.'' But, he said, ``independence will be gradual; it takes time.'' Godmanis said he asked Bush to open a U.S. information center in the Latvian capital of Riga, to encourage American firms to do business in Latvia and to support American universities offering education for Latvian youth. ``Mr. Bush said they are going to speak very seriously about what they can do in those specific directions,'' he said. Deputy White House Press Secretary Stephen Hart said that during the meeting with Godmanis ``the president heard his concerns and the plans of the Latvian government for economic reform.'' `` I am not aware of any commitments that were made,'' Hart said. Roman Popadiuk, also a deputy White House press secretary, said that in administration policy ``the emphasis has been in urging dialogue'' between the Soviet Union and the Baltic Republics.

DOC.HEAD: Hrawi Government Imposes Blockade on Aoun Enclave
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi's government on Monday clamped an economic and diplomatic blockade on rebel Gen. Michel Aoun in an attempt to oust him from the Christian enclave north of Beirut. Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon, immediately expressed support for the move. Aoun has demanded the withdrawal of the 40,000 troops Syria maintains in Lebanon. Also Monday, rival Shiite militiamen fought artillery duels in south Lebanon, leaving six dead and 24 wounded. The Red Cross said it was preparing a mission to evacuate bodies from earlier clashes. The fighting was between the Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-allied Amal militia in the Apple Province. The casualties raised the toll to 186 people killed and 560 wounded since July 16, when renewed fighting broke out in the three-year intermittent war for dominance of the 1.2 million-strong Shiite sect, the largest in Lebanon. By police count, 1,232 people have been killed and 4,203 wounded in the inconclusive power struggle. The government directive instructed military checkpoints at all gateways into Aoun-controlled areas to prohibit the passage of fuel tankers and trucks carrying ammunition or spare parts to Aoun's 19,000 troops. The directive also banned civilians entering Aoun-controlled territory from carrying more than $150, and prohibited money transfers to banks operating in his area. The Foreign Ministry in mostly Moslem west Beirut called in diplomatic representatives Monday and notified them that it will not tolerate any contacts between foreign representatives and Aoun. A government statement said the blockade was ``an initial move to end Aoun's mutiny'' and that if it failed to accomplish its objective, a food blockade would be imposed after two weeks. Aoun, who controls roughly 20 percent of the Christian enclave, denounced Hrawi's blockade as an ``attempt to starve out the people.'' Analysts say the effectiveness of the blockade depends largely on how far Syria is willing to go in supporting Hrawi's drive to re-establish the state authority that has been eroded by 15 years of civil war. Jibran Kourieh, a spokesman for Syrian President Hafaz Assad, said Assad had pledged to Lebanese Christian leaders that Syria would ``fully support'' efforts to extend the Hrawi government's authority to all of Lebanon. The U.S. ambassador to Syria, Edward Djerejian, told a news conference that Syria and the United States both supported the Hrawi government. Syrian troops entered Lebanon in 1976 under a 1976 Arab League mandate to end the civil war. They control 70 percent of the country's territory and ring the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. Aoun, 54, controls the enclave's Metn province. He contends that a military cabinet he headed since September 1988 is the only legitimate government in Lebanon. The rest of the enclave, including all its sea outlets, is controlled by Christian warlord Samir Geagea and his Lebanese Forces militia, which has declared allegiance to Hrawi. The enclave was partitioned after an inconclusive confrontation between Aoun and Geagea that erupted Jan. 30, killing at least 1,044 people and wounding 2,793. Hrawi was elected president Nov. 24 with strong Syrian backing to enforce a peace accord worked out by Lebanon's Parliament. The agreement would end Christian dominance in Lebanon and give Moslems, who make up 55 percent of Lebanon's 4 million population, an equal share of power. Aoun has objected to the accord saying it does not include a timetable for a Syrian troop withdrawal from Lebanon. Hrawi, Aoun and Geagea are Maronite Catholics, the sect that has dominated the government since Lebanon gained independence from France in 1943.

DOC.HEAD: Personal Spending Up at Steepest Pace in 5 Months
With AM-S&L Cleanup, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Personal spending rose 1.0 percent in June, the strongest gain in five months, the government said Monday in a report suggesting that consumers are keeping the nation's weak economy alive. ``This seems to indicate the consumer is not dead,'' said Mark M. Zandi, an economist with Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ``As long as the consumer hangs in there, I believe we will avoid a recession.'' The Commerce Department said consumer spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.64 trillion, the biggest jump since a similar 1.0 percent gain last January. ``This does not indicate we're going into an economic recession,'' agreed Sung Won Sohn, chief economist with the Norwest Corp. in Minneapolis. He noted that consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Consumer spending had been a source of concern in recent months. Spending rose just 0.2 percent in February and April and 0.3 percent in March. Spending was unchanged in May. As measured in the gross national product, the nation's total output of goods and services, second-quarter personal spending actually fell 0.3 percent. But Sohn said the June personal consumption figure, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, indicates third-quarter spending will be a source of strength for the economy. The Commerce Department also said personal incomes rose 0.4 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.64 trillion after 0.3 percent gains in April and May. But the higher spending level resulted in a drop in Americans' savings rate _ savings as a percentage of disposable income _ to 4.9 percent. It had been 5.4 percent in May and 5.1 percent in April. A higher savings rate means less dependence on foreign capital since funds thus would be available domestically for business investment. All of Monday's figures reflected major changes in last year's numbers as a result of the Commerce Department's annual revision announced last week. The biggest change involved the department's $57.9 billion overestimate in wages and salaries, which resulted in lowering the 1989 savings rate from 5.4 percent to 4.6 percent. Americans' income after taxes increased 0.5 percent, up from a 0.3 percent gain a month earlier. Wages and salaries rose $13.0 billion in June after a $10.1 billion increase in May. Personal consumption rose $34.5 billion, including a $9.6 billion gain in spending on durable goods _ items expected to last more than three years. This included a robust $6.1 billion rebound in automobile sales, which had been sluggish for much of the year. Spending on non-durable goods rose $8.2 billion, the first advance since February. Spending for services increased $16.7 billion, the largest jump since a $20.4 billion advance in March.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Trinidad Bjt
US Has No Plans to Send Forces to Trinidad
DOC.TEXT: The United States has no plans to send military forces to Trinidad, where Prime Minister Arthur Robinson and more than 30 others are being held hostage by Moslem rebels, the State Department said today. At the same time, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher criticized Libya's involvement with the rebels, saying it has provided some training for the insurgents. But he said there was no apparent direct link between Libya and the hostage-taking, which occurred last Friday. Boucher refused comment on reports that U.S. military assets were being deployed in the vicinity of Trinidad but said ``there are no plans for U.S. military intervention.'' The USS Roosevelt paid a scheduled visit to Port-of-Spain July 20-23, the Navy said. The carrier is now in port in Norfolk. The Navy has 10 ships in the Caribbean on what the Navy calls ``routine exercises.'' Boucher said there have been no reports of injury to the estimated 6,000 Americans living in Trinidad. President Bush was keeping up to date on developments after returning to Washington late Sunday after a weekend at his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine. ``We fully support the government of Prime Minister (Arthur) Robinson and hope for a peaceful solution to the situation there,'' said White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen. U.S. officials said any direct U.S. role had been all but ruled out. Even sending U.S. experts on hostage negotiations _ discussed informally on Saturday between the United States and representatives of the Trinidad government _ had been ruled out, sources said. ``The Trinidadians would like to find a solution on their own without any outside assistance. They'd just rather settle it themselves,'' the official said. The administration has hailed Trinidad's government as a model of democracy, and the attempted coup was viewed with distress in Washington. Abu Bakr, the leader of a Moslem sect, launched the coup attempt late Friday by seizing the Parliament building in Port-of-Spain and capturing Robinson and about 40 other hostages. Angus Khan, the ambassador from Trinidad and Tobago to the United States, said the negotiations between his government and the ``terrorists over the release of the hostages are very delicate.'' He refused to say more.

DOC.HEAD: Story with Hemingway Twist Ends Life of Old Japanese Fisherman
DOC.TEXT: An elderly Japanese fisherman featured in a documentary akin to Ernest Hemingway's ``The Old Man and the Sea'' has died in what may have been a last fight with a big marlin, the filmmaker said Monday. The body of Shigeru Itokazu, 81, was found Sunday floating in the East China Sea off a small island south of Okinawa in the Ryukyu Islands. Itokazu was found near the skiff in which he fished alone, police in Okinawa said. Other fishermen in the area did not see what happened, but a wound on Itokazu's thumb apparently came from a suddenly tautened fishing line and indicated he was pulled into the sea, probably by a marlin, said John Junkerman, an American documentary filmmaker. ``The line goes out very fast, and can whip around in the air. It apparently pulled him into the sea,'' Junkerman said. Junkerman, a Milwaukee native who divides his time between homes in Boston and Japan, spent most of two years filming Itokazu and life on the remote island of Yonaguni. His film, titled in Japanese ``The Old Man and the Sea,'' was released last month in Okinawa. ``It is very ironic and very unfortunate that Mr. Itokazu had his end this way and so soon after the film was finished,'' Junkerman said. The filmmaker spoke from Yonaguni island, where he flew from Tokyo to join mourners at Itokazu's funeral Monday. Itokazu fished from his dugout-like 22-foot skiff, Junkerman said. ``On shore, it was clear he was an 80-year-old man, but when he was out at sea, it seemed he was 20 years younger. The sea really was his element. He loved it.'' Junkerman, who made the film for a Japanese production company, said he didn't start out with the idea of mimicking the Hemingway story. But last year there were no marlin to be caught and the filming developed into something like the novel about an old fisherman who hadn't caught a fish in 84 days. Hemingway's old man, fishing alone in the Gulf of Mexico, hooks a swordfish longer than his skiff. He manages to subdue the huge fish and tie it to his boat, but sharks tear it to pieces before he can get it to land. Itokazu often said ``it's not very difficult to catch a marlin but the thing one has to do is take your time and catch the fish carefully,'' Junkerman recalled. ``He very much respected the strength and danger of the marlin,'' he said. Marlin fishing was good this year and Itokazu was out looking for the large, slender billfish when he died, Junkerman said.

DOC.SECOND: Colleges Take Lessons From Boston U-Chelsea
DOC.TEXT: Five colleges are hatching plans to help revamp neighboring public schools this fall _ and each say they are drawing lessons from Boston University's unprecedented management takeover of a nearby district. No one is rushing to imitate Boston University's year-old, ambitious effort to manage and radically transform the entire school district of Chelsea, Mass., a nearly broke system of 3,500 students with some of the worst test scores in that state. But the university's 10-year plan to manage Chelsea's day-to-day operations and raise tens of millions of dollars to finance reforms is apparently earning national credence as colleges seek ways to nurture school reform. ``I think the very positive impact of the Boston-Chelsea relationship has been to encourage colleges to become more involved than they have been. But I don't think the model of taking a system over will be the way it goes,'' said Robert Atwell, president of the American Council on Education in Washington. ``The focus is not so much on the model as on the results,'' said Peter Greer, dean of BU's school of education. The point of BU's effort is to show that ``if you want to change education, you have to take a comprehensive approach,'' he said. The BU-Chelsea plan, entering its second year this fall, aims to rebuild dilapidated schools, raise teacher salaries, introduce literacy and prenatal care programs, and boost standardized test scores. So far, however, BU has fallen short of fund-raising goals and is battling the local teacher union. And some in Chelsea still see the university as an invader imposing change. Despite those struggles, officials of at least five colleges interested in helping nearby schools have recently contacted or visited BU to learn what works and what doesn't, college and public school district officials said in interviews. _ George Mason University, in Fairfax, Va., is in early talks that could lead to a contract to help transform the nearby Manassas Park school district. Manassas Park superintendent James Moyers said Monday that the rural, financially pressed district hopes to enter a comprehensive partnership with George Mason, IBM, the city of Manassas Park and the Signal Hill Development Corp. to stock classrooms with computers to revolutionize the way children learn and teachers teach. _ Officials of Glassboro State College, in Glassboro, N.J., General Electric and the Camden public schools are visiting Boston this week ``to find out what works and what doesn't'' in the Chelsea program, said Phil Tumminia, a vice president of Glassboro State. Glassboro State received an $18,500 GE grant this month to draft plans to improve Camden's schools, concentrating on better teacher training. _ Duke University, in Durham, N.C., plans close ties with Durham High School this fall, and the BU-Chelsea experiment was one of several models planners examined, said Duke spokeswoman Janet San Filippo. Under plans hatched last spring, Duke will start programs to get parents more involved in schools, identify and teach gifted minority children who may not perform well on standardized tests, and train college students as tutors. _ Mercyhurt College, in Erie, Pa., will hold classes on campus for some 200 gifted Erie pupils from kindergarten through eighth grade starting this fall, said president William Garvey. _ DePauw University, in rural Greencastle, Ind., may send student teachers to Chelsea to expose them to inner city, multicultural classes, said president Robert Bottoms. In each case, officials said BU's management scheme with Chelsea was far too ambitious financially and otherwise for most colleges. Public school officials, for their part, stressed that they had no desire to be taken over by a college or repeat the often-stormy relationship in Chelsea. ``We are not putting ourselves up as experts in secondary school education. We want to listen to them,'' said San Filippo of Duke. ``We don't want to go into this with any sense that we have a plan we're going to impose,'' agreed Tumminia of Glassboro State. Moyers, of Manassas Park, said that at one point George Mason officials wanted a say in naming certain school district administrators. ``The school board was having none of that,'' Moyers said. Another lesson being drawn from the BU experience is the need to let public schools take the initiative. All five colleges stressed that they wanted relationships based on cooperation and shared knowledge. Erie school officials ``are telling us what they want from us,'' Garvey said. The problems BU experienced in its relationship with Chelsea ``didn't bother us,'' said Erie schools superintendent Joseph Rodriguez. ``No one will dictate to anyone.''

DOC.HEAD: As Attorney General, Souter Opposed State Paying for Medicaid Abortions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 6-7, Bush, in an address, with quote.
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David Souter, as New Hampshire's attorney general, opposed an order that the state pay for Medicaid abortions. In its 1976 brief, the state referred to abortion as ``the killing of unborn children.'' The brief was filed during a federal court appeal of a case begun during the tenure of Souter's predecessor, Warren Rudman, and Souter did not personally argue the case. New Hampshire's attorney general is appointed by the governor and required by law to represent the governor's views in court. New Hampshire's governor at the time was arch-conservative Meldrim Thompson. Souter's name was listed on the brief but it was signed by its author, Richard Wiesbusch, then an assistant attorney general. White House deputy press secretary Stephen Hart said he did not know if Bush had been told about the 1976 brief. ``What's important is the president supports his nominee,'' Hart said. ``There were no specific issues queried about nor was there a litmus test in the nomination of Souter. ... What's important is that he (Bush) chose the man based upon his merits, what he thought was important.'' Bush, in an address to the Youth Leadership Coalition, said today, ``I am very happy with the way the choice has been received across the country.'' ``It is moving in the proper direction and I probably won't have too much more to say about it,'' the president said. Although nothing in the brief sheds any light on Souter's personal views on abortion, the case likely will provide Senate Judiciary Committee members eager to learn those views a vehicle to raise the issue. ``Clearly the Senate should ask Judge Souter to address himself to this document at his confirmation hearings,'' said Arthur J. Kropp, president of the liberal activist group People for the American Way, which today distributed copies of papers filed in the 1976 case. New Hampshire was appealing to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals a lower court injunction that it pay for elective abortions sought by Medicaid patients during the resolution of a larger case in which the state was seeking to prove it didn't have to pay. New Hampshire's brief acknowledged the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe v. Wade decision legalizing abortion but argued that nothing in that landmark ruling required the state to use tax dollars to pay for abortions sought by Medicaid recipients for reasons other than to preserve a pregnant woman's life. ``Many thousands of New Hampshire residents find the use of tax revenues to finance the killing of unborn children morally repugnant,'' the state's brief said.

DOC.HEAD: Van Gogh Show Draws Record Crowd, Works Returned Under Tight Security
DOC.TEXT: An exhibit of works by van Gogh drew a record 1.2 million visitors over a four-month period, organizers said Monday. People camped out through the weekend in hopes of seeing the show before it closed. The ``Vincent van Gogh Retrospective'' offered an unprecedented collection of masterpieces from museums and private collections around the world. It closed Sunday, the 100th anniversary of the Dutch artist's death. Nearly 140 paintings were on show in Amsterdam's Vincent van Gogh Museum, which houses the world's largest van Gogh collection. Simultaneously, 248 drawings were on display at the Kroeller Mueller Museum in Otterlo, about 55 miles east of Amsterdam. ``They are the ones he would have shown if he ever had given an exhibition,'' said Lisbeth Heenk, a spokeswoman for the Kroeller Mueller museum. She said the number of visitors broke records for Dutch museum exhibits as well as van Gogh exhibits in other countries. No security problems or incidents were reported. Security was a serious concern in light of a series of major thefts and vandalism in recent years. The works borrowed for the retrospective were reportedly insured for a total of $3.3 billion. Dutch museums do not insure their own works. Among the most famous paintings on display were ``Starry Night,'' ``The Bedroom,'' and ``The Potato Eaters.'' Not on display were ``Irisis'' and ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' which have been bought at auction for record prices.

DOC.HEAD: President Orders Release of Four Jailed in Coup Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Four Zambians imprisoned for life for plotting to overthrow the president in 1980 were freed Monday on his orders. Their release marked the latest in a series of political reforms made by President Kenneth Kaunda in the past month, since the country's bloodiest anti-government riots left at least 26 people dead. Released were former High Court commissioner Edward Shamwana, former general manager of the state Industrial Finance Company Goodwin Yoram Mumba, Zairean politician Deogratis Symba and driver Chilambe Chimbalile. Shamwana, a former Kaunda aide, acknowledged that he had plotted the coup, and said he had no regrets. ``The reason is I believed there was no other way to change things,'' Shamwana, 57, told a news conference. The ruling party ``does not allow fresh ideas or initiatives,'' he added. ``I believe it is time for people with fresh ideas, a new period of wonderful opportunity,'' he said. Shamwana said in the early days of imprisonment he was tortured, ill-fed and at one stage stripped naked in a cell ankle-deep in human waste. He originally was sentenced to death, but Kaunda commuted that to life imprisonment two years ago. A fifth plotter, businessman Thomas Mulewa Mupunga, died in prison in 1987 of what the government said was natural causes. A Home Affairs Ministry statement, announcing the releases, hailed the move as a ``momentous occasion'' in Zambia's history. ``The release signifies a victory for the forces of love and forgiveness under the philosophy of humanism,'' the statement said. They were freed at a ceremony attended by officials of the ruling United National Independence Party and church leaders, the statement said. Reporters were excluded. Since the anti-government riots in June, Kaunda, a 67-year-old onetime schoolteacher, has announced a referendum next year for Zambians to decide whether they want a return to a multiparty state. Kaunda, who led the British colony of Northern Rhodesia to independence as Zambia in 1964, outlawed political opposition 17 years ago, arguing that Western-style democracy in Africa whipped up tribal hostilities Under further pressure for change, Kaunda also has announced he would free all political prisoners, release more than 1,000 people arrested during the riots, lifted a dusk-to-dawn curfew and has not made any move against a pro-democracy movement forming with former politicians and civil servants, wealthy businessmen and trade union leaders.

DOC.HEAD: University Offering Bagpipe Music Major
DOC.TEXT: Carnegie Mellon University hopes to ``legitimize'' the bagpipe by offering a major in the shrill-toned reed instrument. The program, with two students, will begin in the university's music department this fall. Sophomore Vince Mulhern, who used to major in mechanical engineering, recently applied for one of the two slots. ``When my friends hear about this, they laugh, but no one has said to me I'm crazy,'' he said. ``Of course I don't know what they say behind my back.'' ``I was getting tired of engineering and this is intriguing,'' said Mulhern, a bagpiper for two years. The new program would be music to the ears of Andrew Carnegie, the Scottish immigrant who became a steel baron and founded the school. The bagpipe is played mainly in Scotland. ``We think we'll be able to legitimize the instrument, which when you think about it has been around a lot longer than some we use in orchestras,'' said Marilyn Taft Thomas, head of the music department. James McIntosh, who has taught the instrument informally at the university for six years, will head the new program. McIntosh said student bagpipers will devote little time to the folksy tunes most often heard in parades. They would concentrate on classical music and, like all other music performance majors, play the piano. ``Apart from anything else, they will leave here qualified to be music teachers and, I think, will find there are good opportunities to teach the bagpipe in high schools,'' McIntosh said. ``I know there are schools who would like to have that but can't find anyone qualified to teach it.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union, Albania Agree to Normalize Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th pvs, `The Soviet...' to CORRECT with Albania instigating break in relations in 1961, not Soviet Union. Pickup 8th pvs, `Albania left...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and Albania today agreed to normalize relations that were broken off 29 years ago during Moscow's split with China, the Tass news agency reported. The agreement to re-establish ties and reopen embassies in Moscow and Tirana was reached during talks that were held in Bulgaria in June and in Tirana today, Tass said. The Soviet delegation was led by Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli Kvitsinsky, Tass reported. Both sides were guided ``by a mutual desire to develop the relations of friendship and cooperation on the basis of sovereignty, equality and non-interference in each other's internal affairs,'' the Tass dispatch said. Moscow and Tirana pledged to expand contacts in the political, economic, scientific, technical and cultural areas, it added. Last week, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov had said Moscow was seeking to restore diplomatic relations with Albania, Europe's last bastion of Stalinism. Albania broke off diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union in 1961 as a result of the Kremlin's split with China, which then became Albania's chief Communist ally. Albania left the Warsaw Pact in 1968 after the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia. The Balkan nation then broke with China in 1978 and established a course fiercely independent of both military blocs. It prided itself on being self-reliant and claimed to be the only country practicing true communism. Albania also has no relations with the United States. It has vowed to resist the democratic reforms sweeping Eastern Europe, and still reveres the late Soviet leader Josef Stalin. Even more important is Communist Albania's founding father, Enver Hoxha, who died in 1985. But in recent weeks, Albanian citizens demanding change forced their way into foreign embassies in Tirana and were allowed to leave the country.

DOC.HEAD: Dudley Moore and Brogan Lane Divorcing
DOC.TEXT: British actor Dudley Moore and Brogan Lane are calling it quits after a 2{-year marriage. A Superior Court divorce petition filed Thursday cited irreconcilable differences. The couple has been separated since July 15. Moore, 55, and Miss Lane, 34, were married Feb. 21, 1988, in Las Vegas. It was Moore's third marriage and Lane's second. The couple has no children. Moore chased Bo Derek in ``10'' and starred as a lovable lush in ``Arthur.'' Lane is a model and aspiring actress. Moore's manager, Lou Pitt, said there would be no comment about the actor's personal life.

DOC.HEAD: EC Commissioner Tries to Seize the Initiative on Subsidy Talks
DOC.TEXT: NEWMARKET-ON-FERGUS, Ireland (AP) _ The European Community's agriculture commissioner on Monday proposed a 30 percent cut in farm subsidies over a 10-year period in an effort to end a dispute that threatens global trade talks. Ray MacSharry made the surprise proposal at a private meeting with the agriculture ministers of the United States, Japan, Canada and Australia. ``This is the first time the community has put a specific figure on the table,'' said European Commission spokesman John Cooney. The U.S. delegation reacted coolly. It said it would be inappropriate to negotiate a proposal outside ongoing talks involving the nations of GATT, or the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. ``This is not a place to cut deals,'' said Kelly Shipp, a spokeswoman for U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who attended the meeting with MacSharry. The delegations from Japan, Canada, and Australia agreed with the United States, she said. All are members of GATT. The United States and 14 other farm exporting countries want the 12-nation European Community to end its export credits system and cut direct subsidies for farmers. The dispute is threatening the successful conclusion of the GATT talks on global trade liberalization. However, the U.S. and EC teams expressed confidence an overall GATT agreement would be reached in December. The so-called ``Quint'' meeting of the world's most powerful agriculture ministers was called by MacSharry and held at Dromoland Castle, about five miles outside Shannon in western Ireland. Several hundred Irish farmers, who depend heavily on EC aid, demonstrated outside the meeting. ``No GATT Sellout'' was their slogan. The other agriculture ministers gathered in Ireland were Japan's Tomio Yamamoto, Australia's John Kerins, and Canada's Donald Mazankowski. The five senior agriculture officials were assessing developments since the Group of Seven summit in Houston in mid-July, when the industrial world's leaders spurred efforts to cut farm supports. MacSharry proposed cutting all European farm support by 30 percent between 1986 and 1996. The offer includes cuts that already have been implemented, Cooney said. He cited reductions of 10 percent in support for crops and a 15 percent cut in livestock support. ``It certainly is a substantive one (proposal). It can't be considered flippant,'' Cooney said. The proposal will be presented to the European Commission in September. The Commission would have to approve it before it could be considered at GATT, he said. GATT negotiators are to meet again in Geneva in late August. They agreed at a meeting last week to compile lists and costs of their farm support by Oct. 1. The developed world's farm subsidies cost consumers and taxpayers $245 billion last year, according to the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

DOC.HEAD: Colleges Take Lessons from Boston U-Chelsea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf to CORRECT spelling of Mercyhurst sted Mercyhurt
DOC.TEXT: Five colleges are hatching plans to help revamp neighboring public schools this fall _ and each say they are drawing lessons from Boston University's unprecedented management takeover of a nearby district. No one is rushing to imitate Boston University's year-old, ambitious effort to manage and radically transform the entire school district of Chelsea, Mass., a nearly broke system of 3,500 students with some of the worst test scores in that state. But the university's 10-year plan to manage Chelsea's day-to-day operations and raise tens of millions of dollars to finance reforms is apparently earning national credence as colleges seek ways to nurture school reform. ``I think the very positive impact of the Boston-Chelsea relationship has been to encourage colleges to become more involved than they have been. But I don't think the model of taking a system over will be the way it goes,'' said Robert Atwell, president of the American Council on Education in Washington. ``The focus is not so much on the model as on the results,'' said Peter Greer, dean of BU's school of education. The point of BU's effort is to show that ``if you want to change education, you have to take a comprehensive approach,'' he said. The BU-Chelsea plan, entering its second year this fall, aims to rebuild dilapidated schools, raise teacher salaries, introduce literacy and prenatal care programs, and boost standardized test scores. So far, however, BU has fallen short of fund-raising goals and is battling the local teacher union. And some in Chelsea still see the university as an invader imposing change. Despite those struggles, officials of at least five colleges interested in helping nearby schools have recently contacted or visited BU to learn what works and what doesn't, college and public school district officials said in interviews. _ George Mason University, in Fairfax, Va., is in early talks that could lead to a contract to help transform the nearby Manassas Park school district. Manassas Park superintendent James Moyers said Monday that the rural, financially pressed district hopes to enter a comprehensive partnership with George Mason, IBM, the city of Manassas Park and the Signal Hill Development Corp. to stock classrooms with computers to revolutionize the way children learn and teachers teach. _ Officials of Glassboro State College, in Glassboro, N.J., General Electric and the Camden public schools are visiting Boston this week ``to find out what works and what doesn't'' in the Chelsea program, said Phil Tumminia, a vice president of Glassboro State. Glassboro State received an $18,500 GE grant this month to draft plans to improve Camden's schools, concentrating on better teacher training. _ Duke University, in Durham, N.C., plans close ties with Durham High School this fall, and the BU-Chelsea experiment was one of several models planners examined, said Duke spokeswoman Janet San Filippo.
