Under plans hatched last spring, Duke will start programs to get parents more involved in schools, identify and teach gifted minority children who may not perform well on standardized tests, and train college students as tutors. _ Mercyhurst College, in Erie, Pa., will hold classes on campus for some 200 gifted Erie pupils from kindergarten through eighth grade starting this fall, said president William Garvey. _ DePauw University, in rural Greencastle, Ind., may send student teachers to Chelsea to expose them to inner city, multicultural classes, said president Robert Bottoms. In each case, officials said BU's management scheme with Chelsea was far too ambitious financially and otherwise for most colleges. Public school officials, for their part, stressed that they had no desire to be taken over by a college or repeat the often-stormy relationship in Chelsea. ``We are not putting ourselves up as experts in secondary school education. We want to listen to them,'' said San Filippo of Duke. ``We don't want to go into this with any sense that we have a plan we're going to impose,'' agreed Tumminia of Glassboro State. Moyers, of Manassas Park, said that at one point George Mason officials wanted a say in naming certain school district administrators. ``The school board was having none of that,'' Moyers said. Another lesson being drawn from the BU experience is the need to let public schools take the initiative. All five colleges stressed that they wanted relationships based on cooperation and shared knowledge. Erie school officials ``are telling us what they want from us,'' Garvey said. The problems BU experienced in its relationship with Chelsea ``didn't bother us,'' said Erie schools superintendent Joseph Rodriguez. ``No one will dictate to anyone.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union, Albania Agree to Normalize Relations
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and Albania agreed Monday to end their nearly three-decade estrangement by restoring diplomatic relations that were severed over the Kremlin's ideological quarrel with China. The agreement to re-establish ties and reopen embassies was reached during talks that were held in Sofia, Bulgaria, on June 29-30 and in Tirana, the Albanian capital, on Monday, the official Soviet news agency Tass said. The decision markep by Albania, Europe's last bastion of hard-line Communism, to emerge from its long postwar isolation. Fed the latest stor nearly 25 years, the Soviet Union has been making overtures to Albania to normalize relations that Albania broke off in 1961 during Moscow's split with China, then an Albanian ally. Kremlin leaders, however, could not overcome the deep distrust of the Soviets that was instilled by Communist Albania's founding father, Enver Hoxha, who died in 1985. The Tass dispatch, which was also was read on Soviet television and radio, said the Soviet Union and Albania were guided in their decision to re-establish ties ``by a mutual desire to develop the relations of friendship and cooperation on the basis of sovereignty, equality and non-interference in each other's internal affairs.'' Moscow and Tirana pledged to o foreign embassies in Tirana and were allowed to leave the country. In May, Alia met with the first official U.S. delegation in Tirana since World War II and said he wants to re-establish diplomatic relations with Washington as soon as possible. U.S.-Albanian relations were broken off in 1946. Also in May, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar visited Tirana and told his hosts that the world welcomed Albania's decision to embark on economic and social reforms. In March 1989, Albania sent its first official delegation to China since their break in relations.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds States Can Lose Money Trying to Raise Taxes
DOC.TEXT: It's hardly surprising, but a survey has found that people will go to great lengths to avoid taxes, even crossing state lines to pay lower sales and excise taxes. The American Legislative Exchange Council, a national bipartisan organization of state lawmakers, commissioned Price Waterhouse to do the survey to find out how much states ultimately pay by charging higher taxes. The survey looked at two pairs of states with pronounced differences in their taxes: Massachusetts and New Hampshire, and Indiana and Illinois. It concluded that New Hampshire enjoys most of the economic benefits in the phenomenon it calls ``cross-border activity.'' For the two Midwestern states there was more give and take, though overall, Indiana came out ahead. Indiana benefits at Illinois' expense from favorable cross-state line trade in tobacco and gasoline; Illinois benefits in the sale of wine and liquor. The survey was released Friday at the group's annual meeting here, where 1,500 participants gathered from Thursday until Sunday. The findings are no surprise, but they suggest that lawmakers need to change their perspective when they set out to raise taxes, said economist Paul Lawrence, author of the survey report. ``Under certain circumstances ... the borders of the states, in terms of the taxpayers, are not geographic borders,'' Lawrence said in a telephone call from an office in Springfield, Va. ``Politicians tend not to think about neighboring states. But when people in Massachusetts raise their taxes to raise revenue, people in New Hampshire end up raising money.'' The commodities surveyed were gasoline, wine and liquor, and tobacco. The years examined were 1975 to 1988. Massachusetts has a sales tax of 5 percent; New Hampshire has none. In 1988, New Hampshire's excise tax on a cigarette carton was $1.70. In Massachusetts it was $2.60. New Hampshire owns all liquor wholesale and retail businesses, keeping the revenue and selling the alcohol at lower prices than those found in Massachusetts. Based on these figures and others, the survey reckoned: _ The average annual economic benefits for New Hampshire came to $22.4 million from added tax revenue; $104.2 million in added retail sales, and 796 jobs earning $8.6 million. _ The cost to Massachusetts was an annual loss of 13 percent of cigarette sales and 7.2 percent of annual wine and liquor sales because Massachusetts residents bought those goods in New Hampshire. In Illinois, fuel taxes came to 21 cents a gallon compared with 18 cents a gallon in Indiana. The tax on wine in Illinois was an estimated $1.13 a gallon compared to $1.47 a gallon in Indiana. Liquor taxes in Illinois were $3.80 a gallon against $4.68 in Indiana. A carton of cigarettes in Illinois came with a tax of $2.72; Indiana taxes on a carton were $2.10. Overall the boon to Indiana totaled $58.8 million in sales and excise taxes, $311.6 million in retail sales, and 1,996 jobs paying $22.5 million. The losses to Illinois came to $69.7 million in potential sales and excise taxes, $376.8 million in potential retail sales, and the loss of 2,949 jobs earning $31 million.

DOC.HEAD: `Country Club' Prison to Become Higher Security Lockup
DOC.TEXT: Inside trader Ivan Boesky and Watergate figure H.R. Haldeman once called it home. Now their ``country club'' prison is being fortified as a higher security lockup for hard-time inmates. Lompoc Federal Prison Camp, which was free of walls, fences, bars, guns and watch towers, will be ready to receive inmates as a medium security prison by early August, said prison spokesman Gavin O'Connor. It's been one of 26 minimum-security federal prisons. ``It's quicker and cheaper to convert the camp to a prison than to build an entirely new facility,'' he said. Most of Lompoc's low-risk inmates will be transferred to other low-security camps on the West Coast in the next few weeks, O'Connor said. Prison camps such as Lompoc are referred to as country club prisons or ``Club Fed'' because of the privileges inmates receive. Prisoners can wander about freely, jog, play tennis or lawn bowl. Guards are unarmed. Escapes have been rare at Lompoc because those caught are sent to a traditional prison, O'Connor said.

DOC.HEAD: Connie Chung Puts Series on Hold, Wants Baby
LaserPhoto NY20
DOC.TEXT: Connie Chung said Monday that she's putting her new television series on hold while she tries to become pregnant. The move, which surprised CBS executives when the 43-year-old anchorwoman asked for it last week, marked the second time this year that a female anchor of a network news series has opted for a family over a show. However, in Chung's case, it would be temporary. CBS said it would welcome ``Face to Face With Connie Chung'' back as a series when she is ready to return. ``We want very much to have a child,'' said Chung, who is married to ``A Current Affair'' anchorman Maury Povich, 51. ``Unfortunately, time is running out for me when it comes to childbearing.'' Chung noted that she will be 44 next month. After consulting with her doctors last week, she said in a statement, she became convinced she needs to ``take a very aggressive approach to having a baby.'' Because of that, she said, she has to lighten her workload, and thus now will only do ``Face to Face'' as periodic specials instead of the series that CBS had put on its Monday night lineup for this fall. CBS will replace Chung's show with ``The Trials of Rosie O'Neill,'' a one-hour dramatic series starring former ``Cagney & Lacey'' star Sharon Gless as recently-divorced lawyer who becomes a public defender. Earlier this year, NBC's Maria Shriver left the ``Sunday Today'' show she had co-anchored since 1987. She said she wanted to spend more time with her baby daughter and her husband, actor Arnold Schwarzenegger, in Los Angeles. Shriver was succeeded by former CNN anchor Mary Alice Williams, who joined NBC last year and gave birth to a daughter in January. Chung, who will continue anchoring the Sunday editions of the ``CBS Evening News,'' reportedly is paid $1.3 million annually. She was not available for comment on her decision to put her ``Face to Face'' series on hold. ``This was a very important decision for Connie,'' CBS Broadcast Group president Howard Stringer said in a statement. ``She has my support, respect and loyalty. When Connie is ready we will happily welcome `Face to Face' back to the schedule as a weekly series.'' Chung, who joined CBS News in 1971 and left for NBC in 1983, returned to CBS last year to anchor last season's low-rated ``Saturday Night With Connie Chung.'' She scored high ratings in May with her first two ``Face to Face'' specials. CBS has been third in ratings for three seasons and hoped Chung's new series would help its bid for a comeback next fall. But George Schweitzer, senior vice president for communications at the Broadcast Group, insisted that her withdrawal won't hurt the network's Monday night plans. ``Not at all,'' he said. CBS' replacement series has a popular, well-known star, and is made by the same team that made ``Cagney & Lacey'' a Monday night staple on CBS, he said. Chung's husband, who has anchored the syndicated ``A Current Affair'' ever since Fox Broadcasting began it in 1986, has signed with the rival Paramount Domestic Television to co-produce and anchor a new talk show that starts in the fall of 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Breaking Into Chief's Hotel Room Acquitted
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of trying to break into a visiting police chief's hotel room has been acquitted of a misdemeanor trespass charge. Ricky F. Sumdum, 31, was arrested May 20 after a man was seen tampering with the window of a room at the Westmark Hotel during the Alaska Police Officers Association convention. The second-floor room was occupied by Chief Brent Moody of Wrangell and his wife, Kathy. Moody said the man tried to pry the window open with a piece of wood and fled when Moody tried to grab him. Sumdum was arrested a few blocks away and Moody identified him. But the chief's identification was challenged in District Court. A jury acquitted Sumdum last week. Defense Attorney Phil Pallenberg said the suspect Moody described was much younger than Sumdum and had shorter hair. Mrs. Moody identified a different man in a photo lineup shortly after Sumdum was arrested, Pallenberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Patricia Kluge Convicted of Improper Driving
DOC.TEXT: Patricia Kluge, estranged wife of billionaire John W. Kluge, was convicted Monday of improper driving and fined $50 for swerving to avoid hitting an animal near her country estate. Mrs. Kluge, who has received recent attention for taking personal trips with Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, did not speak during a 15-minute hearing in Albemarle County General District Court. Lawyers for Mrs. Kluge, 41, argued for the dismissal of a reckless driving charge because the rural road on which she was driving is narrow and does not have shoulders. State Trooper J.E. DeFord said Mrs. Kluge's vehicle went 35 feet down an embankment and flipped one-and-a-half times before coming to a stop. He said Mrs. Kluge, who was traveling alone, escaped serious injury in the April 27 crash because she was wearing a seat belt. Judge Steven Helvin reduced the charge from reckless driving to improper driving. ``I don't think it's reckless driving, but I do think there is some culpability,'' he said. Helvin said people should not swerve uncontrollably for animals. Mrs. Kluge, who also had to pay $22 in court costs, was accompanied to court by two lawyers and a security guard. She left the courthouse afterward without comment.

DOC.HEAD: Gunfire Breaks Out Near TV Station, Parliament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with colonel's briefing, negotiator saying peaceful solution likely. Pickup 9th pvs, `Attiba said...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos POS1,2
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Gunfire and explosions broke out today around the government television station and Parliament, where Moslem extremists held the prime minister and 30 other people hostage for a fourth day. Later today, an Anglican minister negotiating between the government and the rebels said a settlement was likely. The heaviest shooting was centered on the television station, whose employees were taken hostage Friday. Automatic rifle and machine-gun fire was punctuated by what sounded like artillery booms. One witness said he heard four explosions that sounded like bombs. ``A major firefight is going on,'' said a diplomatic source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The shooting at the station appeared to be coming from two directions, but it was not clear whether security forces had tried to storm the building. Earlier, automatic weapons fire rang out near Parliament, about a mile from the television station, where rebels seized Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson on Friday. Witnesses said they heard what sounded like heavy artillery booms. A ham radio operator in Trinidad said he monitored a radio communication indicating security forces had stormed the television station and were moving on Parliament. But Col. Ralph Brown of the Trinidad-Tobago Defense Force denied the station was attacked. He told reporters that troops had fired on the TV station when the rebels tried to leave the building. ``Some of his men tried to come out and we are not letting them out.'' An Anglican minister who was negotiating between the rebels and the government, the Rev. Knolly Clarke, also spoke with reporters early this afternoon. When asked if a peaceful solution was likely, he said, ``Yes, today. The end is in sight.'' One of the rebels inside Parliament, Kwasi Attiba, said by telephone that a tentative agreement with the government had been reached to end the siege. Attiba said the accord called for Robinson to resign immediately and be replaced by Deputy Prime Minister Winston Dookeran. Attiba gave no indication when Robinson and other other hostages would be released, and no government official could be reached to confirm his report. An agreement was also reported Sunday by a television executive, Jones Madeira, who was held at the station. He said in a telephone interview that under the plan, Robinson would turn over power to an interim government, which would rule until elections in three months. Robinson won the 1986 parliamentary elections by a landslide, and the next elections are not scheduled until 1991. The rebels claim Robinson's government is corrupt and responsible for widespread poverty in this once oil-rich country. They claimed Saturday to have wired Robinson with explosives and threatened to blow him up if a rescue attempt was made. Attiba said the gunfire at Parliament came from police ``who have been attempting to thwart'' negotiations. Attiba said the rebels were holding eight government ministers along with the prime minister. Energy Minister Herbert Atwell said Sunday the two sides were far from a settlement. But Attiba said: ``We are very hopeful for an amicable solution.'' Security forces patrolled the capital with orders to shoot looters on sight. Abu Bakr, leader of a black Moslem commune, stormed Parliament on Friday and captured Robinson and most of his Cabinet. Bakr is believed backed by Libya but has little general support. Simultaneously, the rebels seized the government television station and its employees. Unconfirmed reports said more than 20 people had been killed in the fighting. A medical officer at the state hospital said today he could confirm only five deaths, including that of a police officer. Fires burned in the capital of Port-of-Spain on Sunday. There was scattered gunfire and widespread looting. Convoys of cars and pickup trucks were loading up with everything from looted powdered milk to refrigerators, electric stoves and television sets. The government sent police and military patrols to re-establish order and continued a nationwide curfew that was imposed Saturday. Atwell, representing the government, appeared on national television late Sunday with an official statement saying: ``I am in no position to offer any hope that the situation will be resolved speedily and-or amicably.'' He confirmed reports that Robinson and Justice Minister Selwyn Richardson had each been shot in the leg. State-run radio 610 said Nolli Clarke, an Anglican priest, was the official mediator with help from Anglican Bishop Clive Abdullah and Roman Catholic Archbishop Anthony Patin. The Red Cross sent mobile units to take blood donations from people too frightened to leave their homes. Radio 610 estimated damage downtown at $50 million as thousands of people looted stores, shopping centers, warehouses and industrial plants. A spokeswoman for President Bush said Sunday that American citizens and tourists on Trinidad and Tobago did not appear to be in danger. ``Obviously we support the government and are coordinating closely with them until the situation is resolved,'' a State Department official said in Washington. The official did not want to be identified. Bakr is a former policeman in his mid-40s who converted to Islam in 1980 while living in Canada. He founded Jamaat al-Muslimeen, which means the Moslem Group in Arabic, in 1984 and set up a commune on land he said had been donated to Moslems by the late prime minister, Eric Williams. Bakr built a mosque, a school and a kitchen to feed the homeless. Some 250 to 300 Moslems live there. Bakr has visited Libya several times and is believed to have received assistance from that country. He has said the coup was intended to stop ``poverty and the destruction'' of Trinidad and Tobago, which has high unemployment and skyrocketing food prices.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Thanks Governors For Bipartisan Effort on Education
DOC.TEXT: President Bush thanked the nation's governors for a bipartisan ``constructive relationship'' on education Monday, even as Democrats stepped up their protest against the administration's latest tax proposal. Bush addressed the governors at their National Governors' Association annual summer conference, speaking by remote telephone hookup from the White House. He pledged continued support for the education reform goals he and the governors agreed on last year, and endorsed their revised plans for a national oversight panel that will grade the states and federal government on progress in meeting the goals. Democrats had insisted on the changes to deny Republicans control of the panel. ``I think it is essential there be some definitive way of measuring progress toward these education goals during the '90s, and this decision ... makes good sense,'' Bush said. ``I want to thank everyone there for the constructive relationship that we've developed.'' Washington Gov. Booth Gardner, a Democrat and incoming chairman of the governors, asked Bush to obtain full federal funding for Head Start and early childhood development programs that are part of the education goals. Bush said, ``We'll see what we can do.'' Democrats, meanwhile, were circulating a letter for signature by the governors that protests in strong terms the administration's proposal in budget negotiations to raise federal revenues by limiting the deduction for state income taxes _ a proposal governors say encroaches on state tax bases. ``To eliminate this deduction would result in a double tax on our citizens,'' said the letter. It was being pushed by Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, whom Bush defeated in the 1988 presidential election, and Maryland Gov. William Donald Schaefer. ``The notion of putting the burden on the states again for Washington's inability to deal with its fiscal problems is just outrageous,'' Dukakis said in an interview. Governors in both parties have voiced opposition to the federal proposal, arguing that limiting the deduction for state taxes to $10,000 would make it more difficult for states to raise their own taxes and put pressure on them to roll back income taxes. They said it comes after states have spent a decade absorbing cuts in federal aid and after most states have had to raise their own taxes. Dukakis said Bush, who used his ``read my lips, no new taxes'' slogan so effectively in the 1988 campaign, has made the deficit worse by delaying action and now, in breaking his pledge, is hammering the states. ``If Mr. Bush, no matter how devastating it might have been to his poll ratings, had moved early as everybody knew had to be done ... I don't think we'd be in the kind of mess we're in now,'' Dukakis said. The letter pushed by Dukakis and Schaefer went beyond a milder mention that Republican Gov. Terry Branstad, outgoing chairman of the governors' organization, and Gardner made in a letter to Bush before the meeting. Dukakis' letter said the administration's plan amounts to a suggestion ``that our citizens should pay a federal penalty tax for living in a state that has taken responsibility'' for paying for its own services. The deduction issue affects states unevenly, falling heaviest on Northeastern states with high income taxes and not affecting those that have no income tax. The governors made only brief mention of their opposition when White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, former governor of New Hampshire, appeared before the governors Sunday. Sununu said he couldn't talk about items that were a part of budget negotiations with Congress. But Dukakis noted that the proposal wouldn't limit the deduction for local property taxes, and that ``it just so happens New Hampshire has the highest property taxes in the country.'' New Hampshire has no income tax.

DOC.HEAD: White House rejects Proposal for Commission to Investigate S&L Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 7th graf to UPDATE with remarks by Bush to the governors; pick up 8th graf, bgng ``Sunday's opening.''
DOC.TEXT: A proposal by Democratic governors for a national commission to investigate the savings and loan crisis was rejected today by the White House. ``We do feel it is unnecessary to create another bureacratic body,'' White House deputy press secretary Stephen Hart said in Washington. ``We think the best thing to do is to work quickly on the current caseload with the funds and the processes we now have in place which are working,'' Hart said. ... ``We feel it's not time to point fingers but it's time to get the money that's owed to the depositors back in their hands.'' The commission idea was pushed by Democrats at the National Governors' Association annual summer conference. They also forced Republicans to accept changes in a proposed national education oversight panel made up of governors, members of Congress and White House appointees. ```Bipartisan' is a very convenient word when you have a president of your party because what you're asking is to have everyone walk hand-in-hand with the president,'' said Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste, head of the Democratic governors, who is considered to have presidential ambitions. However, he added, ``that isn't real bipartisan policy-making.'' Separately, President Bush addressed the meeting by telephone and said he wanted to continue a partnership with the governors to improve America's schools. ``I recognize there is diversity and I've made it a point not to get involved in any state, pointing out how a governor might attempt to do the job better,'' Bush said. Sunday's opening session got off to a rocky start when Democrats expressed their frustration over an element of the education reforms they agreed on with President Bush last fall and winter. Fearing that a national panel to grade states on their progress in meeting education goals could become a partisan sword in the hands of the GOP-controlled White House, Democratic governors failed to show up for a task force meeting on education with their GOP colleagues. After a series of closed-door meetings, the governors agreed to a formula making any decisions impossible without a three-quarters majority _ giving Democrats on the panel an effective veto power. They also agreed that the panel would give the federal government _ and the Bush White House _ a score on how it lives up to goals for improving federal education research and supporting early childhood development. Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell of South Carolina fumed that Democrats were trying to polarize the governors and disrupt a year's consensus on education reforms. Thirty-six governor's seats are at stake in this fall's elections. ``If partisanship is more important than education, then I'll let them defend that,'' Campbell said. White House chief of staff John Sununu, a former chairman of the governors as New Hampshire's chief executive, appeared before his former colleagues to defend the administration's latest proposal to raise revenue by limiting the deductibility of state and local taxes. Governors in both parties oppose the idea as an encroachment on state tax authority. Celeste reminded Sununu that when he headed the governors' association ``one of the concerns you raised at that time was how to protect the revenue base of state and local government.'' But Sununu responded that the original Bush budget was ``consistent with the concerns you raised.'' He warned that without a deficit-reduction agreement domestic programs face 40 percent cuts under the automatic budget-balancing law. The proposal on S&Ls amounts to a statement of concern and a request to Congress and the president. It passed on a voice vote of the NGA executive committee and is subject to a vote of all the governors on Tuesday, the meeting's last day. Michigan Gov. James Blanchard, a Democrat, predicted Congress and President Bush would ignore it. But he said the statement amounted to ``a vote of no-confidence in federal action'' on S&Ls so far. Virginia Gov. Douglas Wilder, a Democrat, who proposed the commission idea, said its job would be to determine what went wrong. He insisted he was ``not interested in bashing the administration.'' ``The only people who are going to pay are the taxpayers,'' Wilder said. ``The taxpayers are entitled to know.'' Republican governors unsuccessfully tried to delete mention of the commission. Gov. Garrey Carruthers of New Mexico called it ``a feel-good'' vote, and Gov. John Ashcroft of Missouri said it would only delay a solution. ``I think the time for studying is over,'' Ashcroft said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed, 80 Injured When Bridge Railings Give Way
DOC.TEXT: Guard rails on a bridge crammed with merchants and shoppers gave way under the weight of the crowd, and two people were killed and 80 injured as they fell into the river below, state media said Monday. The state news agency Rompres said 10 of the injured were in critical condition after Sunday's accident. It said the accident apparently was caused by overcrowding due to ``careless merchants'' selling their wares on the bridge, which leads to the flea market in the Transylvanian city of Tirgu Mures. The crowd reportedly pressed against a railing, causing it to collapse. In the melee that ensued, the other railing also gave way, and dozens of people fell into the river Mures 18 feet below. Rompress said two women died. The report said 26 of the injured required hospitalization. Most suffered broken bones and chest injuries. Some newspapers in recent weeks had criticized private traders in the city, who reportedly acquire goods from state-run shops illegally and resell them at much higher prices on the black market. Romania for years has been plagued by widespread consumer and food shortages. Tirgu Mures is in central Romania. It was the site of violent clashes between ethnic Romanians and ethnic Hungarians that left at least six dead and hundreds injured in mid-March.

DOC.HEAD: Increasing Security Will Have Little Effect, Experts Warn
With AM-Britain-Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A series of Irish Republican Army bombings has highlighted the group's ability to get around security in England, where fear of terrorism is balanced against a determination to live normally. Police believe the bomb that killed Conservative Party lawmaker Ian Gow Monday was planted by the IRA, which has recently struck against the British army, the Stock Exchange and a London club favored by Conservatives. No group, however, immediately claimed responsibility for the slaying of Gow outside his home in Southeastern Hankham. Metal detectors at the House of Commons and a barrier guarding the prime minister's home testify to the threat, but most of London remains a relaxed and open city. Politicians and experts on terrorism argue that intensive security and fear would indicate a victory for the IRA, which has waged a terrorist campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland for two decades. Gow, killed by a bomb stuck beneath his car, had been warned he was on an IRA hit list. But his telephone number was listed and neighbors said his gate was often open. ``Mr. Gow was determined not to live in a castle and be protected,'' said Jonathan Graves, parish priest in Gow's village. ``He lived an open life.'' Peter Bottomley, another Conservative lawmaker, expressed the feeling of many politicians on increased security: ``We need to take obvious and sensible precautions. ... But the idea that each of us can have four bodyguards around us would mean that the IRA had won.'' The recent attacks, however, have prompted appeals for a return of the tight security following the death of six people in an IRA bombing at Harrod's department store in 1983. For a time, bags and parcels were searched at shop entrances. Scotland Yard recently distributed 13,000 posters advertising a toll-free hotline for reporting suspicious activities. A spokeswoman for Scotland Yard said a surge in notifications of suspicious parcels indicated heightened public concern. Late last year, a gate and a retractable concrete barrier were installed at Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's official residence, No. 10 Downing Street. But terrorism expert Ian Geldard said increasing security for all politicians _ who now rely on mundane precautions such as checking beneath cars _ would not necessarily be the best solution. ``You can never have total security,'' Geldard said. ``The terrorists always have the advantage because they can choose the time and the place.'' Geldard, editor of Terror Update, a privately circulated newsletter, said the IRA clearly has targeted specific establishments and individuals. ``It would not be particularly sensible to increase security for everyone. The amount of disruption would be a victory for the IRA,'' he said. An unidentified IRA leader discussed the group's strategy in an interview published in the June 28 edition of Republican News, the weekly newspaper of the IRA and its Sinn Fein political wing. The IRA intends to ``surprise the enemy, give them no rest, continually pressurize them and of course to hit them where it hurts, preferably at the central nervous system,'' the leader said. He gave as an example the attack on the Carlton Club, a facility frequented primarily by members of the Conservative Party. There was no warning before that bombing or before Gow was killed. But eight warnings preceded the explosion in the visitor's gallery at the Stock Exchange on July 20. Mrs. Thatcher on Monday urged lawmakers to take warnings seriously. ``Many members of Parliament, indeed all of them, will have been given advice to have special regard for safety,'' she said. ``I make one plea, that they take that advice very seriously indeed, for themselves and their families and their staffs.'' Government security advisers refuse to detail arrangements, but it is widely believed lawmakers are advised to vary their daily routine. Mrs. Thatcher Monday told lawmakers to check under their cars and examine all parcels arriving by mail.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Goes on Vacation
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev left Monday for a vacation in the Crimea, in southern Russia, the Tass news agency said. The one-sentence item provided no other details on his trip. Gorbachev usually takes about a month's vacation in August. The new session of the Supreme Soviet legislature, expected to take up the nation's critical economic plan, convenes Sept. 3. In a separate dispatch, Tass said Gorbachev expressed his gratitude to various Communist Party officials, groups and Soviet citizens congratulating him on his re-election as general secretary at the 28th Communist Party congress. Gorbachev said he was moved by their good wishes, the news agency reported. ``I shall apply every effort, using the rights and possibilities that go with my state and party posts, to make sure current difficulties will be overcome and decisive headway made along the path of far-reaching political and economic reform and renewal in every aspect of society's life,'' Tass quoted Gorbachev as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Say At Least 600 Refugees Massacred in Church
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with seven grafs to UPDATE with 600 reported dead by witnesses, details, minor editing to conform. Pickup 7th pvs, `A spokesman...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based partly on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith and photographer Alistair Sinclair were among them.

Government troops today broke into a refugee camp in Monrovia and massacred at least 600 people, most of them women and children, witnesses said. The government denied responsibility. People who said they escaped the attack said about 30 soldiers blasted the church door down with machines guns. They then opened fire on an estimated 2,000 people from the Gio and Mano tribes who had taken refuge there. The Gio and Mano tribes speak a different language than the government troops. One witness who visited the Lutheran Church compound in the Sinkor district of the capital said he saw women with their heads smashed open or blown to pieces by bullets, babies still tied to their backs. Bodies of other people were hanging from the window frames of the church building, apparently killed while trying to escape, he said. ``I saw dead bodies all around,'' the source said. ``This is genocide.'' He spoke on condition of anonymity. Earlier today in Washington, White House deputy press secretary Stephen Hart said U.S. Embassy officials confirmed that Liberian troops slaughtered at least 200 people at the church compound. There was no independent confirmation of the 600 dead figure. A spokesman for President Samuel Doe said rebels were responsible for the killings. In a radio telephone call to the British Broadcasting Corp. in London, the spokesman said rebels wearing government uniforms killed the civilians. Refugees at a Methodist church across the street fled when they heard the killing. Thousands of refugees fleeing the civil war between rebel forces and the crumbling government of President Samuel Doe are crowded into refugee camps in the area. Their numbers have swelled recently as rebel troops have stormed into Monrovia. The witnesses said soldiers broke into the church compound at about 2 a.m. when the refugees were asleep. There was no telephone in the compound, so the victims had no way of calling for help. Most refugees were members of the Gio and Mano tribes, which form the main support for the rebels. Most of Doe's troops are from his Krahn tribe and the Mandingo tribe. Refugees sought protection at the church at the end of May after government soldiers attacked them at U.N. headquarters in Monrovia. The soldiers killed an unarmed security guard and abducted about 30 civilian men. Many of their bodies were later discovered on the outskirts of the capital. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar withdrew all U.N. staff from Liberia in protest, halting an emergency program to aid war refugees. The U.N. chief said in New York that he reacted ``with horror and dismay'' to today's massacre. The White House condemned the massacre as a ``senseless act of terror.'' But it said the United States was not about to send in any troops. ``At this point we don't believe that would be a prudent course of action,'' Hart told reporters. As street battles raged in downtown Monrovia, rebel leader Prince Johnson seemed more preoccupied with his power struggle with a rival leader than with victory over President Doe. Johnson told two Western photographers on Sunday that the rival rebel leader, Charles Taylor, is ``a criminal and a rogue.'' ``He contacted Libya to bring communism here, and Moammar Gadhafi gave him $8 million to stage the Liberian revolution,'' Johnson alleged as he met the photographers in a small cafe in a Monrovian suburb. Taylor has consistently denied reports he received aid from Gadhafi and claims to be a die-hard capitalist. In a separate meeting with foreign reporters Sunday, Johnson said he was leading the main rebel attack on Monrovia and claimed to have 7,000 men under his command, including 4,000 deserters from Doe's army. ``I will get Doe. He is not going to get away,'' said the 38-year-old Johnson, whose forces had advanced to within a mile of Doe's seaside mansion. Johnson said he would install a civilian government after Doe is overthrown. Taylor's forces remained in Paynesville, about six miles east of downtown, where their advance has been blocked for several weeks by stiff resistance from government troops. Taylor claims to have at least 5,000 fighters. As Johnson spoke to reporters from the back of a heavily armed pickup truck, his forces captured street fter street in fierce fighting. The streets were filled with spent cartridges and most of the buildings in the area were riddled with bullet holes after three days of battles. Bodies of dozens of civilians shot by retreating government troops late Saturday lay in the streets of the downtown business district. Among the public buildings captured by the rebels were the defense ministry, the central post office and the national bank. Doe remained barricaded in his hilltop executive mansion, surrounded by an elite guard of troops. Rebels reportedly killed Doe's assistant minister of defense, Steven Blayee, as he was trying to escape from the capital Sunday morning. Johnson, who split with Taylor in February, said the two had trained in Libya with 167 men who later formed the backbone of the rebellion. He said Taylor had agreed to adhere to Libyan socialist principles, while he had not. The rebels invaded in December from Ivory Coast, accusing Doe's government of corruption and human rights abuses. Doe took power in a bloody 1980 coup that ousted the elitist descendants of freed American slaves who founded the nation in 1847. Liberia has 2 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates on Short-term Treasury Securities Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were mixed in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $9.3 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.50 percent, up from 7.49 percent last week. Another $9.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.37 percent, down from 7.40 percent last week. The three-month bill rate was the highest since they sold for 7.62 percent on July 16. The six-month bill rate was the lowest since it averaged 7.30 percent last Dec. 4. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.75 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,810.40 and 7.76 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,627.40. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.85 percent last week, down from 7.87 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Pearl Bailey Leaves Hospital With New Knee
DOC.TEXT: Pearl Bailey left the hospital Monday after undergoing surgery to replace her arthritic left knee with a metal and plastic joint. The entertainer had the operation July 11 at Pennsylvania Hospital. Bailey, 72, will stay in Philadelphia for about a week to continue physical therapy, the hospital said. Back in her Arizona home, she will continue exercising and in six weeks should be able to resume daily activities. The bone and cartilage in the knee had degenerated, doctors said. With her new knee, she was able to walk with a cane.

DOC.HEAD: Deadline to File for Election Slips By Candidates
DOC.TEXT: There won't be a single City Council candidate on the November ballot in this central Arkansas town. The incumbents were not apathetic, just forgetful. ``We flat goofed up,'' Alderman John Sutton said Sunday, explaining how he and the rest of the council missed Friday's deadline to file for re-election. Mayor Floyd ``Sonny'' Johnson filed in the nick of time, after being reminded of a change in the filing date. Johnson drew one challenger, but no one filed petitions to run for the council, which helps govern this town of about 1,200 southeast of Little Rock. The six council members, all of whom want their seats back, have until September to file as write-in candidates. But as write-ins, their names would not be printed on the November ballot. The filing deadline was changed last year from September to July.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Cuts Stars From Personal Staff
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney ordered Monday that the number of generals and admirals assigned to his staff be cut in half. Cheney directed that 13 of the 27 spots on his personal staff that are saved for Army, Air Force, Marine generals and Navy admirals be eliminated, filled with civilians, or given to lower ranking military officers, a Pentagon statement said. The effect isn't necessarily immediate, since the changes will be made when the officers in the present positions finish their tours of duty or move on to their next assignments, the statement said. The change is in line with the Defense Department's moves to pare the nation's armed forces in response to ``world changes and tighter budgets,'' the statement said. The affected job positions include the adviser for NATO Affairs, the deputy assistant secretary of defense for legislative affairs, the assistant inspector general, and the assistant to the assistant to the Secretary of Defense for atomic energy. It follows an order Cheney made last month to eliminate 78 of the Pentagon's 1,073 flag officer positions over the next four years. Monday's action doesn't add to that number, it only designates that 13 of those general officer slots no longer be on Cheney's personal staff, the statement said. The managers of the staff organizations affected by Cheney's decision can decide what will be done with each slot, the statement said. ``With fewer generals and admirals, those who remain must be placed in positions of command and crucial military responsibility,'' the statement quoted Cheney as saying. ``We cannot afford to assign our most seasoned and experienced military officers to Pentagon staff jobs that could be handled by civilians or less senior military officers.'' Pentagon spokesman Bill Turner said he knew of no study that had been undertaken to determine the cost savings behind such a move. Turner predicted, however, that the long-term savings could be substantial due to reduced salaries and the cost of the support facilities generally offered high-ranking military men and women. The lowest-ranking general, a one-star, now earns a little over $69,000 a year, not including allowances for such things as housing and food. A four-star receives a maximum of $83,000 a year in base pay, Turner said.

DOC.HEAD: Berry Surrenders on Drug, Pornography Charges
DOC.TEXT: Rock 'n' roll star Chuck Berry surrendered to police Monday to face charges of marijuana possession and child abuse, authorities said. The St. Charles County Sheriff's office said Berry, who had been on tour in Europe, surrendered Monday morning and was taken to jail, where he was booked. He later appeared before Associate Circuit Judge Lucy Rauch, who set bond at $20,000. The 63-year-old musician, known for such rock 'n' roll standards as ``Johnny B. Goode,'' and ``Roll Over Beethoven,'' posted a property bond and was released, officials said. Berry was charged July 19 after local drug agents raided his rural estate near Wentzville, about 40 miles west of St. Louis. A statement released by William Hannah, St. Charles County prosecutor, said four charges were filed against Berry. One charge was for possession of over 35 grams of marijuana. Three child abuse charges are based on allegations Berry made nude films of youths under the age of 17 for sexual gratification. Authorities said the search of his estate turned up several plastic bags of marijuana, some hashish, two .22-caliber rifles and a shotgun, plus $122,000 and various pornographic videotapes, slides and books. Berry has denied using drugs. Arraignment was scheduled for Aug. 30.

DOC.HEAD: New Musicals, A Laboratory for New Shows, Folds
DOC.TEXT: New Musicals, an ambitious laboratory for the development of new American musical theater, has folded after only one production, it was announced Monday. The production company was terminated July 25, one month after its first show, ``Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' closed out a disappointing run at the State University of New York at Purchase. ``I overestimated the box-office income and undercapitalized the operation,'' said Martin J. Bell, producing director of New Musicals. ``The size of our audience could only support workshops or small musicals, which was contrary to our mission.'' ``Spider Woman'' was a lavish musical version of the Manuel Puig novel. It had a book by Terrence McNally, a score by John Kander and Fred Ebb and was directed by Harold Prince. The musical, which starred John Rubinstein and Kevin Gray, played an eight-week engagement in Purchase, from May 1 through June 24. New Musicals had a $10 million budget for its first year which was to have included three more musicals. Investors, including Capital Cities-ABC, Inc., Columbia Artists Management, Inc., and Jujamcyn Theaters, had put up a total of about $2.5 million to get the project going. Other moneys were expected from the box-office receipts of ``Spider Woman,'' which drew less than 40 percent capacity at a 1,375-seat theater in the university's performing arts complex. Bell said the box-office receipts were hurt by the mostly negative reviews, especially in The New York Times. The producer had asked that critics not review the show because it was a work in progress and that a review ``defeats what we're trying to do here.'' Besides the Times, the musical was reviewed by the Daily News, the New York Post, The Associated Press and several other publications. ``My heart is broken, but working on `Kiss of the Spider Woman' with Hal Prince, John Kander, Fred Ebb, Terrence McNally and the rest of the gang was worth it all,'' Bell said. ``There were times sitting in that theater during the process when I knew this was the only place on Earth I wanted to be.''

DOC.HEAD: More Than 100 Polish Parliament Members Urge Jaruzelski to Quit
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 members of Parliament have signed a petition urging President Wojciech Jaruzelski to resign, newspapers reported Monday. The signatures were gathered late Friday by members of the Center Alliance, a 2-month-old political organization that backs the election of Solidarity Chairman Lech Walesa to replace Jaruzelski this fall, said the government-owned daily Rzeczpospolita. Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party leader, has already indicated he will resign before his term officially expires in July 1995. Jaruzelski told the Sejm, the 460-member lower house of parliament, on Saturday that he endorses plans to hold a debate in September on the proper timing of new presidential and parliamentary elections. The Center Alliance petition asks Jaruzelski to step down in recognition that conditions have changed since his election in July 1989. ``Appreciating your contributions, Mr. President, since taking office, we appeal to you now to show understanding for the historic challenges of the new era and to resign from office,'' the petition said. Jaruzelski was elected president by Parliament with the help of some members of Solidarity a year ago after Poland's Communist Party became the first in the East bloc to give up its monopoly on power and hold partially free elections. At the time, it was thought Jaruzelski's holding the presidency would insure smooth relations with the Soviet Union and Poland's then-hard-line Communist neighbors, East Germany and Czechoslovakia. Since then, orthodox Communist leaders have been ousted in a democratic upheavals that led to multiparty elections throughout Eastern Europe. Many Poles consider Jaruzelski's remaining as president to be out of step with the changes elsewhere in the region. Jaruzelski led the December 1981 martial law crackdown that suppressed the Solidarity labor movement, but later initiated negotiations on power-sharing that resulted in the union becoming legal again last year. Walesa has not declared his intention to run for president, but his supporters are gathering allies in the Sejm and the 100-member Senate for a possible vote to elect him to the post in coming months. Opposing Walesa are members of a new pro-government party, the Citizens Movement for Democratic Action, which favors a constitutional amendment that would require a direct popular vote for president. They believe Walesa could be defeated in such a ballot. Some members of Democratic Action are promoting Solidarity Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki as a more viable presidential candidate than Walesa. Both Democratic Action and Center Alliance have grown out of the Solidarity movement, now deeply split into pro-Walesa and pro-Mazowiecki wings.

DOC.HEAD: Recuperating Vice President's Wife Celebrates Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Quayle, recuperating from a hysterectomy, celebrated her 41st birthday Sunday with her family and spent part of the day responding to a deluge of get-well messages and cards, a spokeswoman said Monday. Mrs. Quayle, wife of Vice President Dan Quayle, is recovering well but will curtail her schedule for the next four to six weeks in accordance with her doctor's advice, said Denise Balzano, her chief of staff. She said Mrs. Quayle had received boxes of messages and cards. ``She is most appreciative of everyone's thoughtfulness and their prayers,'' Mrs. Balzano said. Mrs. Quayle returned home last Wednesday, four days after undergoing a hysterectomy. The vice president's press office said the operation was performed because Pap smears indicated she had ``severe dysplasia,'' a cell abnormality that experts said can be a precursor to cervical cancer.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Official: No Solution in Sight to Diplomatic Impasse
DOC.TEXT: A Spanish diplomat said Monday there is no solution in sight to a conflict with Cuban authorities over 18 asylum-seekers at the Spanish Embassy in Havana, the Notimex news agency reported. The Mexican government agency quoted Fidel Sandagorta, first-secretary at the embassy, as saying there was no indication anything could lead to a quick end to the impasse, which has strained relations between Spain and its former colony, Cuba. The refugees at the Spanish Embassy are the last remaining of dozens who sought asylum in Swiss, Czechoslovak, Spanish and Italian missions starting July 9. On Saturday, four Cubans left the Italian ambassador's residence in Havana after President Fidel Castro promised not to prosecute refugees who fled to diplomatic compounds. The diplomat said Spain maintains its position that the refugees cannot be forced to abandon the embassy unless there are satisfactory conditions for their departure. But Cuba will not let anyone leave the country who has entered a diplomatic mission by force. Havana accused the United States of masterminding the waive of refugees as part of an alleged plot to destabilize Cuba, charges the United States denied. Spain suspended a $2.5 million aid program after Cuba took a hard-line on Cubans who entered the Spanish Embassy. Castro accused Spain of collaborating with the United States and renounced the aid.

DOC.HEAD: State Can Contact Patients Of Dentist With AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Patients of a Florida dentist who may have given a woman AIDS could be tracked down and asked to take AIDS tests, but they couldn't be told why, officials said Monday. Florida law protects the identity of anyone who has AIDS, even from those who may have been infected by the person. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control last week described a case involving a 21-year-old college student who may have gotten AIDS from her dentist during a tooth extraction. The dentist was diagnosed with AIDS three months earlier and wore gloves and a mask. State health officials have made no public comment about published reports that the woman was from somewhere in Florida. Two sources, however, confirmed Monday on condition they not be identified, that it was a Florida dentist. The CDC said the case was the first in the nation involving a health professional possibly transmitting AIDS, although researchers could not positively say how the woman got infected. But the CDC did rule out more conventional ways of getting the disease such as sexual encounters or intravenous drug use. The name of any Florida resident who has acquired immune deficiency syndrome or who tests positive for the AIDS virus is confidential under Florida law, said spokesman Steve Konicki of the Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services. While officials wouldn't confirm publicly that the CDC case originated in Florida, they were willing to say that if it did, the state has the ability to track down the dentist's patients to urge them to be tested for AIDS. ``If this was a Florida case, HRS would be able to contact patients of the doctor,'' said Brian Ballard, Gov. Bob Martinez's chief of staff. ``I can assure you that HRS understands their mission is public safety.'' The patients would not be told, however, that their connection to the dentist was the reason they were asked to take an AIDS test, Konicki said. That same confidentiality protection applies to anyone with AIDS to encourage them to disclose names of people to whom they may have transmitted the disease. ``The intent of the law, the confidentiality part of the law, is that it only goes to the identity of somebody who's infected,'' said state Rep. Lois Frankel, chairwoman of the task force that produced a sweeping 1988 Florida AIDS law. ``Confidentiality is an important part of contact tracing,'' she said. ``You can't force someone to give you the name of a partner.'' Questions were raised about the laws that protect patient records of doctors and dentists, which would be one of the only ways to obtain names of those at risk. While Ballard said the state should have access to the overriding issue of public health, others aren't so sure. ``It's confidential. The only thing (the state) could do is go to court and get a court order. They'd have to rule that the case overrides the patient-doctor relationship,'' said state Rep. Elaine Gordon, chairwoman of the House Health Care Committee. Announcement of the case and the national attention it triggered drew complaints from the American Dental Association, which worried that it would make the public fear a dentist's office as a place of ``danger and infection.'' Florida health officials questioned whether the CDC knew enough to go public with such a potentially frightening report. Dr. Harold Jaffe, deputy director for science at the CDC's HIV-AIDS program, responded that it was in the public's interest to publicize the case.

DOC.HEAD: Bumper U.S. Marijuana Crop Predicted
DOC.TEXT: A mild, rainy summer has been ideal for marijuana cultivation in the Midwest, police say as they work to weed out an expected bumper crop. It isn't just the weather that's boosting production. Stepped-up federal efforts to stop drugs from being smuggled into the country have driven up the price of marijuana, encouraging the growers to increase their efforts, according to federal authorities and law enforcement officials in several states. ``We've had all this rain, good hot, humid weather which marijuana thrives in, and plenty of people interested in making a little money,'' said Sgt. Jim Hinkle of the Illinois State Police. Hinkle coordinates Operation Cash Crop, an eradication program the state runs jointly with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Oklahoma, Texas and Wisconsin are expected to have massive tracts of cultivated and wild marijuana by fall, officials said. California, though wracked by drought, also is likely to produce a bumper crop of marijuana, officials said. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration says U.S.-grown marijuana is netting drug dealers hundreds of millions of dollars annually. Cultivated, high quality marijuana _ like the potent sinsemilla variety _ sells for about $2,500 a pound, Hinkle said. One plant can provide a pound of the drug, he said. The street price of average-grade marijuana is about $160 to $240 per ounce this year across the country, up from $120 to $180 an ounce a year ago, according to the DEA. Authorities hope to get the jump on pot growers before the harvest season, which lasts for three months beginning in September. In Northern California over the weekend, about 200 federal and state agents descended on prime public land to hunt for pot in what was called the largest marijuana raid in the state. An even bigger problem, officials say, is finding ``ditch weed.'' The wild plant has little potency but is used to cheat buyers by mixing with higher-quality strains. Ditch weed grows in abundance in many states _ much to the consternation of police _ because it is an offspring of seeds planted when marijuana was cultivated to make hemp rope in World War II, drug officials say. ``It is, after all, a weed, and it grows _ and grows and grows,'' Hinkle said. Nebraska in 1989 eradicated more than 73 million ditch weed plants and 6,300 cultivated marijuana plants. That's nearly twice the number of ditch weed plants plucked in Indiana, which ranks second to Nebraska in wild weed destruction, according to DEA statistics. Jeff Hanson, spokesman for the Nebraska State Patrol, said the state has been a magnet for people looking for free marijuana. ``I think word kind of spread around that we have marijuana here,'' Hanson said in a telephone interview. ``We get a lot of out-of-state plates on these rural dirt roads, and you don't have to be super-intelligent to figure out these people aren't out there just to enjoy the scenery.'' Police everywhere say pot farmers are hard to catch because the land where marijuana thrives often is isolated. Many states rely on informants and aerial surveillance to nab suspects and spot marijuana plots. Illinois offers $1,000 to residents who call in with information leading to a substantive arrest. Critics say the use of informants smacks of spying on the neighbors, but law enforcement officials' contend the public's help in eradicating illegal drugs is vital. ``It's difficult to catch these guys and to prove a case, especially a cultivation case,'' Hanson said. ``We really do need the public's help.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Denies Paying for Favorable Radio Reports
DOC.TEXT: Two journalists alleged Monday that some radio reporters working free-lance for foreign stations accepted money or favors from the Foreign Ministry to do pro-Israel stories packaged as independent news items. The two, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the free-lancers worked out of a Jerusalem recording studio that has close ties with the ministry. The ministry denied the allegations in a statement released Monday, but said it suspended all ties with the studio lest ``some aspects of the current arrangements ... be misconstrued as involving a conflict of interest.'' The New York Times reported Monday that ministry officials secretly channeled money to the studio to pay the reporters' salaries. It also said Israeli diplomats abroad helped the free-lance reporters recruit radio clients in major locations. One Jerusalem-based radio reporter told The Associated Press the ministry paid the studio fee of $75 per hour for some free-lance reporters who otherwise would have to cover the expense themselves. In return, ``sometimes they (ministry officials) ask the reporters to publish certain information,'' the reporter said. Another broadcast journalist said some colleagues working for foreign stations accepted money from the ministry in exchange for stories favorable to Israel packaged as independent news reports. The ministry statement Monday declared, ``There are no journalists on the Foreign Ministry payroll.'' The ministry said it has worked with the studio for years, commissioning programs on current events and other subjects that are distributed by Israeli embassies abroad. It said the programs were ``distributed by us and in our name.'' The ministry claimed that it decided to suspend ties with the studio on July 18 _ 10 days before it was first asked by The New York Times about the relationship. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said the ministry was concerned that some journalists who worked for the studio were also ``independent journalists,'' meaning they free-lanced for clients abroad. But Avi Yaffe, owner of the studio, said the suspension was a result of the media inquiries. ``About 2{ weeks ago, they (ministry officials) said there are all kinds of journalists that are asking questions. We think we have a problem here,'' Yaffe told the AP in an interview at his studioon Herzl Boulevard in Jerusalem. ``They (ministry officials) said they don't want problems, they don't want to be linked to something like this.'' Yaffe said nearly half his business came from the Foreign Ministry, but denied allegations of a covert link. He said free-lance reporters use his studio to produce programs for foreign radio stations, including two major U.S. networks and outlets in Europe, South America, Africa and Asia. Yaffe said he had more than 10 free-lance reporters working in the studio. ``Most of the reporters are also working for other (media) organizations, and they are moonlighting here,'' he said. He refused to identify the reporters. Yaffe said that to simplify accounting procedures, foreign radio stations paid the studio in full for each broadcast prepared by a reporter. The station kept part of it for use of the facilities, and passed the rest on to the reporter, he said. The ministry and Yaffe acknowledged that the ministry held briefings for reporters using the studio. ``Sometimes, somebody from there (the Foreign Ministry) says if you want, we have such and such a guy who will talk to you about something,'' Yaffe said. He said it was left up to the reporters whether to attend. Connie Mus, chief of the Foreign Press Association and a reporter for the Christian Broadcast Network, said he was concerned over the reports. ``This undermines the position of every journalist working in this country,'' he said. ``Professional journalists should be independent. If they're paid by the Foreign Ministry, it discredits the entire press corps.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Case in Home Stretch
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 4 grafs to update, picks up 2nd graf pvs.,``The evidentiary ...''
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors and Mayor Marion Barry's attorneys finished presenting evidence Monday in the mayor's drug and perjury trial, and Barry pleaded with the city's black residents to avoid reacting violently if he is convicted. ``We have grown as a people in the last 20 years, and we are not going to destroy what we have brought back,'' Barry said after the court session ended. ``Those who talk about that don't represent me.'' Barry scoffed at conjecture that rioting could occur like that which happened in the nation's capital when the Rev. Martin Luther King was assassinated in 1968. ``Frankly, I really don't see (rioting) happening no matter what happens,'' Barry said. ``I want to say I have heard no serious consideration of anything like that.'' The evidentiary phase of the trial came to an unexpected early ending when Barry's lawyers abandoned an effort to call two witnesses they had hoped could weaken the government's case on one of the 10 cocaine-possession charges the mayor faces. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson then set closing arguments for Wednesday morning, providing an extra day to prepare them as Barry's lawyers had requested. On Friday, prosecutors introduced a document showing city worker Clifton Roberson was absent from his job at the time Roberson said he had accepted a job application from admitted crack cocaine dealer Lydia Pearson. Pearson had testified that she delivered the application, along with crack cocaine, to the mayor about 10 a.m. Sept. 7, 1988. Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy said Roberson was absent from his job later in the day but was there in the morning to get the application. Mundy said he had wanted to recall Roberson but decided against it Monday because the worker couldn't be ``dead certain'' about what happened on Sept. 7. At issue is whether Roberson was absent from 4:30 p.m. to 6:30 p.m., as the form originally indicated, or whether he was away from the office from 8:30 a.m. until 10:30 p.m. The latter time was listed in the margin above the original 4:30 p.m. entry, which had been scratched out. Mundy said Roberson could testify to being away from work late in the day, but couldn't be as certain about who had made the handwritten change. ``He doesn't think it is his handwriting, but he can't say for sure,'' Mundy said. ``He just can't recall that precisely.'' On Friday, prosecutors called a former clerk in Roberson's office who identified the handwriting on the form as that of the defense witness. The document is ``a brand-new piece of evidence'' that ``should not be admitted'' unless the defense is given a chance to dispute it, Mundy had originally argued. Jackson was considering Mundy's request, until the defense attorney informed the court that he would not be calling either Roberson or his mother. Mundy had said earlier he wanted to call Roberson's mother for verification. Roberson had scribbled on the city document that he was laying a stone for his father's grave. Assistant U.S. attorney Richard Roberts opened the day's proceedings by saying the government would not call any more rebuttal witnesses. Barry has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, three felony charges of lying to a federal grand jury and one count of conspiracy.

DOC.HEAD: Pennsylvania Abortion Law Contested In Federal Court
DOC.TEXT: The fight over the toughest state abortion law in the nation entered federal court Monday as a group of doctors and abortion clinics asked a judge to throw out key sections of the law. The case is being watched by activists on both sides of the abortion debate because of its potential to present a challenge to the landmark Roe vs. Wade decision that in 1973 established a woman's right to have an abortion. The class-action suit argues that abortion controls passed by the Pennsylvania Legislature in 1988 and 1989 unconstitutionally infringe on the rights of women to obtain abortions. Among the provisions in dispute are requirements that a woman notify her husband before obtaining an abortion and that she wait 24 hours between visiting a clinic and receiving an abortion. Other contested sections require that doctors provide counseling to women seeking abortions and that minors obtain the written consent of one parent or a court order to receive an abortion. The law has been temporarily blocked by a federal court order pending a ruling. Only Guam, a U.S. territory in the Pacific, has adopted more stringent controls. Its law also was temporarily blocked. Kathryn Kolbert, an American Civil Liberties Union attorney representing the plaintiffs, said the law allows the state to interject itself into the private affairs of women and their doctors, eroding privacy rights established under the Roe ruling. ``This act puts government in the operating room and at the kitchen table with women making decisions on abortion,'' she said. ``It questions the ability of women to make independent decisions,'' she added. One doctor testified that criminal penalties in the 1989 law might deter other physicians from performing abortions. The law, as revised last year, carries stiff penalties for doctors who violate its provisions. Dr. Thomas Allen of Women's Health Services of Pittsburgh, one of the clinics filing suit, said malpractice insurance typically covers civil but not criminal cases. ``They are a little more afraid'' of the prospect of criminal charges, Allen said. ``It may deter some of my colleagues from providing the service.'' On cross-examination by Senior Deputy Attorney General Kate L. Mershimer, Allen acknowledged a 24-hour waiting period might be necessary in some cases, but added: ``I don't think it should be mandated.'' In other testimony, Dr. Michael Alan Grodin of the Boston University school of medicine and public health expressed concern with parts of the law requiring ``informed consent.'' He said information should be provided to a patient on an individual basis and that the law's requirement intrudes on the doctor-patient relationship. This is the second time Senior U.S. District Judge Daniel H. Huyett III has been called upon to rule on the constitutionality of the Pennsylvania abortion law. Some sections of the law are similar to those ruled unconstitutional by the U.S. Supreme Court in a 1986 Pennsylvania case. That ruling came after Huyett upheld challenges to a 1982 abortion law. The state's 1988 law was largely an attempt to redraft many of the voided provisions. The 1989 law was passed after the Supreme Court, in a Missouri case, Webster vs. Reproductive Health Services, gave states greater leeway to restrict abortion. The law is being challenged by Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania; Women's Suburban Clinic; Women's Health Services; Reproductive Health and Counseling Center; Allentown Women's Center; and Allen, on behalf of state doctors who perform or make referrals on abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Children from Chernobyl to be Treated in Israel
DOC.TEXT: A religious movement on Monday announced plans to bring to Israel 3,000 Jewish children who were exposed to radiation during the nuclear accident at Chernobyl in the Soviet Union. ``For the first time since the beginning of Russian immigration, such a large group of children will come to Israel without their parents,'' the Chabad movement said in a statement. ``Chabad responded to appeals from the parents who have asked that their children be evacuated from the disaster area and given proper medical treatment,'' it said. The first group, which includes 196 children aged six to 15 from the Byelorussian cities of Gomel and Mozyr, will arrive Wednesday by chartered plane, the movement said. They will be accompanied by 35 adults, it said. A medical team will first examine the children at Jerusalem's Hadassah Hospital, the movement said. According to Chabad, five children in the group are known to be suffering from leukemia as a result of the April 1986 disaster at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor. ``The situation of the others is unclear because ever since the disaster, they have not been checked thoroughly and have not received any medical treatment,'' Chabad said. ``Following their arrival, they will undergo detailed medical tests and will be under constant observation so that any symptoms that may develop as a result of their exposure to radiation can be treated in time.'' Chabad said a special clinic would be created for the children at the movement's headquarters in Kfar Chabad. ``Chabad will not rest until all the 3,000 children who have been exposed to radiation are brought to Israel and receive proper medical treatment,'' the movement's chairman Rabbi Shlomo Maidanchik said. Chabad, an acronym for ``Wisdom, Understanding, Knowledge,'' is a movement of Lubavitcher Hasidim, followers of the New York-based Lubavitcher Rabbi. Lubavitcher officials claim a million followers worldwide. The movement is historically linked with the town of Lubavitch in Byelorussia, the Soviet republic that was declared an ecological disaster site following the Chernobyl accident.

DOC.HEAD: Sonar Maker Pleads Guilty in Civil Suit
DOC.TEXT: A manufacturer of sonar devices for nuclear submarines pleaded guilty to two felony charges Monday and agreed to pay $5.1 million to settle a civil suit alleging it overcharged the Pentagon for labor costs. Ametek Inc., pleaded guilty in federal court in San Diego, Calif., to two charges of making false statements to the government and was fined $110,000, the Justice Department said in a news release. The company admitted submitting false estimates of labor costs to the Pentagon, officials said. The company, based in Paoli, Pa., also agreed to pay $5.1 million to settle a lawsuit brought under the False Claims Act, the department said. The suit, originally filed by attorney Alan J. Ludecke, charged that Ametek had inflated labor costs for making two sonar systems for the Los Angeles-class attack submarines and Trident missile subs, the department said. Under the terms of the settlement, Ludecke will receive $765,000 or 15 percent of the $5.1 million payment. The False Claims Act allows whistleblowers to bring lawsuits on behalf of the government. The Justice Department decided to take over the case and conducted its own investigation of the allegations first brought to light by Ludecke. ``In an era of shrinking military expenditures, we will move to insure that the government gets what it pays for, said Stuart M. Gerson, assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's civil division.

DOC.HEAD: Angola Claims UNITA Killed 22 Civilians, Sabotaged Oil Lines
DOC.TEXT: UNITA rebels in Angola killed 22 civilians, blew up electric pylons and sabotaged 14 oil pipelines, undermining efforts to end the 15-year-old civil war there, news reports from Angola said Monday. Rebels confirmed sabotage attacks in the southern African nation, but David Horacio, UNITA spokesman in Lisbon, said civilians were never a target. The United States has backed UNITA, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, in its fight to force the Marxist government to share power. War has raged since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. The Angolan news agency ANGOP, in a dispatch monitored in Lisbon, quoted an unidentified military source as saying rebels killed 20 villagers, wounded two and burned seven houses in a raid Thursday in coastal Benguela province. Rebels killed two more civilians the same day, one from Namibia, in an ambush on two vehicles in southern Cunene province, bordering Namibia, ANGOP said. Angolan government sources, quoted by the Portuguese news agency LUSA, said UNITA blew up electric pylons 100 miles south of Luanda, leaving the capital without power for the second time in less than a month. The Angolan military said in a statement that rebel attacks on Angola's oil supply ``are intended to display a false military superiority but in no way contribute to the advent of peace; on the contrary, they lead to an escalation of the internal conflict,'' ANGOP reported. Oil production at Quinguila in Northwestern Soyo district bordering Zaire was down 30,000 barrels a day after UNITA destroyed 14 pipelines there, ANGOP said . Crude oil is Angola's main source of foreign currency. The country produced an average 455,000 barrels a day last year and stands to earn more than $2.5 billion from oil exports this year, according to Western studies. Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva of Portugal said recently the two sides may meet in August in Portugal to sign a cease-fire. A U.S. State Department official said during a visit to Angola this month that the the United States will continue to aid the rebels ``until such time as there is a process for national reconciliation under way.'' Washington is thought to channel about $50 million worth of military aid to UNITA, mostly via Zaire. Rebel and government delegations met in April and June in Portugal for peace talks, and both sides said later they were ready to sign a truce. A June 22, 1989, cease-fire brokered by President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire collapsed within days.

DOC.HEAD: Mixed Verdict for Former Bodyguard in Drug Agent's Killing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: EDITS throughout to UPDATE with potential sentence, sentencing date set, no reaction from Bernabe, background; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A former bodyguard for drug traffickers was convicted Monday of kidnapping and other charges in the kidnap-slaying of a U.S. drug agent in Mexico, but was acquitted of murder. A U.S. District Court jury found Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez guilty of kidnapping and racketeering in the 1985 torture killing of Drug Enforcement Administration Agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena. The jury also convicted Bernabe, 31, of aiding the escape of Rafael Caro Quintero, a drug lord whose Guadalajara, Mexico, home was where Camarena was tortured and slain. The government alleges that Caro was among those who interrogated and killed Camarena in revenge for the agent's raids on rich marijuana and cocaine plantations. According to testimony, Mexican law enforcement officers also aided Caro's dramatic escape from Guadalajara Airport. Caro was recaptured, then convicted in Mexico and is one of 20 people serving sentences there in the complex case. In addition to the specific charge of murdering Camarena, Bernabe was acquitted of conspiracy to kidnap the agent and of racketeering in the kidnap and murder of Camarena's pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Bernabe faces up to life in prison for kidnapping and racketeering and 10 years for the other conviction. The former Mexican policeman showed no reaction as he stood with his lawyers listening to the verdicts on simultaneous-translation earphones.
