After the verdicts, the jury resumed deliberations on charges against the two remaining defendants. The jury on Thursday convicted Honduran drug kingpin Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros of the Camarena kidnapping, but cleared him of a murder charge. Matta's attorney said the jury was confused. Bernabe, who was arrested a year ago and was the only defendant to testify during the trial, admitted he was a bodyguard for drug traffickers, but denied any role in Camarena's kidnapping and murder or Zavala's killing. Camarena's slaying by Guadalajara's powerful drug cartel incensed U.S. drug enforcement officials and strained relations between the United States and Mexico. The DEA has vowed to capture every person involved in the slaying. So far, 22 people have been charged in this country and more than 20 convicted in Mexico. The trial is the second prosecution in the case. In Los Angeles in 1988, a drug trafficker and a former Mexican policeman were convicted in federal court of multiple charges, including murder, in the Camarena case and another drug trafficker was found guilty of aiding and abetting the murders. Camarena, 31, was kidnapped off a Guadalajara street. According to testimony at both trials, he was taken to Caro's house, where he was tortured and interrogated before being slain along with his pilot. Their bodies were found a month later on a ranch 65 miles from Gaudalajara. The murders were said to be in retribution for DEA drug seizures which cost the drug barons $5 billion in profits. Judge Edward Rafeedie set Bernabe's sentencing for Sept. 24, and ordered lawyers to refrain from comment on the case until all verdicts have been returned. The two remaining defendants are Ruben Zuno Arce, a Guadalajara businessman and brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria accused of taking part in Camarena's kidnapping, and Javier Vasquez Velasco, a former bodyguard accused of slaying two American tourists in an apparent mistake killing. Neither is accused of murder.

DOC.HEAD: 100s of Civilians Massacred in Liberia; Gov't Denies Responsibility
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with State Department saying death toll believed in 200 range, details. Picks up 4th pvs, `People who...' with minor editing thereafter to trim
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based partly on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith and photographer Alistair Sinclair were among them.

Loyalist soldiers of President Samuel Doe burst into a Lutheran church compound Monday and massacred at least 600 civilian refugees, including many children, witnesses said. However, State Department officials in Washington said late Monday that their information, based on reports from U.S. Embassy staff still in Monrovia, indicates about 200 had been killed by Liberian troops. In either case, a spokesman for Doe denied the allegations. In a telephone call to the British Broadcasting Corp. in London, the spokesman said rebels wearing government uniforms killed the civilians in the early morning raid. Witnesses said most victims were children and women, some with babies strapped to their backs and others cowering in corners. They had been seeking refuge from the civil war, which began in late December when rebels invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast in a bid to oust Doe. The rebels accuse Doe, in power since 1980, of rights abuses and corruption. People who said they escaped the attack alleged about 30 soldiers blasted the church door down with machines guns. They then opened fire on about 2,000 people from the Gio and Mano tribes who had taken refuge there. Government troops have killed hundreds of Gios and Manos, whose tribes have supported the rebels seeking to overthrow Doe and speak a different language than Doe's loyalists. Most of Doe's troops are from his Krahn tribe and the Mandingo tribe. Earlier Monday, White House deputy press secretary Stephen Hart said U.S. Embassy officials had confirmed government troops slaughtered at least 200 people at the church compound in Monrovia. There was no independent confirmation of the 600 dead figure. The White House condemned the massacre as a ``senseless act of terror'' but had no plans to send in troops. ``At this point we don't believe that would be a prudent course of action,'' Hart said. Witnesses said soldiers broke into the church compound at about 2 a.m. when the refugees were asleep. There was no telephone, so victims had no way of calling for help. Bodies of some people apparently killed while trying to flee were hanging from window frames of the church building, said one person who visited the camp. ``I saw dead bodies all around,'' the source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Other witnesses who refused to give their names said they saw women with their heads smashed open or blown to pieces by bullets. Thousands of refugees fleeing the civil war are crowded into refugee camps in the capital. Their numbers have swelled recently as rebel troops have stormed the city. The survivors said that after the soldiers had riddled the refugees on the ground floor with bullets they went upstairs and attacked a second group, of 1,000, sleeping there. ``We thought they had come to ask us questions. Then they started killing, and everyone began screaming and trying to hide,'' said one man who claimed he hid on the roof of the church. The soldiers were from Doe's Krahn tribe, said the survivors. The floor of the church was covered with blood stains Monday. Bodies were huddled under the pews where people tried to hide and lay draped across the church altar. More bodies were huddled in the corner. The bodies of women were strewn on the floor with children still wrapped in shawls on their backs. The ceiling was riddled with bullet holes. ``My people, help me. My son, where is my son? I beg you. Don't leave me,'' pleaded an injured woman on the church steps. A man nearby, his neck slashed, called out for water. The compound was filled with the bodies brought outside after the massacre. People passing the church appeared numb at the sight of rows of corpses. People who survived the attack were seen Monday afternoon being rounded up by government soldiers. The soldiers ordered survivors away from the building and shot into the air to make them move, said the witnesses. Refugees had sought protection at the church in late May after government soldiers attacked them at U.N. headquarters in Monrovia. The soldiers killed an unarmed security guard and abducted about 30 civilian men. Many of their bodies were later discovered outside the capital. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar withdrew all U.N. staff from Liberia in protest, halting an emergency program to aid war refugees. Perez de Cuellar said in New York that he reacted ``with horror and dismay'' to Monday's massacre. The war has grown to include tribal warfare, with both the government and rebels accusing the other of civilian slayings. The government of neighboring Guinea has accused fighters of rebel leader Charles Taylor of crossing into its territory and slaughtering Krahns and Mandingos. Meanwhile, Taylor's men are engaged in battles with followers of a rival rebel leader, Prince Johnson. Johnson split with Taylor months ago, and his fighters last week advanced to within a mile of the presidential mansion. Taylor has offered to pardon Johnson if he joined in the struggle to topple Doe. Johnson indicated Monday he had no intention of working with Taylor. In a meeting with foreign correspondents in Monrovia, he accused Taylor of being a Libyan-backed socialist and said he received $8 million in aid from Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. ``He is not going to come here now and make himself president. I will meet Taylor after Doe is overthrown. I don't want power, I want a fair election. Taylor will manipulate the election,'' Johnson said. Johnson, a former lieutenant in Doe's army, said: ``I will get Doe. He is not going to get away.'' He claimed to have 7,000 men under his command, including 4,000 deserters from Doe's army. Taylor claims to have at least 5,000 fighters. He has denied receiving aid from Libya. Taylor named his own interim government, with himself as the head, last week. Doe, who has repeatedly said he will die before leaving Monrovia, remained holed up in his heavily fortified presidential mansion.

DOC.HEAD: French Prisoners Protest Pardons for Pro-Iranian Hit Squad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to UPDATE with police using tear gas to break up roof protest, one inmate injured. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `Similar protests...'
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of inmates at prisons across France refused to return to their cells Monday in a new wave of protests against presidential pardons for five members of a pro-Iranian assassination team. The largest protest was at the Strasbourg-Elsau prison outside the eastern city of Strasbourg, where about 200 of the 640 inmates refused to return to their cells after an afternoon walk. About 40 protesters climbed atop a roof and refused to come down until riot police fired tear gas grenades to end the three-hour rebellion. One inmate suffered unspecified injuries when he fell from the roof, police said. Similar protests began late in the day in at least six other prisons from Marseille on the south coast to Lille in the far-north. They followed a series of protests over the weekend by inmates angered over President Francois Mitterrand's Friday pardon of Anis Naccache and his four accomplices. Five prison officials were slightly injured in the weekend protests. Naccache had served 10 years of a life sentence for the failed assassination of Shahpour Bakhtiar, Iran's prime minister prior to the 1979 Islamic revolution. A policeman and a passer-by were killed and another policeman paralyzed in the 1980 assassination attempt in Paris. Naccache was allegedly acting on Iranian orders and his imprisonment has been a major object of contention between France and Iran. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said in an interview Saturday that he hoped the release could help bring about the freeing of all Western hostages held in Lebanon. Three unions representing prison guards issued statements partially blaming the government for the protests. One of them, the General Union of Prison Syndicates, said the pardons ``confirm once again that all men in France are not equal before the law.'' At the Ormingen prison in eastern France, scores of prisoners ended an 18-hour mutiny Monday in which they hurled roofing tiles at riot police, and set fire to the kitchen, gymnasium and prison shop. Many were armed with iron bars or hand tools. The riot police did not intervene, and the inmates gave up at midday Monday following hours of negotiations with prison officials. No promises were made to the prisoners, officials said. They could not immediately provide an estimate of the damages caused to the facility. There were also protests at Caen, where the five prison employees were slightly injured Saturday. The inmates there, demanding pardons of their own, had chanted, ``Us, too. Us, too.'' The Paris newspaper Le Monde reported Monday that Iran may also be seeking the release of two other men serving life prison terms in France: Georges Ibrahim Abdallah, a Lebanese convicted in 1987 of complicity in the assassinations of diplomats from the United States and Israel, and Varoujan Garbidjian, an Armenian convicted of a 1983 bombing at Orly airport which killed eight people.

DOC.HEAD: Zsa Zsa Gabor Gets Out of Jail
LaserPhoto LA9
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor on Monday left the media-besieged jail where she chose to spend her 72-hour sentence for slapping a Beverly Hills police officer, virtually ending her publicity-mad misdemeanor case. Surrounded by about 100 reporters and onlookers and at least one heckler who told her to go back to Hungary, Miss Gabor, 72, said she spent her jail time doing secretarial work that was slightly hampered by her ignorance of the alphabet. ``I had to file, but I don't know the ABCs, so they wrote out the ABCDE for me,'' she said outside the jail. ``I did very well.'' Miss Gabor said that on returning to her Bel-Air home, ``I want to take a hot bath and talk to my dogs and my horses.'' Retired custodian Fred DeGrazio, 72, of Hawthorne documented the release with a video camera and running commentary. ``I have nothing else to do,'' he explained. ``She should go back to Hungary and be the aristocrat she thinks she is,'' he said shortly before Miss Gabor's release. ``Why don't you jump in a coffin?'' snapped her husband, Frederick Von Anhalt, who says he's a prince. Von Anhalt, Miss Gabor's eighth husband, said the previous 72 hours had been tough on him. ``My weekend was terrible. My wife, she wasn't home,'' he complained. On Friday, Miss Gabor began her 72-hour sentence for slapping a policeman during a traffic stop last year. She paid $85 a day to do her time at the El Segundo jail rather than have the county pick accommodations for her. ``I was very happily surprised,'' she said of her stay in the Los Angeles suburb known for its refineries and aerospace offices and factories. ``Everybody was warm and nice and sweet. It was OK. The Beverly Hills Police should come and take lessons from this police.'' But there was that moment of terror. ``At first I was petrified,'' she said. ``They even took my makeup away.'' She also scolded reporters for a weekend story that her husband delivered silk sheets to the jail. ``I didn't have silk sheets. I don't even have silk sheets at home. I was on a horse blanket,'' she said. She also declared the food to be ``terrible.'' Among other accomplishments during the 72 hours, Miss Gabor claimed she finished writing her autobiography, ``One Lifetime is Not Enough.'' One jail stay was enough for the El Segundo Police. ``This is so time-consuming,'' Lt. L. Lunsford said Sunday, after handling about 60 telephone calls from people with inquiring minds. Municipal Judge Charles Rubin ordered the jail sentence last May after ruling Miss Gabor had violated probation by failing to perform 120 hours of community service at a shelter for homeless women. He increased the community-service time to 145{ hours. Along with her jail time and community service, Rubin ordered Miss Gabor to pay nearly $13,000 in fines and restitution. Miss Gabor's attorney, Harrison Bull of Santa Barbara, said finishing the jail sentence completes the sometime actress' debt to society. ``I filed notice of completion last week. I am going to say she completed more than 200 hours of community service,'' considerably more than she was asked to do, said Bull. Of the $13,000 in fines, $10,000 has been paid and the rest will be paid this week, he said. ``This is probably the biggest sentence ever served by anyone for such a minor incident in the history of United States jurisprudence,'' Bull said with the understatement that has marked the case.

DOC.HEAD: Nautical Tribute Kicks Off Queen Mother Birthday Festivities
DOC.TEXT: A nautical tribute by 2,000 yachts on Monday kicked off six days of festivities celebrating the 90th birthday of Britain's favorite grandmother, the Queen Mother. From the deck of the Royal Yacht Britannia, Queen Elizabeth reviewed yachts passing in the waters separating the mainland from the Isle of Wight. Among the boats was a ketch representing the New York Yacht Club. Crews cheered and doffed their caps on boats decked out in brilliant flags and pennants, a splash of color against the misty evening sky. The Queen Mother, consistently listed in opinion polls as the public's favorite member of the royal family, arrived at Portsmouth to a 21-gun salute as she went on board the Britannia. Since Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon married into the royal family on April 23, 1923, she has captivated her subjects with her joie de vivre, breathtaking energy and indelible charm. She comforted England during the darkest days of World War II and inspired courage by refusing to leave King George V in England for safe haven with their daughters, Elizabeth and Margaret. Many people say the highlight of this week's celebrations will be the Queen Mother's visit Wednesday to the East End, the neighborhoods hardest hit by German bombs during the blitz. On Wednesday night, the Queen Mother will return to the Britannia to watch a firework display over the Thames River and attend a birthday dinner given by her daughter, Queen Elizabeth II. There are no official engagements Thursday, although Prince Charles has arranged a special concert for his grandmother at Buckingham Palace. After a quiet day Friday, the Queen Mother is expected to celebrate her Aug. 4 birthday at her London home, Clarence House. However, as in recent years, the Queen Mother can expect to see a good-humored crowd outside her home from the crack of dawn, bursting into choruses of ``Happy Birthday'' and eager to give her flowers and presents. She usually appears to accept gifts from children in the crowd.

DOC.HEAD: Foresters Call For Radically Broader View of Research, More Money
DOC.TEXT: The world's largest collection of forestry scientists called Monday for radical changes in forest research, pleading for more money, more graduate students and a broader view of the globe's ecosystem. The Society of American Foresters embraced proposed changes of a new report by the National Research Council, an affiliate of the National Academy of Science. ``By and large, the current extent and direction of forestry research is insufficient to answer today's pressing problems or those of the future,'' said Arthur Smyth, president of the society and its nearly 20,000 members. ``We are facing serious environmental questions about global warming and biodiversity. Yet, we find our country's commitment to forestry research is eroding, just when we most need to understand and look for solutions to these pressing concerns,'' he said. The report presented at the society's annual convention in Washington concludes that current forestry research is ``inadequate to meet society's needs.'' Support for research, physical facilities and research equipment is lagging and ``because funding has not kept pace with changing technology, the technology used in forestry research and teaching is rarely up to date.'' ``The number of scientists and amount of resources devoted to forestry research have declined significantly and are continuing to decline, even as needs increase,'' the study said. The report recommends the Forest Service's research budget be increased by 10 percent annually over the next five years, from the 1988 level of $135 million to a total of $218 million. It also suggests the Agriculture Department make available $100 million annually in competitive grants for research. Jerry Sesco, deputy chief of research for the Agriculture Department's Forest Service, said forest research has been conducted by scientists with specific expertise in such areas as water, timber and wildlife. ``We need more at the interdisciplinary, ecosystem level. It goes back to the first Earth Day when we said everything is related to everything else. We are finding that is true more and more,'' he said. ``Basically, we don't know very much about how ecosystems operate. We need to understand better how people and natural resources integrate,'' Sesco said. The committee that prepared information for the report was chaired by John C. Gordon of Yale University. Other members included William Atkinson of Oregon State University, Jerry Franklin and David Thorud of the University of Washington and James Sedell of the Forest Service in Corvallis, Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Rain, Rain Everywhere
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms stretched across much of the nation Monday, causing flooding in Texas and threatening more high water. Flooding continued in northeastern Iowa. In western Texas, the town of Alpine received 2 inches of rain between 4 a.m. and noon, flooding low-water crossings and railroad tracks to the west. A flood watch was posted for the mountains of western Texas between the Guadalupe Mountains and Big Bend. Summer rains caused major flooding over the weekend in the northeastern Iowa town of Finchford on the west fork of the Cedar River. The Red Cross set up an emergency shelter at junior high school in nearby Cedar Falls, but no one had shown up by Monday afternoon. The flood's crest was expected to reach Waterloo, about 10 miles downstream from Finchford, on Monday, and Cedar Rapids, about 50 miles from Finchford, on Thursday. But the National Weather Service predicted flooding downstream would be less serious. Showers and thunderstorms fell Monday in sections of Texas, New Mexico, Colorado, Oklahoma, Kansas, Nebraska, Oregon, Lower Michigan, Ohio, Kentucky, Illinois, Alabama, Georgia and northwest Florida. Scattered showers and storms fell over east-central and southern Florida, Louisiana, North Carolina, Virginia and Maine. The mercury dropped to 41 degrees in Alamosa, Colo., breaking the city's low-temperature record for the date of 42 degrees in 1979 and 1986. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 58 degrees in Arcata, Calif., to 108 in Needles, Calif. The low for the nation was 38 degrees in Yellowstone National Park, Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Police Continue Search For Owner of Cambridge Weapons Cache
DOC.TEXT: The owner of a huge arsenal remaind at large Monday after police siezed more than 500 guns and an antitank gun from his duplex. An arrest warrant was issued for Henry Stram, 50, said police Lt. Richard Bongiorno. The arrest warrant alleges illegal possession of a machine gun, two counts of possession of infernal machines and possession of explosive fireworks. ``We believe he's on Cape Cod,'' Bongiorno said, adding that police were cooperating with authorities there. Two weekend raids at Stram's home in a residential section of Cambridge yielded more than 200 handguns, 300 rifles, an antitank gun, antique guns, mortar shells and ``thousands and thousands of rounds of ammunition,'' said Lt. Donald Carney. Police said the firepower in the home was enough to outgun the department. Stram is licensed to carry firearms and was known to neighbors as a gun collector and a member of the National Guard. Police seized his entire collection, citing public safety concerns. ``That amount of guns, it's unheard of,'' said Carney. ``Especially in a house in the middle of the city. If anyone broke in and took the guns ... it would wreak havoc on the streets.'' Police went to the house because of a reported break-in. The report proved wrong. The weapons were estimated to be worth about $150,000, Bongiorno said. Since 1960, Stram, a lifelong Cambridge resident, has been a member of the 102nd Fighter Interceptor Wing of the Massachusetts Air National Guard at Otis Air Force Base on Cape Cod, according to Doug Karson, an Otis spokesman.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine Man Reputed to be 124 Years Old Dies
DOC.TEXT: Armando Frid, a horse tamer and cattle driver in the early stages of a life said to have spanned 124 years, has died, the government news agency Telam said Monday. Telam put Frid's date of birth as May 24, 1866, in Vega de Maipu, in the western province of Neuquen. The 1989 Guinness Book of World Records lists the greatest authenticated age of any human as 120 years, 237 days. Shigechiyo Izumi of Japan died at that age in 1986. Hector Colla, the agency's correspondent in Viedma, near the rural town in Rio Negro province where Frid died, said he knew Frid and examined birth documents that government officials confirmed as genuine. Colla spoke in a telephone interview with The Associated Press. An editor at the newspaper Rio Negro also told The AP by telephone that Frid attained 124 years of age two months ago, according to checks the paper made in the past about a resident who was considered a celebrity. Colla said Frid died last Saturday at his home in Carmen de Patagones, about 600 miles south of Buenos Aires and 2{ miles outside Viedma. Townspeople gave Frid a party on his 110th birthday because they figured he wouldn't have many more, Colla said. But Frid told them, ``eating grilled beef and drinking mate, I'll keep on living.'' Mate is a bitter tea, served hot or cold, that is a popular drink in Argentina. Beef cooked over an open flame is the national dish, in plentiful supply even to the poor. Among many jobs, Frid hunted foxes and pumas, raised horses and worked as an oil hand in Patagonia. His last job was as a baker in Buenos Aires, Telam said.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Kills Conservative Lawmaker, a Thatcher Confidante
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of explosion and investigation, Thatcher comment, minor editing. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON3,5,9,12,16
DOC.TEXT: A bomb hidden under a car exploded Monday, killing a Conservative Party lawmaker and confidante of the prime minister who was on an Irish Republican Army assassination list, police said. Ian Gow, chairman of the Northern Ireland committee in the House of Commons, died of injuries minutes after turning the ignition key in his car outside his house, authorities said. Scotland Yard's chief anti-terrorist officer, George Churchill-Coleman, said the attack appeared to be the work of the IRA. No one else was injured, and no one immediately claimed responsibility. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher viewed the car, with its roof on the driver's side peeled back and all the glass blown out. ``I could talk to him like nobody else,'' she said of Gow after visiting his wife. Gow, 53, had been warned he was on a list of 100 lawmakers, judges and civil servants found in an IRA bomb factory in south London in December 1988, Churchill-Coleman said. Friends and neighbors in Hankham, on England's southeast coast, said Gow took few precautions. ``It would be easy for terrorists to get him,'' said Jane Birch, a neighbor. It appeared that a device packing about five pounds of explosives was placed under the driver's seat, set to go off when the ignition was turned on, Churchill-Coleman said. ``My impression is that it was some sort of tilt switch. Once you turn it on, it explodes immediately,'' he said. Gow was Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's parliamentary private secretary from 1979 to 1983. He was also a close family friend and political ally to whom she turned for advice in moments of difficulty. Gow resigned from her government in 1985 to protest the Anglo-Irish Agreement which guaranteed Ireland a say in the province's affairs. He saw the accord as undermining British authority in Northern Ireland. Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey and Britain's Roman Catholic Cardinal Basil Hume joined politicians in condemning the attack, the fourth slaying of a British lawmaker since sectarian violence broke out in Northern Ireland in 1969. The IRA has claimed responsiblity for a series of bombings in England, including one on May 16 that killed Sgt. Charles Chapman at a British army recruiting office. Other recent targets have included London's Stock Exchange, the Carlton Club, a traditional Conservative Party watering hole, the Stock exchange and a Royal Air Force base in northwest London. In Washington, the State Department condemned the killing and offered condolences to Gow's family. Gow's killers were ``plain, common murderers,'' Mrs. Thatcher said after spending nearly an hour with Gow's wife, Jane, at the couple's home near Eastbourne, 60 miles southeast of London. Mrs. Thatcher went to a special private service for Gow. She said the Gows and their two sons spent some Christmases with the Thatchers and that the families were close. The prime minister, who narrowly escaped an IRA bombing that killed five at a hotel in Brighton during a Conservative Party meeting in October 1984, said public officials should take all precautions suggested by Scotland Yard. ``Most (members of parliament) want to lead an open life, but I must renew the plea in view of what happened here in a quiet village _ everyone must have regard for their own stafety and the safety of their staff and family,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. Police scoured the area trying to discover whether the bombers stayed in the locale before the attack. Nearly a dozen bouquets of flowers were placed near the gate to the drive. The large brick house stands behind a high wall across the street from a primary school, closed for summer vacation. ``I think if Ian had been here he would have been the first to say, as he did on countless other occasions when such atrocities occurred, we should not give in to intimidation,'' said Conservative lawmaker Charles Wardle. ``It is vitally important that nothing should change people's minds _ no atrocity, no murder, no bullying.'' Neil Kinnock, leader of the opposition Labor Party, called the slaying ``a terrible atrocity against a man whose only offense was to speak his mind.'' Last Tuesday, after an IRA bomb killed three police officers and a nun in Northern Ireland, Gow expressed his anger at IRA tactics. ``These murders are as odious as they are futile,'' he said. ``Once again, wives have been turned into widows and children into orphans, and for what purpose?'' In a June 28 issue of Republican News, the weekly newspaper of the IRA, a leader said the group was determined ``to hit the enemy on as many fronts as possible and to stretch their resources and nerves.'' ``England is the `belly of the beast' and that is where it hurts most,'' the unidentified IRA leader said.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Dutch Oldsters Die of Salmonella Poisoning
DOC.TEXT: Seven residents of an old people's home died and 10 others were hospitalized after eating a salmonella-infected pudding containing raw eggs, Dutch TV reported Monday. It said 15 other residents at the Maria Auxiliatrix home for the elderly suffered minor symptoms after eating the desert last Tuesday. The house had 265 residents. Salmonella are bacteria that can develop in some foodstuffs or under unhygienic conditions and cause severe food poisoning. The Health Ministry last year warned against giving raw eggs to the elderly because of the risk of samonella poisoning. The TV report quoted Harry Speentjes, director of the Martinushof home, which is affiliated with Maria Auxiliatrix, as saying raw eggs were not supposed to be used in any food served at the institution because of the warning. The first fatality occured Thursday, but the case was not made public until Monday, when the cause of the deaths was established, the report said. Speentjes was also quoted as saying that all the victims were over 80 and all were suffering from terminal illnesses.

DOC.HEAD: Houe Committee Votes to Zero-Out Stealth Bomber
DOC.TEXT: A House Armed Services subcommittee voted Monday to eliminate all $3.8 billion in procurement money President Bush had sought for the B-2 bomber, lawmakers said. The panel on procurement and military nuclear systems adopted the proposal of its chairman, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., to stop buying the stealth aircraft after the 15 planes currently under development are delivered to the Air Force. The Armed Services' subcommittee on research and development meets Tuesday to take up the president's requets for money for B-2 testing. The full committee meets later in the day to put the finishing touches on its $283 billion defense bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. In other action behind closed doors, the panel eliminated the $1.3 billion the Pentagon sought for the program to move the MX nuclear missile from fixed silos to railroad cars and zeroed out the $1.3 billion for the AMRAAM anti-aircraft missile. Rejecting Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's attempts to kill the V-22 Osprey, the House panel added $165 million for advance procurement of the tilt-rotor assault transport that takes off like a helicopter but can fly like a plane. The panel also restricted the purchase of the C-17 transport aircraft, requiring Cheney to certify that the plane's first successful flight has been demonstrated before some $350 million can be spent on the two planes sought in the new fiscal year. The administration had proposed spending $2.1 billion on the C-17, a hevay transport designed to land on fields that the gigantic C-5 models cannot use. The panel slashed $1.2 billion from the classified A-12 Navy attack aircraft program. The subcommittee's action on the B-2 reflected the eroding congressional support for the aircraft, which is manufactured by the Northrop Corp. Lawmakers have expressed sticker shock over the cost of a single plane _ nearly $865 million. The B-2 still has substantial support in the Senate. A serious blow to the program came last week when Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services panel, came out for winding up the program despite attempts by the administration to make the project more appealing to lawmakers. Cheney revised his plan for the aircraft in April, cutting the total number of planes to be bought from 132 to 75 and reducing the buy in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 from five to two. In the closed session, the panel by voice vote rejected an amendment by Rep. Ike Skelton, D-Mo., to include $200 million for future procurement of the stealth bomber. Instead, the subcommittee followed Aspin's lead and zeroed out $3.8 billion for procurement of the two planes.

DOC.HEAD: Bertha as `Minimal' Hurricane Moves Northeast Through Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: Forecasters said minimal hurricane Bertha could reach the Canadian provinces by Wednesday but was mainly of concern to marine interests. Bertha, which was downgraded Sunday night to a tropical storm after it temporarily weakened, regained enough strength to push it just over the hurricane threshold of 74 mph. At 6 p.m. EDT Monday, Bertha was centered near 36 degrees 5 minutes north latitude and 67 degrees 4 minutes west longitude. That is 600 miles south-southwest of Halifax, Nova Scotia, said forecasters at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. It had top sustained winds of 75 mph and was moving northeast at 14 mph. Bertha was expected to stay at the same strength, course and speed through early Tuesday, said forecaster Miles Lawrence. Earlier, Bertha kicked up surf along Carolina beaches and sent gusts up to about 45 mph toward Bermuda. But forecasters said that because it was already edging northeast toward the open Atlantic when it was born, it was never much of a threat. The first hurricane of the 1990 Atlantic season could reach the Canadian provinces of Nova Scotia and Newfoundland by Wednesday or Thursday, forecasters said.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroys Naples' New Courthouse
DOC.TEXT: Fire devastated Naples' new courthouse Monday, turning the 32-story building into a glass inferno. One firefighter was slightly injured. The fire was discovered on the 7th floor of the 360-foot tower, the tallest in a three-building complex that was to have been completed the end of this year. Construction of the building began in 1979. The cause of the fire, which resulted in an estimated $1 billion worth of damage, is under investigation. ``So far, nothing has emerged that points to arson,'' said Enzo Mauro, a deputy at the district police station. The construction company, however, excluded the possibility that the origin of the fire was electrical. Firefighters were hindered in their efforts to extinguish the rapidly-spreading fire because of the heavy shower of debris that rained down as sections of the iron-and-glass tower collapsed. An automatic fire-extinguishing system had been designed for the building, but was not yet functional. Officials had hoped the opening of the new judicial complex would help alleviate a huge backlog of criminal cases, many involving the Neapolitan Mafia.

DOC.HEAD: GM Rolls ``Job One'' Saturn Off The Line With No Outside Spectators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf to CLARIFY Saturn is priced to compete with Corolla and Civic. A longer version moved on the business wire.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NS2
DOC.TEXT: A red, four-door Saturn sedan piloted by retiring General Motors Chairman Roger Smith rolled off the assembly line Monday, ceremonially but secretly kicking off production of the ground-breaking car. GM said that Smith, who retires Tuesday after 9{ years as GM's chairman, drove and United Auto Workers union President Owen Bieber rode shotgun when the ``Job One'' of the new GM model came off the line. Smith had promised he would drive ``Job One'' off Saturn's assembly line before he retired. But after seven years of media hype since the project was announced, the ceremony was closed to the news media. A photographer at Monday's ceremony was barred from taking pictures of the entire vehicle, reporters wre kept outside the plant gates and departing employees refused to answer questions. The company has yet to officially release a picture of the car but so-called ``spy photos'' have been published. In contrast, when Nissan began making light trucks in 1983 in Smyrna, 25 miles to the northeast, its ``Job One'' ceremony was a carefully produced affair with speeches, a film of the plant's history and open access for the news media. Richard G. ``Skip'' LeFauve, GM Saturn's president, said in a news release that Saturn's ceremony was private because of GM's plans to focus national attention on the car's launch this fall. He said it also provided a chance for team members to talk with Smith. ``Without Roger, there wouldn't be a Saturn,'' he said. The Saturn project was envisioned as a way of using non-traditional production and management techniques to make cars that would compete with imports that steadily have eaten away GM's U.S. market share. Smith introduced the project in 1983 saying the company planned to annually make 500,000 subcompact cars, costing about $6,000 each and getting mileage of 60 miles per gallon. The final product actually has more interior room, a longer wheel base and more features. It now is aimed to compete with the Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla, with a $10,000 to $12,000 price tag and a smaller 35-mpg rating. Production estimates have been halved. Smith's promise to drive ``Job One'' off the assembly line before he retired also was modified. When pressed recently if he would be able to keep his promise, Smith and Saturn officials said he would drive the car only if it was ready for production. ``Production is coming on line, retail facilities are under construction, and we can't wait to get to the marketplace this fall,'' said LeFauve. Behind Smith and Bieber was incoming GM Chairman Robert Stempel in the ``Job Two'' Saturn. Saturn officials said they will not begin shipping cars until the fall, shortly before they go on sale in October.

DOC.HEAD: President Barco to Become Colombian Ambassador to Britain
DOC.TEXT: President Virgilio Barco, who completes his term in office next week, will become Colombia's next ambassador to Britain, according to a radio report Monday. The Caracol radio network, citing ``reliable sources,'' said Barco will become Colombia's next ambassador in London when President-elect Cesar Gaviria takes office Aug. 7. Neither the presidential palace nor Gaviria's office would confirm the report. Outgoing presidents and cabinet ministers have in the past been given diplomatic posts abroad, often to give them more security. Members of the Barco administration have been under continual threat from Colombia's violent drug traffickers. Those threats intensified last August when drug lords declared war on the Colombian establishment.

DOC.HEAD: Panel: Honecker Unfit to be Held but Fit to be Tried
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's deposed Communist leader Erich Honecker is too sick to be held in jail but is fit enough to be tried, the official news agency ADN reported Monday. ADN, quoting a Health Ministry statement, said Honecker was still recovering from surgery for kidney cancer in January and was not well enough to be incarcerated. But a medical exam by a team of doctors found him in condition to be questioned and to stand trial, ADN said. Honecker, 77, ruled East Germany for 19 years until he was ousted in October as a wave of pro-democracy demonstrations swept the country, leading to the peaceful overthrow of the Communist government and the opening of the Berlin Wall. The medical panel concluded that seven other former Communist officials, who had been among Honecker's closest aides, were all fit to prosecute and to be placed in custody, ADN said. It said former secret police chief Erich Mielke, former economics czar Guenter Mittag and former labor chief Harry Tisch were under arrest, while the other four remained free. All three had been members of the ruling Politburo under Honecker. Mielke was arrested on Thursday. Honecker and the seven are charged with corruption and abuse of office. They had been arrested soon after Honecker's fall but were later released because of advanced age and poor health. Honecker has been staying at a Soviet military hospital outside East Berlin. ADN quoted Federal Prosecutor Guenter Seidel as saying he intended to continue his investigation against the former East German leaders, although their poor health often disrupted the proceedings.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Wants Taxpayer Checkoff to Finance TV Campaign Ads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES vote on GOP amendment; edits throughout to tighten; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Monday voted to use $20 million in public money for Senate candidates' TV commercials, drawing on the presidential campaign fund supported by the $1 checkoff on individual income tax returns. Republicans called the proposal a ``food stamp voucher for politicians'' that would open the door to taxpayer financing to pay most of the cost of congressional campaigns as it does now with presidential elections. ``Underneath the hood, it's the same old lemon running on taxpayer financing and spending limits,'' said Kentucky Sen. Mitch McConnell, the leading Republican opponent to the Democratic bill. By a 49-46 vote, the Senate rejected a Republican amendment that would delete from a campaign finance reform bill a measure to give Senate nominees $180,000 to $1.1 million each in government vouchers to buy broadcasting time for abiding by voluntary spending ceilings demanded by Democrats. All 44 Republicans present voted for the amendment by McConnell. Democrats Howell Heflin of Alabama and James Exxon of Nebraska also bolted from their party to support it. Beginning debate on campaign finance reform that both parties claim to want to address a growing public cynicism about politics in the wake of the savings and loan scandal, Democrats and Republicans remained at logger heads over the idea of spending ceilings. Majority Democrats, as they have for years, continued to insist on state-by-state limits on how much candidates can raise and spend to win or keep Senate seats. ``Anything short of that only creates the appearance of reform,'' said Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine. ``That's the central issue dividing the two parties.'' Republicans last week offered to accept ``flexible ceilings'' exempting in-state contributions and gifts from out-of-state donors less than $200 but Democrats rejected anything less than an absolute aggregate ceiling. Republicans contended Monday any bill limiting spending would stifle challengers and allow Democrats to maintain control of both houses of Congress. ``Everybody knows this is not going anywhere because it's a spending-limit bill that the president will not sign,'' said Senate GOP leader Bob Dole of Kansas. Dole said Republicans would not attempt to filibuster the bill as they did two years ago, successfully beating back eight attempts by Democrats to have the chamber vote on it. Both sides acknowledged that any agreement with President Bush is not likely until Congress returns from its August vacation. In addition to the public financing of vouchers, the Democratic bill also provides discount mail subsidies to candidates abiding by the spending limits as well as funds to counter broadcast ads by independent groups costing over $10,000. Additional public financing would also be provided to candidates whose opponents exceed the voluntary spending ceilings. McConnell's amendment would have eliminated all those potential public sources of money in the bill. In the House, Speaker Thomas S. Foley said he hopes to bring widely different versions of campaign-reform measures to the floor before the House recesses at week's end. Unlike the Senate versions, two Democratic alternatives and a Republican version in the House would all diminish the role of labor, corporate and trade association PACs but would not eliminate them. Like their Senate counterparts, House Democrats are insisting on spending ceilings while House Republicans oppose them. ``I think we might have to consider having separate procedures for the House and Senate,'' said Foley, a Washington Democrat . ``Obviously some features applying to state parties would have to be consolidated.'' House Democrats would establish a spending ceiling of $550,000, roughly half the average spent by winners in the 1988 House elections. The Democratic-proposed limits on Senate races _ based on the size of a state's voting-age population _ range from slightly under $2 million in smaller states, such as Nevada, Montana and North Dakota, to $10.3 million in the largest state, California. Mitchell attempted to refute Republican claims that a spending ceiling would benefit incumbents and maintain a Democratic majority. ``Any limits will benefit challengers because incumbents have the greatest access to money,'' Mitchell said, citing the 1986 and 1988 Senate elections, in which incumbents outspent challengers in 51 of 55 races by a total of more than $100 million. Republicans countered that six successful challengers in those elections _ four Republicans and two Democrats _ spent more than the Democratic bill would allow. Senate Democrats bowed to Republicans in agreeing to abolish PACs Friday and agreed to remove from their bill a public-financing provision that would have financed up to 70 percent of a candidate's general election campaign through a voluntary taxpayer checkoff. Republicans, for example, want to disallow the use of free ``franked'' mail by incumbent senators in election years and prohibit such efforts as the $45-million, union-sponsored 1988 voter-registration and get-out-the-vote drive _ which mostly benefited Democrats.

DOC.HEAD: US Rules Out Military Intervention in Trinidad
With AM-Trinidad Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The State Department said Monday there are no plans for U.S. military intervention to bring an end to the Moslem-led insurrection against the elected government in Trinidad. While refusing comment on reports of U.S. military maneuvers in the area, deputy spokesman Richard Boucher suggested that a military solution had been ruled out. At the same time, Boucher criticized Libya's involvement with the rebels, saying it has provided some training for the insurgents. But he said there was no apparent direct link between Libya and hostage-taking which occurred last Friday. Abu Bakr, the leader of a Moslem sect, launched the coup attempt by seizing the Parliament building in Port-of-Spain and capturing Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson and about 40 other hostages. Robinson and one other goverment minister were believed to have been shot in the leg early in the coup attempt, and both have been getting medical attention, said Bernard W. Aronson, assistant secretary of state for inter-American affairs. Trinidad government spokesman Gregory Shaw identified the second victim as Justice Minister Selwyn Richardson, and said both men were in stable condition. Shaw said Robinson had been shot in both feet, not the legs Aronson, who spoke in an interview on the ``MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour'' on the Public Broadcasting System, also said people were killed in the coup attempt but said the department did not have a figure on the casualties. He said none of them was a high-ranking government official, but he declined to identify the victims further. The Trinidad crisis has some of the earmarks of the situation in Grenada seven years ago when a radical leftist movement took power. In that case, the United States and several other Caribbean countries decided to oust the radicals. As in Grenada, the insurgents have shown a willingness to use extremist methods to advance their cause. In both Grenada and Trinidad, there were signs of involvement by anti-American elements from abroad. In Grenada, the leadership there had close links to Cuba while in Trinidad, Libya has been allied with the rebels. Also, in both cases, a major concern of Washington has been the well being of thousands of Americans residing in the two countries. But a major difference between the two situations is that whereas virtually all of the Americans in Grenada were students at a medical school, the 6,000 Americans in Trinidad are dispersed around the island and are less vulnerable to a mass hostage-taking. The international political climate also has undergone a dramatic transformation since 1983, a period when Cold War tensions were at a peak. There is little indication that the events in Trinidad will have an impact beyond that country's borders. This was not the case in 1983, when members of the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States asked for the dispatch of U.S. troops. Beyond that, American officials said government officials in Trinidad have indicated a desire to resolve the crisis without outside help.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Protection Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House acted Monday to protect the Grand Canyon from any further damage from the hydro-electric functions of the nearby Glen Canyon Dam. A bill approved by voice vote directs the Interior Department to operate the dam on the Colorado River in Arizona in a such a way that natural, cultural and recreational resources downstream in the Grand Canyon are protected or improved. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., sponsor of the bill, said that for more than 25 years the dam has been diverting water through power turbines upstream of Grand Canyon at times of peak electricity demand. This has caused fluctuations in water flow that has hurt wildlife in the canyon and frequently left rafters stranded on sand bars, conservationists argued. Enviornmentalists filed lawsuits demanding that the Interior Department do an environmental impact statement analyzing dam operations. In 1988, a six-year study concluded that the dam was damaging the canyon environment, and last July the Interior Department announced that it would prepare the environmental impact statement. ``The current management of this dam is a national embarrassement,'' Miller said. ``The primary purpose of this bill is to take immediate and lasting steps to protect the resources of the Grand Canyon.'' Miller's bill requires the Interior Department to take interim steps, pending completion of the impact statement, to protect the environment and mitigate and damage that has already taken place. It directs the department to take long-term steps for operation of the dam after the impact statement is completed. The bill still must be approved by the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: ACLU Seeks To Block Prayers At Graduation, Other School Activities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to clarify suit filed by civil rights group.
DOC.TEXT: A civil rights group on Monday sued two school districts in this heavily Mormon state, seeking to forbid prayers at everything from graduations to football games.
DOC.HEAD: Prayers at, 2nd graf
Palestinian Youth Dies from Gunshot Wound
DOC.TEXT: A 15-year-old Palestinian boy died Monday from a gunshot wound suffered in a clash with Israeli soldiers in the occupied West Bank, and Israeli authorities said two separate Arab guerrilla cells have been uncovered. In Monday's clashes in the occupied territories, 10 Palestinians were wounded, Arab reporters said. The army confirmed three wounded and said it was checking further. Arab reports identified the shooting victim as Saher Baarah, 15, of the West Bank city of Nablus, who was shot in the head Saturday night. Baarah died Monday at the Tel Hashomer hospital in Tel Aviv. The army confirmed that a Palestinian had died from a plastic bullet wound sustained during clashes Saturday with stone-throwing Arab demonstrators in Nablus. Baarah's death brought the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli gunfire during the 31-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation to 725. At least 242 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators. Forty-five Israelis have also died in the violence. Also in Nablus, the military and the Shin Bet security service uncovered a guerrilla hideout used by a group calling itself the Revolutionary Security Service, affiliated with Yasser Arafat's Fatah wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the army said. The hideout, a well-concealed cave dug under a house, contained a rifle and machine gun, four pistols, a large amount of ammunition, knives and other military equipment, the army said. Investigators also found two identity cards belonging to Arabs killed as suspected collaborators this year. Another identity card found in the cave belonged to a Palestinian who was badly wounded by an axe last April, the army said. The group has attacked and violently interrogated dozens of Palestinians it suspected of collaborating with Israel during the uprising, the army said. Eleven members of the group were captured in Nablus last month. Israeli authorities also released information about another Fatah guerrilla cell whose six members _ all Israeli Arabs _ were indicted by a military court in Lod last week. The indictment alleged the cell, led by Khaled Hassan Canaan from the village of Tamra in western Galilee, planted bombs in two Haifa shopping centers and on a beach in the northern town of Nahariya the past year. None of the bombs caused any injuries or damage. The indictment said Fatah had recruited Canaan while he was studying law in West Germany two years ago. It alleged that the group received orders from high-ranking Fatah officials in West Germany and Yugoslavia. Israeli officials said they had passed information on this Fatah cell to the United States. Arafat, the PLO chairman, renounced terrorism and recognized Israel's right to exist in December 1988, opening the way to direct talks with the United States. The U.S. administration suspended those talks in June after Arafat failed to discipline the PLO faction responsible for a foiled seaborne raid on a Tel Aviv beach.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Anti-Junk Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House approved a bill Monday that would let homeowners and businesses keep incoming junk faxes and phone calls off their telephone lines. The legislation, approved by a voice vote, would authorize the Federal Communications Commission to set up a national register of telephone subscribers who object to the unsolicited messages. The FCC also would establish penalties for advertisers who call people oin the list. ``This legislation empowers consumers and businesses with the ability to `just say no' to unsolicited telephone advertisements,'' said Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on telecommunications and finance. Solicitations by charitable and political organizations would be exempt from the ban. Consumers, either private individuals or businesses, could specify that they do not wish to receive advertising by FAX machines or automatically dialed, prerecorded telephone solicitations. The legislation was crafted in conjunction with the FCC, the telephone industry and the direct marketing industry, Markey said. The Senate still must approve it.

DOC.HEAD: Travel To Nicaragua Resumes
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua's national airline is flying between Managua and Miami for the first time in more than five years. An Aeronica flight carrying babies, businessmen, travel agents and government ministers landed at Miami International Airport on Sunday afternoon and was immediately hailed as the opening of a bridge between the new democracy in Nicaragua and the exile community in Miami. The 140-minute trip was Aeronica's first Miami-Managua flight since former President Reagan imposed an economic embargo on Nicaragua on May 7, 1985, cutting off trade between the two countries. Following Chamorro's February election, President Bush lifted the embargo March 7, clearing the way for Aeronica to resume service to South Florida, home to a Nicaraguan community estimated at between 80,000 and 150,000. No U.S. airlines now serve Managua, but Continental, American Airlines and Pan American World Airways have approached the U.S. Department of Transportation about starting up routes.

DOC.HEAD: Man Rescued From Rubble Says He Tried to Kill Himself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE survivor's medical contention. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `He said...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MLA3
DOC.TEXT: A man rescued Monday 14 days after an earthquake buried him in the basement of a luxury hotel said that while trapped in the darkness he often wished he were dead and even tried to kill himself. Pedrito Dy, a cook and part-time fitness instructor, was the third survivor pulled since Friday from the ruins of the Hyatt Hotel in the northern resort of Baguio. He is one of the longest survivors of an earthquake on record. Dy, 27, was flown to Manila for medical treatment. One doctor, Raul Morena, said Dy's athletic build protected him from serious injury in the July 16 quake that killed about 1,600 people. Doctors said he suffered only from dehydration and low blood sugar, which caused disorientation. Dy spent a peaceful night at Manila's Makati Medical Center, where he was being fed dextrose and a soft diet, doctors said Tuesday. They said Dy's blood sugar levels had returned to normal. Speaking from his hospital bed on Monday, Dy said that while trapped he lay on his back beneath a cushion, which protected him from the debris that shifted repeatedly in aftershocks. He said he survived by drinking urine and rainwater. ``I drank my urine, sometimes drops of rainwater,'' Dy said. ``I caught water with my mouth and scooped urine with the palm of my hand. For 13 days, I was telling myself I would die.'' Dy's voice was barely audible. His eyes were glazed and his conversation rambled from recollection to recollection without concern for the subject or sequence of time. Dy said he finished his shift as a cook at the 350-room hotel and headed for the basement gymnasium to lead about a dozen employees in an afternoon workout. Suddenly, the building shook and the force of the temblor hurled him against an exercise cushion hanging on a wall. The wall collapsed. But the cushion shielded him from serious injury. While trapped, Dy said he was aware of the passage of time because a clock that had hung on the gym wall continued operating. It struck every noon and midnight. ``On the 13th day I told myself I wish I were dead,'' he said. ``I attempted to kill myself two times. I banged my head on the wall. ... I prayed constantly to the Virgin Mary and gave my life up to the Lord. Then I wasn't scared anymore.'' On Sunday, Dy heard noises. It was the tapping of Filipino miners tunneling through the debris, searching for survivors. He called out for help. Alex Fongafong, a miner for PHILEX Mining Corp., heard the cries. Wedging himself through a narrow tunnel, the miner found a small triangular opening. Peering inside, he saw Dy lying on his back. ``We'll come back for you and we will bring you out,'' Fongafong shouted. He returned later with mining engineer, Hector Castillo, who used a jackhammer to cut through a beam blocking Dy's escape. After a couple of hours, Castillo said rescuers bored a 1{-foot hole and pulled Dy into the passageway to freedom. Outside, hundreds of rescuers and spectators cheered as Dy and the others emerged early Monday. ``I am calling for my wife and parents: I'm alive, I'm alive,'' Dy told a radio reporter in Ilocano, the dialect of northern Luzon island. ``I'm OK.'' Later, in Manila, Dy told reporters he made a ``secret vow'' to the Virgin Mary during his days in darkness, although he did not reveal what it was. Dy said he was among 12 people trapped in the basement of the hotel wing used to house employees. But all the others had died. The July 16 earthquake measured 7.7 on the Richter scale. Besides the 1,653 people killed, 1,000 are missing and presumed dead, 3,000 were seriously injured and 110,000 were homeless. Foreign rescue teams in Baguio abandoned the search for more survivors more than a week ago because they said sensor instruments indicated no more people were alive in the ruins of eight hotels. Baguio is 130 miles north of Manila. But Filipino crews, many of them volunteers, continued the search. There was renewed optimism after two survivors, both hotel employees, were pulled from the rubble, where they had been trapped for 11 days. The two _ Luisa Mallorca, 20, a cleaning woman and Arnel Calabia, 26, a guard _ were reported in good condition and were flown Sunday from Baguio to Manila for medical treatment. More than 50 people, including 12 Americans of Filipino origin, are still believed buried beneath the Hyatt. There have been other miraculous cases of earthquake survival in modern times, but Dy appears to be one of the longest survivors on record, based on a review of Associated Press reports on other major recent quakes. When a powerful earthquake struck San Francisco on Oct. 21, 1989, rescuers pulled an Oakland longshoreman, Buck Helm, from his car 89{ hours afterward. He died 28 days after his rescue. The most celebrated survivors of a Mexico City earthquake in September 1985 were the ``miracle babies'' found in the rubble of two maternity hospitals. The newborns survived periods of entombment ranging from eight hours to almost nine days.

DOC.HEAD: Stricter Log Export Ban Passes Conference Committee
DOC.TEXT: A congressional conference committee approved a bill Monday that would ban the export of unprocessed logs from most state-owned lands in the western states. Northwest lawmakers drafted the measure this spring to offset a shrinking timber supply as logging is prohibited on more and more public lands in an attempt to protect wildlife that inhabit old-growth forests, including the rare northern spotted owl. The proposal now goes to the floors of the House and the Senate, where approval is expected. Under the bill, export of raw logs could continue on one-fourth of the state-owned lands in Washington, but would be banned on all state lands in Oregon, California, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, Wyoming, Utah, Colorado, Arizona and New Mexico. Hawaii and Alaska are not affected. Backers of the proposal say it will keep at home about 600 million board feet of timber, three-quarters of it in Washington an Oregon, annually shipped to more lucrative markets overseas. In each of the last two years, about 3.6 billion board feet of unprocessed timber, the bulk of it from private land, has been exported from Washington and Oregon, about 80 percent of the total national exports. About one in four trees cut in the Pacific Northwest is shipped to foreign countries, primarily Japan. ``When we are experiencing a tight timber supply, as we are now in the Northwest, it makes absolutely no sense to be shipping raw logs overseas,'' Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., said. Packwood and several other Northwest lawmakers also advocate a ban on the export of raw logs from private lands, but the Bush administration as well as the timber industry strongly opposes that idea. The bill would make permanent the temporary ban on raw log exports from federal lands in the Western United States. It also would close loopholes in the federal ban that allow some timber companies to obtain federal logs from a third party for their domestic mills while shipping their own private logs overseas.

DOC.HEAD: Fujimori Orders Two-Day Bank Holiday in Peru
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with Fujimori dismissing four top police officials. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `Fujimori said...'
DOC.TEXT: President Alberto Fujimori declared a two-day bank holiday Monday to stop a run on the institutions as he prepares to unveil his economic program aimed at ending the country's economic crisis. Fujimori, sworn in Saturday to a five-year term as president, said the bank holiday would give his government time ``to implement the necessary measures to carry out our economic program.'' The mandatory holiday took effect immediately, and banks were closed throughout the country on Monday. Also Monday, Fujimori, a political newcomer, continued a major shakeup by firing four of the country's top police officials. The move follows his dismissal of the heads of the navy and air force over the weekend. The government announced that new chiefs had been appointed to head the National Police, General Police, Technical Police and Security Police. No specific reasons were given for the police changes. In his inaugural address, Fujimori pledged a crackdown on official corruption. Fujimori said his government's economic program will be announced to the country on Thursday or Friday by Prime Minister and Economy Minister Juan Carlos Hurtado. The president has refused to discuss details of the drastic measures he has promised to try to turn Peru's economy around. But he told reporters Monday that the economic measures would not adversely affect Peruvians' savings. ``Quite the contrary,'' he said. ``We want to encourage Peruvians to save and the measures are aimed at that goal.'' Fujimori's predecessor, Alan Garcia, left the new president with an economy that has collapsed. Annual inflation tops 3,000 percent. Four of five people lack steady work and the government is virtually bankrupt. Fujimori has said he will cut price subsidies, raise taxes and privatize many state-owned companies. He has also said he would devalue Peru's inti to raise the dollar's cost by 300 to 400 percent. Last week, many banks ran out of money, leaving thousands of workers unable to cash their checks. Drivers formed blocks-long gasoline lines and bread disappeared from poorer neighborhoods. Store shelves are often half-empty because merchants withhold supplies in expectation of higher prices. Also Monday, Fujimori hosted a luncheon at the presidential palace for the nation's top military and police officers. The luncheon followed his decision last weekend to dismiss the heads of the navy and the air force. On Monday, both branches of the military recognized the new commanders-in-chief appointed by Fujimori hours after his inauguration. Fujimori dismissed Gen. German Vucetich and Adm. Alfonso Panizo. He named Gen. Arnaldo Velarde to head the air force and Adm Luis Montes Lecaros to command the navy. Fujimori did not given any reasons for the changes. Panizo and Vucetich would normally have remained in their posts until the end of the year. The president did not explain the reasons for the changes. Panizo and Vucetich would have normally remained in their jobs until the end of this year. Vucetich said he does not know why he was dismissed, and declared he would seek a meeting with Fujimori to get an explanation. Vucetich was forced to retire and Panizo was reassigned to a position in Washington. Analysts said the dismissals were probably part of an effort to impose authority over the military and in line with Fujimori's pledge to fight corruption. Vucetich had been accused of corruption earlier this year by a prominent television newsman. The general denied the allegations. Panizo probably was fired because he was slow in denying rumors the military was plotting a coup if Fujimori won June's presidential election, the analysts said. However, Fujimori has given the military a prominent role in his government. Three ministries _ defense, interior and fisheries _ are headed by military officers. Fujimori, 52, is an agronomist of Japanese descent who won a landslide election victory in his first campaign for office over acclaimed novelist Mario Vargas Llosa.

DOC.HEAD: Stepfather Found Guilty of First-Degree Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with comments from foster mother, prosecutor. Pick up 5th graf pvs, `The state...
DOC.TEXT: A stepfather was convicted Monday of murdering a toddler he plunged into a toilet as punishment for soiling his pants. The case forced reforms in the way Florida protects children considered at risk of child abuse. It took jurors less than two hours of deliberation to convict Thomas Coe of first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse. Circuit Judge Randall McDonald ordered the jury to reconvene Wednesday to decide if Coe should be sentenced to life in prison or death in the electric chair. ``He deserves the electric chair,'' said Pam Kirkland, the child's foster mother for 14 months. ``For what he did and the way he did it, I think that would be an appropriate punishment.'' Coe, 23, testified last week that he ``was out of control'' July 27, 1989, when he dunked his 2-year-old stepson, Bradley McGee, into the toilet as punishment for soiling his pants. The boy died the next day of massive injuries. ``You have a confession from the man, that was very damaging,'' said prosecutor John Aguero after the verdict. Defense attorneys slipped out a back entrance of the courthouse without answering reporters' questions. The state contended that the child's death was a malicious culmination of weeks of Coe's bizzare abuse. But the defense said in closing arguments that the fatal dunking was an isolated incident in toilet training and that Coe's intent wasn't malicious. Coe's attorney, Robert Norgard, argued Coe should be convicted of a lesser offense. ``All he meant to do was dunk Bradley's head in the water to use the association with water to teach the child not to soil his pants,'' Norgard said. ``In the heat of the moment, he thought of something that was frankly unusual, but he did not intend to hurt that child.'' Prosecutor John Aguero countered: ``There is no rational explanation for an irrational act. This was a senseless killing.'' Bradley's death came two months after he was ordered returned from foster care to his mother, Sheryl McGee Coe, and stepfather, Thomas Coe. Mrs. Coe, 21, has testified that during those two months her husband often forced the child to pick up feces with his mouth and ground his fist and cayenne pepper into the boy's genitals. She admitted to sometimes aiding in abuse and beating the toddler with pillows just before he died. She pleaded no contest to second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse and is serving a 30-year term. Norgard suggested that the jury find Coe guilty of manslaughter, citing the actual wording of the law as, ``culpable negligence'' rather than an intentional act, and reckless disregard for human life. ``We're not here to ask you to find Coe not guilty _ that man did cross the line,'' Norgard said. ``But hold this man responsible for what he did and not for what he didn't do.'' Medical experts have testified for the prosecution that when Bradley died, his body was covered with more than 50 bruises, some of them more than two weeks old. Norgard also did his best to discredit the allegations of the principal state witenss, Sheryl Coe, saying she was trying to distance herself from the crime to make life easier on herself in prison. Because of news reports about the case, the trial was moved from Polk County _ where the death occurred _ to Fort Myers. Outrage over the case also led to the state's passage of the ``Bradley McGee Act'' which allocated $79 million for more child-protection workers. A former Florida Health and Rehabilitative Services caseworker was convicted last month of felony child abuse for negligence for failing to provide a judge with a psychological evaluation of the Coes describing them as infantile, explosive and unable to handle children. Three other state workers were cleared of charges filed in their handling of the case.

DOC.HEAD: Spill Upgraded to Major Proportions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-9, `The revised ...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with largest slick 8 miles long, Redfish Island seriously affected, editing to conform; picks up 10th graf pvs, `By Monday ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard estimated Monday that 500,000 gallons of oil leaked into Galveston Bay from two barges, 10 times its original estimate of the weekend spill that has killed fish and stalled marine traffic. ``We have upgraded the spill to a major spill,'' said Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene. A patchy sheen of oil was seen heading through the Bolivar Pass from the bay into the Gulf of Mexico, threatening to make the cleanup more difficult, Coast Guard Petty Officer Gene Maestas said Monday night. The bay is bordered by environmentally sensitive marshes and beaches. A skimmer ship was dispatched to try to keep the oil from the gulf. Thick, black patches of goop and a brown sheen have spread through much of the bay, Greene said. He said suspicious oil was reported on at least two beaches south of where the barges and a tanker collided Saturday. The largest slick, estimated at 8 miles long, remained northeast of the collision site late Monday near Redfish Island in the Houston Ship Channel, which ``took a pretty bad hit,'' Maestas said. The Coast Guard didn't have an estimate of how much oil had washed up on the island. The revised estimate came after crews finished removing oil from a listing barge Monday, and determined how much oil was left in a second barge partly submerged in the channel, officials said. Coast Guard officials estimated 48,000 gallons of oil leaked from the listing barge, meaning most of the oil leaked from the nearly sunken vessel. The two barges contained a total of 1.68 million gallons of ``catfeed'' oil, a heavy refinery oil similar to No. 5 fuel oil, Maestas said. Any spill over 100,000 gallons is considered major, Greene said. The Coast Guard originally estimated 50,000 gallons had spilled. The spill has killed an undetermined number of fish near Redfish Island, and forced the closure of the channel. By Monday afternoon, at least 58 ships were stalled at the Houston docks or outside the Galveston Bay because the channel was closed. Mark Layton, manager of Kerr Marine Steamship Inc., estimated the delays were costing ship owners up to $20,000 per ship. The Coast Guard hopes to reopen the channel by Wednesday, Greene said. The salvage contractor T&T Marine of Galveston used four skimmer vessels and a vacuum truck to suck up oil on Monday, Greene said. Booms were used to surround leading edges of the spill to try to contain the heaviest sections. Almost every area surrounding the bay is considered environmentally sensitive, said Texas Water Commission Chairman B.J. `Buck'' Wynne. ``While the amount of the spill is less than the Mega Borg, I would say the potential for aquatic damage is more significant,'' he said, referring to last month's spill of 3.9 million gallons from the Norwegian supertanker some 57 miles offshore from Galveston. Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro agreed, and said a special session of the Legislature may be necessary to enact oil spill readiness laws. ``I think once again it shows that we in Texas really aren't prepared to deal with an oil spill,'' he said. ``This happened Saturday and this is Monday morning, and we're still talking about what equipment to put where and where we are going to get the equipment from.'' Wynne and Mauro plan on Tuesday to present Coast Guard officials with a plan to use oil-eating microbes on the spill. The state tried the microbes on the Mega Borg spill and said they'd reduced the oil in the test area. `These tidal wetlands are very sensitive,'' Wynne said. `If oil gets in there, it might be more difficult to clean up with conventional methods.'' He said use of skimmers or other mechanical devices could endanger shallow marshlands and sensitive estuaries. The tanker Shinoussa was damaged in the collision with two of three barges under tow by the tanker Chandy N, but did not leak any of the 24,900 metric tons of jet fuel it was carrying. Coast Guard officials originally believed the tanker was of Liberian registry, but learned Monday that the 610-foot, double-hulled vessel is a Greek ship.

DOC.HEAD: Victim Of Stray Bullet Recalled As A Happy Girl
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with mayor's comment, CORRECT that child hit by two shots, not in armpit. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `Yaritimi Fruto...
DOC.TEXT: An infant boy was killed by a stray bullet Monday, just hours after mourners packed the funeral of a 9-year-old girl shot to death less than a week before. The 9-month-old baby, Rayvon Jamison, was shot after someone pumped seven bullets through the door of the child's Bronx apartment at 4:11 p.m., said Officer Fred Weiner, a police spokesman. His death brings to four the number of children killed in New York in a week by bullets apparently intended for others. He was sitting in a walker when he was struck twice by gunfire, Weiner said. The child's mother, uncle and grandmother were in the room at the time of the shooting, he added. Rayvon died a short time later at Lincoln Hospital. Police were investigating a possible dispute between the uncle and another man as a motive in the shooting, but had made no arrests. Mayor David Dinkins said the killing demonstrated the need for a complete federal ban on assault weapons. ``Do we need further proof of what happens when we allow so many people to be armed with so many guns firing so many bullets?'' Dinkins said. ``Our children are dying.'' Yaritimi Fruto, 1, was killed last week in Brookly by gunmen who also killed her father. Ben Williams, 3, was killed last week when someone fired 18 shots through the door of his grandmother's Brooklyn apartment while he slept on a fold-out couch. There have been no arrests in those shootings. Earlier in the day, about 250 people listened as pastor Wengeslao Martinez of the Rock of Salvation Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn, and his son, Samuel, recalled VeronicaCorales' enthusiasm. Samuel Martinez described Corales, as ``beautiful, sincere, truthful, happy, cheerful and full of joy.'' ``This is all the things she expressed and made us express back to her,'' he said. ``Her love and joy is within our hearts.'' Shortly after her funeral, an indictment charging Dorian Daughtry with second-degree murder in her death. Daughtry, 22, is a former minor-league baseball player. The girl was struck by a stray bullet July 22 as she slept in a parked car in Brooklyn's East New York section. Her family had just returned from a New Jersey amusement park and was dropping off relatives. Police said Daughtry apparently was involved in a shootout with at least one other person and the girl was struck with a bullet from Daughtry's gun, which was not recovered. Daughtry joined the Seattle Mariners' Class A farm team, the Bellingham, Wash., Mariners, in 1987. He played outfield and roomed with Ken Griffey Jr., now a major league all star. Daughtry asked to be released after the 1989 season.

DOC.HEAD: Pearl Harbor Medal Approved
DOC.TEXT: The House approved legislation Monday establishing a commemorative medal for members of the U.S. armed forces who were present during the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor Dec. 7, 1941. By voice vote, the House directed the Treasury Department to strike a bronze medal that would be presented to those veterans as nearly as possible to the 50th anniversary of the attack. The medal could be accepted by families of those killed on that fateful day or veterans who survived the attack and died later.
