The bill applies to those who defended Pearl Harbor and other military installations in Hawaii. The bill also directs the Treasury to duplicate smaller versions of the medal in bronze that can be sold. The suprise Japanese attack by 360 planes from six aircraft carriers sank seven of eight battleships of the U.S. Pacific Fleet. The United States entered World War II the following day with a declaration of war against Japan. Military casualties were listed as 2,343 killed, 960 missing and 1,272 wounded. In addition, 49 civilians were killed and 83 wounded.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Prime Minister Says Trinidad Siege to End
DOC.TEXT: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad (AP) _ Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson and the chief negotiator for Moslem extremists said Monday they have reached agreement to end a 4-day-old hostage siege. Robinson is one of 41 hostages reported held since Friday by black Moslem extremists led by Abu Bakr. Justice and National Security Minister Selwyn Richardson, speakig from inside Parliament where the uprising began, said the agreement called for Robinson's immediate resignation with elections to be held within 90 days. Richardson said the government had granted amnesty to the Moslem radicals involved in the insurgency, which has left at least nine people dead, according to officials. Speaking by telephone from inside Parliament, Robinson said the agreement was reached after ``very difficult bargaining.'' The prime minister said he instructed Col. Joe Theodore, head of the Trinidad and Tobago Defense Force, to ``make necessary arrangements for the evacuation (of hostages and rebels) as soon as possible.'' Chief rebel negotiator Bilal Abdullah, speaking next on the telephone, said: ``I wish to totally corroborate what Prime Minister Robinson has just said.'' Army spokesman Maj. Dave Williams reported earlier Monday that the Moslems were armed with AK-47 assault rifles, pistols and grenades. In the first official casualty count, Williams said at least nine people had died in the fighting since Friday. He said Anglican negotiator Knolly Clarke told him additional bodies were inside the parliament building, but it was not known how many. Trinidad is just off northeast Venezuela, and is a former British colony that gained independence in 1962. It has been wracked in recent years by declining oil revenues and economic doldrums, including high unemployment.

DOC.HEAD: 14 Monkeys Die of Heatstroke at the Centers for Disease Control
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen research monkeys suffered heatstroke and died after being left outside as temperatures soared into the 90's, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control said Monday. The rhesus monkeys, which had been taken from their cages for deworming and health screening, were discovered on the floor of an outdoor housing building at the agency's breeding and holding complex in Lawrenceville. The monkeys died July 9, but Monday was the first public announcement of the deaths by the CDC. CDC officials said it was the biggest number of accidental primate deaths in the half-decade history of the research agency. The monkeys were among a colony of 100 raised for research in the CDC's breeding complex. Researchers said heat usually doesn't cause abnormal stress for rhesus monkeys, which are commonly found in the subtropical regions of India and Asia, as well as in the frigid Himalayas of Nepal. ``Everyone concerned with it is very upset that it happened, and we are taking steps to see that it doesn't happened again,'' said Bobby G. Brown, chief of the CDC's animal resources branch. Brown said the monkeys, among 33 which had been taken from one section of the rhesus compound, had been anesthetized to allow six animal handlers to safely deworm them and test them for the simian AIDS virus and tuberculosis. The other monkeys suffered no ill effects from the treatment. The CDC is investigating the deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Court Rejects Appeal against Extradition
DOC.TEXT: In the first test of a new extradition law in the Republic of Ireland, a man wanted in an IRA bombing campaign lost an appeal Monday against being extradited to England. The High Court denied an appeal by television engineer Desmond Ellis, 37, whose lawyers said they would appeal to the Supreme Court. Ellis is named in two warrants alleging possession of explosives with intent to endanger life and conspiracy to cause explosions in Britain between Jan. 1, 1981, and Oct. 27, 1983. Scotland Yard Detective Sgt. Ian Macleod testified that 13 fingerprints linked Ellis to an Irish Republican Army arms cache found in October 1983, and five bomb attacks in London in 1981. Laywers for Ellis argued that the alleged offenses were political, and ``an integral and necessary part of the campaign by the IRA to end British rule in Northern Ireland.'' Justice Liam Hamilton held that the alleged offenses involved ``indiscriminate violence and can correctly be characterized as terrorism.'' Ellis swore in an affidavit that he was in Irish or U.S. jails during the bombings. The District Court ordered Ellis' extradition last January. He has been in custody since then, awaiting appeal. He will remain in custody until his appeal before the Supreme Court. The case is the first to be heard under a 1987 Republic of Ireland Act which curtails the plea of political motivation. The IRA is seeking to overthrow the institutions governing the Irish Republic, as well as end British rule in Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Freeze Accounts Linked to U.S. Thrifts Collapse
DOC.TEXT: Swiss authorities froze several bank accounts last week believed to contain millions of dollars linked to savings-and-loan fraud in the United States, Justice Ministry spokeswoman Ursula Riedel said Monday. She said the accounts were frozen in at least three Geneva banks pending a Swiss decision on a U.S. request for judicial aid in the case of now-defunct Community Savings and Loan in Bethesda, Md. She said U.S. government investigators asked in mid-July for access to bank records they think can shed light on the scandal. Swiss federal authorities can approve transmission of the request to Geneva officials, who will make a final decision on the U.S. request. The U.S. request did not say how much money allegedly is in the accounts, Ms. Riedel told The Associated Press. Published reports said President Tom J. Billmann of Community Savings and Loan was alleged to have defrauded clients of $106 million. Swiss accounts reportedly hold $22 million of the total. Authorities closed the Bethesda bank after the case broke. Billmann, 50, is living in the Costa del Sol resort area of Spain and is being sought by police, the Washington Post reported.

DOC.HEAD: Yankees Owner Forced to Abandon Management Role
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comment from Steinbrenner, fans, details. A version moving on sports wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY29,30,33
DOC.TEXT: George Steinbrenner was stripped Monday of direct control of the New York Yankees, all but ending a turbulent 18-year reign during which he alienated players and fans alike. Fans at Yankee Stadium for a game against the Detroit Tigers greeted the announcement with a 90-second standing ovation. Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent forced Steinbrenner to resign as principal partner of the team for paying a gambler to dig up dirt on Dave Winfield, the American League team's onetime star outfielder. Steinbrenner agreed to Vincent's terms following a four-month investigation by the commissioner into Steinbrenner's dealing with self-described gambler Howard Spira. Observers suggested that Steinbrenner was seeking leverage to force Winfield to accept a trade to another team, something his contract gave him a right to refuse. ``Mr. Steinbrenner will have no further involvement in the management of the New York Yankees or in the day-to-day operations of that club,'' Vincent said. Steinbrenner, the team's majority owner, must resign as general partner by Aug. 20, when someone will be appointed to take his place, subject to the approval of Vincent and the other major league teams. Vincent asked Steinbrenner to reduce his interest to below 50 percent within the next six months. Steinbrenner will, however, be allowed to consult on major business decisions involving the Yankees, but he must ask Vincent's permission to attend games. ``For all purposes, Mr. Steinbrenner agrees that he is to be treated as if he had been placed on the permanent ineligible list,'' Vincent said. Steinbrenner also agreed he wouldn't contest the decision in court. ``I will not comment on the decision,'' Steinbrenner said. ``I'm very happy it was resolved. I'm very satisfied with the resolution, and that's all I'm going to say.'' This was the second straight summer baseball penalized one of its more famous characters. Last August, Pete Rose was banned for life for gambling. As one baseball's more fiery characters, Steinbrenner was famous for his hiring and firing of managers, particularly the late Billy Martin, and for feuding with his players, including Reggie Jackson and Winfield. Winfield was one of Steinbrenner's many high-priced free agents, but Steinbrenner turned on the star outfielder after he went 1-for-22 in the 1981 World Series loss to Los Angeles. Later, Steinbrenner derided Winfield as ``Mr. May,''' saying he only came through when it didn't count. Winfield and Steinbrenner feuded throughout the 1980s and, after several years of trying, Winfield was finally traded to the California Angels last May. Steinbrenner is the only owner to be severely penalized twice for major offenses. He was suspended in 1974 by then-Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for making illegal campaign contributions to Richard Nixon. This time, Vincent disciplined Steinbrenner for violating Rule 21, otherwise knows as the ``best interests of baseball'' clause. ``I am able to evaluate a pattern of behavior that borders on the bizarre,'' Vincent said. ``It is apparent to me that Mr. Steinbrenner does not appreciate the gravity of his conduct.'' The investigation centered on Steinbrenner's $40,000 payment to Spira, a 31-year-old New Yorker who describes himself as a former gambler and a former employee of the David M. Winfield Foundation. Steinbrenner testified before Vincent on July 5 and July 6 and gave various reasons for the payment to Spira. Among them were that he was afraid Spira would attack his family, that he gave Spira the money ``out of the goodness of my heart'' and that he wanted to protect two former Yankees employees from embarassing revelations. Many fans at Yankee Stadium thought Steinbrenner got what he deserved. ``That's what should happen to any owner that constantly makes decisions to hurt the club,'' said Trevor Beckford of Westbury, N.Y. ``He traded away my favorite player, Dave Winfield, and changed managers it seemed like every month.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Echols; AMS separates moved on Frid as a0684, Echols as a0662
DOC.TEXT: Bolton Sullivan, a founder of Skil Corp., which produced the first portable electric saw, died Thursday at his home in Lake Forest. He was 94. With his father, J.W. Sullivan, Bolton Sullivan founded Skil Corp. in 1924 in a one-room shop on Chicago's northwest side. The company manufactured and sold the Skilsaw, invented by Edmund Michel. The firm gained a worldwide reputation as a manufacturer of portable electric tools before it was merged into Emerson Electric Co. in 1979.

Saginaw-Chippewa chief Arnold Somwick, 59, and his wife, Margaret, 52, died Sunday night in a car crash as they were returning from a powwow in Michigan's Upper Peninsula. Sowmick was credited for helping to bring jobs and relative prosperity to his Isabella Reservation tribe, which has about 1,000 members. Margaret Sowmick, also a tribal member, was a teacher's aide on the reservation just east of Mount Pleasant.

Nixon Smiley, an author and roving reporter who chronicled Florida history, died of cancer Sunday at Doctor's Hospital. He was 78. Smiley's 13 books described the history and ecology of Florida, focusing on offbeat characters and rural life. After a stint in the Navy, Smiley worked as a teletypist with The Associated Press and went to work for The Miami Herald in 1940. He first made his reputation as the newspaper's gardening reporter, from 1947 to 1963, and later moved to feature writing. In 1956, he was appointed research coordinator of Fairchild Tropical Garden in addition to working on his newspaper column. In addition to son Karl, Nixon Smiley is survived by his wife Evelyn, grandchildren Thomas, Scott, Mark and Larua and his uncle, Harry Smiley of Novato, Calif. There will be no services. His family asks that contributions in his memory be made to Fairchild Tropical Garden.

Armando Frid, who was a horse tamer and cattle driver in the early stages of a life said to have spanned 124 years, died July 21 at his home, the government news agency Telam said Monday. The 1989 Guinness Book of World Records lists the greatest authenticated age of any human as 120 years, 237 days. Shigechiyo Izumi of Japan died at that age in 1986. Hector Colla, the agency's correspondent in Viedma, near the rural town in Rio Negro province where Frid died, said he knew Frid and examined birth documents that government officials confirmed as genuine. Among many jobs, Frid hunted foxes and pumas, raised horses and worked as an oil hand in Patagonia. His last job was as a baker in Buenos Aires, Telam said.

Georges Conchon, author of prize-winning novels and screenwriter for an Oscar-winning film, died Sunday at age 65. The family said he died in a Paris-area hospital after a sudden illness. No details were released. Conchon mixed a varied literary career with long-term government service. From 1960 to 1980, he was secretary of debates at the Senate, the upper chamber of the French Parliament. His 1959 novel ``La Corrida de la Victoire'' (The Corrida of Victory) won the Prix des Libraires and his 1964 novel ``L'Etat Sauvage'' (The Savage State) won the Prix Goncourt, France's most prestigious literary award. Conchon was a journalist for the newspaper France-Soir in 1959-60 and served as artistic adviser to the national television channel Antenne 2 after his retirement from the Senate in 1980. He was a member of the governing Socialist Party.

Charles ``Red'' Barrett, who holds the major league record for the fewest pitches in a nine-inning game, died at his home Saturday after a long illness. He was 75. While pitching for the Boston Braves in 1944, Barrett faced 27 batters and threw only 58 pitches in a 2-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. Barrett was named to the National League All-Star team in 1945. He pitched in the World Series for St. Louis in 1946 and for the Braves in 1948. Barrett, who also pitched for Cincinnati, compiled a career record of 69-69 with an ERA of 3.53.

The oldest known American war veteran, George E. Echols, died July 26 at the age of 105, the Department of Veterans Affairs said Monday. The department said Echols, who served in World War I, died at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center here after a brief illness. Echols who was born Nov. 2, 1884, in Athens, Ga., served with the Army in France from June 1914 to October 1919. Echols' passing means that the oldest known American war veteran is now Nathan E. Cook, 104, of Phoenix, who is also the only known living veteran of the Spanish-American War, the veteran's department said.

DOC.HEAD: `World's Finest Emerald' _ Weighing 83.1 Carats _ Remains Unsold
DOC.TEXT: A plum-sized emerald valued at millions of dollars remained unsold Monday night after its owner called the highest bid of $850,000 unacceptable and removed it from an auction. Touted as the world's finest, the 83.1-carat gem went on the auction block at the Ritz-Carlton Houston. But the stone was removed from the auction ``with reserve'' after the highest bid received fell short of hopes. ``That was not acceptable,'' said Rob Plumer, a representative of the owner, whose name was kept secret. Nicknamed ``Denise'' after the fiancee of the Los Angeles owner, the emerald was the main attraction of a sale that featured hundreds of other gemstones and Soviet artwork. The sale, estimated to bring $10 million, began Sunday and continued Monday evening. Plumer said the owner would consider whether to offer it for sale later. ``We had mixed feelings about selling it anyway. We really don't know now,'' he said. He said the gem was valued at more than $3 million. He said the minimum acceptable bid for the gem would have been $1.5 million. The emerald was retrieved from the famous Muzo mine in Colombia, considered the finest emerald mine in the world, said Sandy Reid, executive vice president of Greystone Galleries of Toronto.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Oldest Veteran Dies At 105
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf: ``Echols, who,'' to CORRECT 1914 date from beginning of service in AFrance to beginning of service in U.S. Army
DOC.TEXT: The oldest known American war veteran, George E. Echols, died last week at the age of 105, the Department of Veterans Affairs said Monday. The department said Echols, who served in World War I, died July 26 at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center here after a brief illness. Echols, who was born Nov. 2, 1884, in Athens, Ga., served with the Army from June 1914 to October 1919. He served in France during the United States participation in World War I. Echols' passing means that the oldest known American war veteran is now Nathan E. Cook, 104, who is also the only known living veteran of the Spanish-American War, the veteran's department said. Cook now lives at the Carl Hayden Veterans Affairs Nursing Home in Phoenix, Ariz. In addition to his Spanish-American War service, Cook also served with the Navy during the Boxer Rebellion in China, the Philippine Insurrection, clashes on the U.S.-Mexican border, and in World War I and World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Roseanne Sings Again
Laserphoto LA16
DOC.TEXT: Roseanne Barr sang again, but this time she had accompaniment from back-up singers. During a talk show taping Monday afternoon, Barr and husband Tom Arnold stood and sang the national anthem with about 300 members of the studio audience. In this rendition, however, the comedy star did not screech, grab her crotch, spit or stick her fingers in her ears. Hand over her heart, she laughed and sang softly, accompanied by Arnold, the audience and host Sally Jessy Raphael, whose New York-based syndicated program traveled to Universal Studios to interview the couple. The hourlong talk show, to be broadcast Wednesday, was devoted entirely to the fracas following Barr's screaming version of ``The Star Spangled Banner'' delivered last week during a San Diego Padres doubleheader against the Cincinnati Reds. ``I've apologized over and over, about fifty times,'' Barr said during the taping. ``But the press, on TV, says I haven't apologized. '' As for grabbing her crotch and spitting, ``I apologize for that, too,'' Barr said. Barr stars in the TV comedy series ``Roseanne.''

DOC.HEAD: Drug Czar Proposes Plan for Rescuing `Drug Orphans'
DOC.TEXT: Federal drug czar William J. Bennett on Monday proposed taking children away from drug-ridden families and neighborhoods, and putting them in foster homes and other institutions. ``It may be radical, but radical circumstances require radical means,'' Bennett said during a luncheon on the opening day of the National Urban League's 80th anniversary convention. Bennett told those attending the civil rights group's meeting that with the big-city narcotics crisis likely to get worse before it gets better, anti-drug efforts must focus on the young. ``The heart of any plan must be a plan to save our children,'' said the director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. ``If we don't tend to these children soon, no government or non-government program will fill the need.'' Bennett proposed that the courts be permitted to remove children from families were parents or guardians are addicted or too preoccupied with drugs to provide physical, moral or spiritual guidance. The courts would place the children in foster homes, such institutions as Boy's Towns or Girl's Towns and school- and church-sponsored centers, Bennett said. He noted that courts can now take such steps for abused or negelected minors, but said his proposal was likely to provoke controversy. ``If this shocks some people into getting guardians to guarding, and parents to parenting, then fine,'' Bennett said. He appealed to the Urban League for support, citing a statement by group President John E. Jacob that ``drugs are destroying more children and more families than poverty ever did.'' Bennett provided few specifics on his proposal. He told a news conference following the luncheon that he wanted ``to see if we can get some agreement on the principle.'' Jacob said in a telephone interview that he found ``unnerving'' any proposal that would take children away from their parents and ``this one is no less unnerving.'' But he said the children's safety should be the uppermost concern. ``The challenge is that if you don't like our plan, come up with a better one to strengthen families and help children stay in families,'' Jacob said. Bennett said he'd been criticized recently for remarking that orphanages might help solve the problem of children whose families had disintegrated from drugs. ``Some people thought that was too Dickensian a phrase, but the reality is a lot worse than anything Charles Dickens ever imagined,'' Bennett said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders FBI to Make Index of Documents on Hoffa Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ordered the Justice Department to index FBI documents on its investigation of Jimmy Hoffa's disappearance 15 years ago Monday, a ruling the former Teamsters leader's family hailed as a victory. U.S. District Judge Stephen Limbaugh ordered the government to prepare within 30 days an itemized list off all documents related to a freedom of information request by the family. The government must provide a detailed justification for any documents it wants exempted, Limbaugh ruled. ``Our family is extremely grateful. Fifteen years have gone by without them telling us what they know,'' said attorney Barbara Crancer, who sued the government for files on her father's case in February 1989. ``We've waited so long to hear something,'' she said. Crancer said it was ``pretty ironic'' the ruling Friday came just before the 15th anniversary of Hoffa's July 30, 1975, disappearance. ``I don't think the judge planned it that way,'' she said. Calls seeking comment from FBI spokesman John Anthony and Justice Department attorney Henry Fredericks were not immediately returned. Hoffa, 62, vanished from a restaurant parking lot in the Detroit suburb of Bloomfield Township. Federal investigators have said they believe he was murdered but couldn't release their files because their probe was continuing. Hoffa built Detroit's Local 299, a tiny Teamsters unit, into a 15,000-member local, and became president of the international union. In 1958, he was hauled before the U.S. Senate rackets committee and accused of running a ``hoodlum empire.'' Nine years later, Hoffa was convicted of jury tampering and fraud involving the Teamsters Central Pension Fund and received a five-year federal prison term. Under a sentence commutation he received from President Nixon in 1971, Hoffa was barred from returning to office in the Teamsters until 1980. When Hoffa vanished, he was contesting that provision in court. His son, Detroit attorney Jimmy P. Hoffa has said he thinks his father was killed because he was trying to return to union power.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of July 23-30:
DOC.HEAD: Profit Down at Times Mirror, Tribune, Knight-Ridder, Washington Post
DOC.TEXT: Knight-Ridder Inc. reported a 64.8 percent drop in second-quarter earnings, while Times Mirror Co. said its after-tax profit tumbled 44.7 percent. Both said the big drops resulted from comparisons to year-earlier profits that were inflated by one-time gains from the sale of assets. In other earnings reports, Tribune Co. said its net profit fell 25 percent, and Washington Post Co. said its earnings decreased 7.5 percent. All the companies said their operations were affected by the weakness in the advertising climate.

Times Mirror said it earned $47.0 million in the April-June quarter, compared with $85.0 million in 1989. Revenue rose 5.3 percent to $906.6 million from $861.3 million. The company said 17 percent of the year-earlier profit came from the sale of timberlands. Robert F. Erburu, chairman and chief executive, said weak economic conditions continued to adversely affect the company's newspaper and other advertising-driven businesses. For the first six months, the company earned $93.0 million, down 39.5 percent from $153.8 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 4 percent to $1.78 billion from $1.71 billion.

Tribune earned $58.1 million in the quarter, compared with $75.3 million a year ago. Revenue rose 2 percent to $656.2 million from $643.1 million. The company said its operating profit from newspaper publishing fell 33 percent, mainly due to losses at the Daily News in New York. Profit at the Chicago Tribune improved, but results at its other papers were flat or lower because of softness in retail and classified advertising. Operating profit for the newsprint group fell 83 percent because of lower newsprint selling prices and the adverse impact of a stronger Canadian dollar. For the first six months, Tribune earned $89.6 million, down 20 percent from $112.1 million in 1989. Revenue rose 3.6 percent to $1.24 billion from $1.2 billion.

Knight-Ridder earned $44.6 million in the quarter, compared with $126.8 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 2.2 percent to $591.7 million from $578.7 million. The company noted that two-thirds of the 1989 profit resulted from the sale of the Star News in Pasadena, Calif., and television operations. Net income from continuing operations in the latest quarter was up 14.3 percent from a year ago, it said. Knight-Ridder said advertising revenue at its 31 newspapers was under pressure, with retail and general advertising revenue marginally higher and classified ad revenue down slightly. For the first six months, Knight-Ridder earned $70.5 million, down 52 percent from $147.3 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 2.7 percent to $1.15 billion from $1.12 billion.

Washington Post earned $55.9 million for the quarter, compared with $60.5 million a year ago. Revenue edged up 1 percent to $379.6 million from $374.5 million. The company said revenue at its newspaper division dipped 2 percent as ad volume fell 9 percent at The Washington Post. Revenue at Newsweek was up 6 percent because the latest quarter had one more issue than the year-ago period. Revenue was down 4 percent for the broadcast division and up 11 percent in the cable division. For the first six months, Washington Post earned $95.0 million, down 6.9 percent from $102 million in 1989. Revenue edged up 0.5 percent to $720.5 million from $716.3 million.
DOC.HEAD: Reuters Says Earnings Up 27 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Reuters Holdings PLC said July 24 that its after-tax profit jumped 27 percent in the first half of the year, helped by strong sales in all major markets, particularly Europe. Reuters said earnings for the January-June period were the equivalent of $188 million, compared with $148 million in 1989. Revenue rose 26 percent to $1.2 billion from $954 million. The company said sales strength was partly due to the relative weakness of the pound during the period, which made British companies more competitive in selling products and services in other countries. The pound has since rebounded. Reuters said that ``conditions in financial markets remain difficult and cancellations of Reuter services, which were already high, have recently risen further.'' The company did not report separately for the second quarter, which is not required under British law.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Posts Loss of $51 Million in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. lost $51 million in the second quarter because of costs and interest expenses related to Time's $14 billion purchase of Warner Communications Inc. But the company said July 23 that earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization climbed to a record $536 million for the quarter. It said four of its six business segments _ films, records, cable TV systems and programming _ had record second quarters. Earnings were down in the magazine division because of the soft advertising climate and startup costs of Entertainment Weekly, and profits also were down in the book division. Time bought controlling interest in Warner last July but did not complete its purchase of the rest of Warner's stock until January. Compiling results as if both companies had been combined both years, the latest loss compared with a loss of $52 million in 1989's second quarter. Revenue rose 4.4 percent to $2.59 billion from $2.48 billion. For the first six months, Time Warner lost $102 million, compared with a loss of $133 million a year ago. Revenue rose 6 percent to $5.33 billion from $5.03 billion.
DOC.HEAD: Washington Times' Loss Reported at $35 Million a Year
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Times has been losing $35 million a year and the deficit is being covered by the Unification Church, The Washington Post reported July 27. The Post quoted Bo Hi Pak, a deputy to the church's founder, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, from an interview in Seoul, South Korea. Pak said the church and its subsidiaries are ``very glad to subsidize'' the Times because it contributes to world peace. The newspaper will not be sold or closed, he said. He estimated losses at $250 million since the newspaper started publishing eight years ago. The Times and the Post are the only two daily newspapers in Washington. The Times, which publishes Monday through Friday, reported circulation of 106,852 in September. The Post, which publishes seven days a week, reported Monday through Saturday circulation of 731,407 and Sunday circulation of 1,126,123. Arnaud de Borchgrave, editor-in-chief of the Times, said the newspaper is not subsidized directly by the Unification Church. ``We are subsidized by various businesses run by members of the church,'' de Borchgrave said. ``I run a secular newspaper. It has no connection with the church. We have never received an editorial instruction from the church or from Dr. Pak since I took over in March 1985.'' Pak is president of the parent company of the newspaper. In the interview, he said the church hopes to expand its video operations into a nationwide cable system, and to establish businesses and recruit church members in China and the Soviet Union. Businesses operated by church members include a machine tool company in Germany, a fishing fleet in Alaska, a computer lab in Japan, a video production company near Washington and a controlling interest in a nationwide cable channel. Pak said church headquarters in Seoul receives revenue of $100 million a year in business profits and church dues from members. He did not provide a breakdown.
DOC.HEAD: Second-Quarter Profit Up Slightly at Capital Cities-ABC
DOC.TEXT: Losses on ESPN's first months of major league baseball coverage held earnings growth at Capital Cities-ABC Inc. to a slim 1.6 percent in the second quarter, the company said July 24. Capital Cities warned its third-quarter earnings could be below last year's level if weak advertising demand persists at its TV station, radio and publishing operations and additional losses result as anticipated for ESPN's baseball coverage. Capital Cities owns 80 percent of the cable network. The owner of the ABC Television Network said it earned $142.3 million, or $8.19 a share, in the three months ended July 1 compared with $140.2 million, or $7.83 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 11 percent to $1.36 billion from $1.23 billion a year earlier. Operating income was up 2 percent to $270.3 million, reflecting significant improvement at the ABC TV network, a 10 percent gain from the publishing group, a moderate rise at its TV stations and a slight decline in radio operations. But video operations results fell sharply as a result of a $20 million loss incurred in the quarter at ESPN, which this spring began its first year of covering major league baseball. Last year, ESPN won a four-year, $400 million contract to cover up to 175 baseball games a year. But the audiences have been smaller than expected, forcing the cable network to give advertisers extra commercial time for free.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Asks Probe of Metzenbaum Involvement in Times Story
DOC.TEXT: An attorney representing a GOP lobbyist involved in a controversial savings and loan bailout asked the Senate Ethics Committee to decide whether Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum or his aides improperly shared confidential investigative material with The New York Times. The inquiry was requested July 23 by Stanley M. Brand, a lawyer representing lobbyist Robert J. Thompson, who was an aide to George Bush when he was vice president. Metzenbaum, an Ohio Democrat, is chairman of the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust, monopolies and business rights, which is looking into Thompson's involvement in negotiating the bailout of 15 thrift institutions now combined as Bluebonnet Savings Bank of Dallas. The Times ran a front-page story by reporter Jeff Gerth on questions surrounding the Bluebonnet deal July 8, the day before Metzenbaum's subcommittee held a hearing on the case. ``It now appears indisputable that sensitive investigative information ... gathered in the name of the U.S. Senate, was deliberately, intentionally and inappropriately given to a major national newspaper,'' Brand wrote. Brand based his complaint, in part, on a statement from Cable News Network reporter Brooks Jackson, who said he was told by Metzenbaum's staff that they had made an exclusive arrangement to share information with Gerth in exchange for an agreement that the Times would hold the story until the day before the hearing. Jackson, who was quoted in the July 21 editions of The Washington Post, said he was quoted accurately but declined to reveal which Metzenbaum aide had told him about the arrangement with the Times. Gerth referred inquiries to Howell Raines, the newspaper's Washington bureau chief, who said, ``As a matter of policy, we don't discuss sources or the editorial process.'' He said the story was ``meticulously researched from a number of sources'' and ``was industriously and honorably reported.'' Nancy Coffey, Metzenbaum's press secretary, said Brand's complaint was too ridiculous to comment on. Wilson Abney, staff director of the ethics committee, said he could not discuss what action the panel was taking on the complaint or even whether it had been received. He said complaints typically are referred to staff attorneys, who can then recommend whether or not the complaint should be investigated.
DOC.HEAD: IBM Cancels TV Ads for Golf Tourney
DOC.TEXT: Some advertisers canceled television commercials that were to run during the Professional Golfers' Association championship Aug. 9-12 after a controversy over the host club's all-white status. ``Supporting even indirectly activities which are exclusionary is against IBM's practices and policies,'' Gina Chew-Holman, an IBM spokeswoman, said July 24. Toyota and Anheuser-Busch joined IBM in withdrawing support for the telecast. Club founder Hall Thompson earlier had said the private club, Shoal Creek, would not be pressured into accepting black members. He later apologized and said he was quoted out of context. Shoal Creek officials have said the club does not have a policy against blacks and that some blacks have been guests. The Associated Press Sports Editors, an organization of sports editors of AP member newspapers, sent a letter to PGA officials July 2 protesting Thompson's remarks and called on major golf organizations to examine the membership policies of country clubs before awarding championship events.
DOC.HEAD: Council on Aging Worker Fired for Tipping Press to Feature Story
DOC.TEXT: A food server who urged a newspaper to profile a 115-year-old man was fired from her job at the Council on Aging because she was not authorized to contact the media, officials said. Betty Scanlan, 60, earned $3.80 an hour serving lunch to about 10 senior citizens. She also set aside lunches for sailors who delivered food to elderly patrons of the council's Meals on Wheels program. Scanlan called the Pensacola News Journal after a sailor said he delivered meals to a man who claimed to be 115. A reporter said she would investigate the claim and also wanted to write about Navy volunteers from Corry Station Technical Training Center. ``I thought it would be great for the sailors to get a little recognition ... I didn't think it'd be such a disaster,'' Scanlan said July 25. On July 18, Scanlan accompanied the reporter to a church where sailors were picking up meals. Later that day, Scanlan was fired because personnel policy stipulates that only the council's chairman, executive director and project directors ``may officially represent the agency in making public announcements, speeches and comments about agency business,'' council officials said. The newspaper has yet to run the stories.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Rips Cuomo Over Labor Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News blasted Gov. Mario Cuomo in an editorial July 29 for creating a ``completely unjustified'' board of inquiry to examine labor negotiations at the newspaper. ``The News feels free to call the governor's action ... a cynical political move by a potential presidential candidate to curry favor with national labor leaders,'' the editorial said. The News and its 10 unions have been negotiating for months without success to replace contracts that expired March 30. State Labor Commissioner Thomas Hartnett announced July 26 he was appointing a fact-finding panel to provide ``a fresh look at the issues'' and help prevent the dispute from harming the regional economy. The panel has no legal authority to compel actions by either side, although it has broad power to subpoena witnesses and gather evidence. The editorial called the panel a ``completely unjustified intrusion into the collective bargaining process and a violation of federal labor law.'' It also ripped the board as ``a publicity stunt that could have a ruinous impact on the state's business climate.'' Cuomo called the editorial ``a ploy by a management that is desperately seeking to avoid an objective look at the issues.'' He said the state has ``the legal right, and the practical obligation, to help achieve fairness by disclosing the truth.''
DOC.HEAD: Magazines' Difficulties Reflect Industry, Analyst Says
DOC.TEXT: Woman magazine is being closed and Woman's Day no longer is for sale, two developments reflecting difficult times in the magazine business. Conde Nast Publications Inc. said July 25 it would close Woman magazine after its September issue. It is the first Conde Nast magazine to cease publication since the Newhouse family took over the company in 1959. Woman has been published for 10 years but was acquired by Conde Nast about 18 months ago. Separately, France's Hachette SA said it shelved plans to sell Woman's Day magazine, saying it was dissatisfied with the bids it received over the past two months and now will invest in improving it. Both Woman's Day and Woman have had double-digit declines in advertising pages for the year's first six months amid an industry-wide ad slump. Consumer magazine ad pages were off 3.3 percent across the industry in the year's first half compared with the January-to-June period in 1989, with traditionally heavy magazine advertisers such as automotive and tobacco companies making major cutbacks in spending. Magazine industry analyst Martin S. Walker said the two latest developments show ``the market has really decided that there is no long-term future in broadly based women service magaines.''
DOC.HEAD: Reporter Misidentified as Killer
DOC.TEXT: A reporter covering a murder trial was ejected from the courtroom July 24 after a witness misidentified her as the killer. The witness changed her mind after a closer look, but reporter Marlys Duran of the Rocky Mountain News was ordered to leave the room and told she might be called as a defense witness. Mildred Goble was a witness in the first-degree murder trial of Christina Acker, who was accused of killing Margaret Hamilton in 1989. Asked if Acker was in the courtroom, Goble pointed to the reporter. ``I was seated in the first row of the spectators' section behind the defendant,'' Duran said. ``I was just dumbfounded.'' The reporter said she and Acker have the same hairstyle, but the suspect's hair is a different color, ``and she's probably 6 inches shorter than me.'' Defense attorney Harvey Steinberg said prosecutors were still relying heavily on Goble's testimony. ``It's kind of strange they'd take that position after she identifies Marlys Duran as the last person to be seen alive with the victim.''

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Allowed To Speak at City Council Meetings
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of a feisty quarterly newspaper that often takes potshots at City Council members is once again allowed to speak her mind at council meetings. Mayor Mel Hughes lifted his edict prohibiting Enrica Stuart, publisher of the Monitor, from speaking at council hearings as a member of the public. Stuart, who writes most of the articles and distributes the paper free to residents, was told at a May meeting that she could not speak. ``You're either a member of the public or a member of the press,'' Hughes told her. Stuart objected, and the American Civil Liberties Union backed her up. ACLU attorney Marketa Sims told the council that Stuart was being deprived of her First Amendment rights to free speech and her rights under the state's open meetings law. Despite reversing himself, the mayor remained unapologetic. ``I think I was absolutely right,'' Hughes said. ``... When she gets out of line the next time, I'll bring it up again.''
DOC.HEAD: Former Reporter Sentenced to Prison for Sex Crimes
DOC.TEXT: Peter Citron, a former entertainment reporter and columnist, was sentenced to three to eight years in prison and was diagnosed as a mentally disordered sex offender requiring treatment. In passing sentence July 23, District Judge Merritt C. Warren described Citron as a pedophile since at least 1965. ``You are a sick man, and you need treatment for a long time,'' Warren said. Citron, 50, pleaded no contest in May to two counts of sexual assault of a child. He was a columnist for the Omaha World-Herald at the time of his arrest in February and resigned shortly after his arrest. Citron was charged after two boys, then ages 13 and 11, told police Citron had fondled them through their clothing in separate incidents at his home. Police officers seized several boxes of evidence from Citron's home. Before the sentence was read, Citron told the judge that he was ``dreadfully sorry'' for any harm he had done and asked for probation instead of a prison sentence. Psychiatric reports ordered by Warren concluded that Citron is a treatable mentally disordered sex offender. As a result, Citron could serve at least part of his sentence at the Lincoln Regional Center, a state mental hospital.
DOC.HEAD: Police Confiscate Photographer's Film at Crime Scene
DOC.TEXT: Police confiscated the camera and film of a newspaper photographer taking pictures at the scene of a fatal shooting July 24. The camera was returned shortly thereafter and the undeveloped film was returned about seven hours later, after a telephone conference between police and newspaper attorneys. Police said Albuquerque Journal photographer Jeff McClintic crossed the lines of a crime investigation. McClintic denied it and Journal Editor Gerald Crawford said authorities were high-handed in seizing the camera and film. Versions of the incident differed, with police and the district attorney's office both saying the other had ordered the confiscation. Assistant District Attorney Mark Burtner, who was on the scene, said the film was taken because an unidentified person was taking pictures in the middle of a crime scene. Police ordered the confiscation, he said. Police supervisor Capt. Cliff Jenkins said police were concerned that pictures of the unidentified body might be printed before next of kin could be notified. He said the district attorney's office ordered the confiscation.
DOC.HEAD: Owners of Hair Salon Sue `A Current Affair'
DOC.TEXT: A hair salon is suing the television show ``A Current Affair,'' saying the show falsely portrayed it as a den of devil worship and promiscuous teen-agers. The suit was filed July 23 by Super Hair Associates Three-13 in Marietta, Ga. It seeks at least $40,000 damages. One of the salon's employees was Jan Parsons, who, according to a suit by her mother, was featured nude in a home video made by movie star Rob Lowe. A spokesman for the television show, Jeff Erdel, said the suit has no merit. The suit contends the narrator of the segment titled ``It's the Shame of Atlanta'' heralded the segment as a ``special look inside the bizarre Atlanta club scene.'' ``Jan was not new to the fast lane,'' the narrator continued. ``Locals say the hair salon where she worked is a magnet for rebellious teen-agers, kids who sleep around, do drugs and spend all night in the clubs. It's the shame of Atlanta. ... Some say the hair dressers at Super Hair worship the devil, some insist it's a drug ring and some suspect it's a personality cult.''
DOC.HEAD: Drug Maker Among Defendants in Shooting Suits
DOC.TEXT: Three lawsuits each seeking more than $57 million were filed by the widows of three men killed during a shooting spree at a printing company last year. Joseph Wesbecker killed himself after fatally shooting eight workers at Standard Gravure Corp. The lawsuits were filed July 25 against the company, its security service, Wesbecker's estate, a psychiatrist who was treating him at the time of the shootings and a drug company that makes an anti-depressant he was taking. Wesbecker was on long-term disability leave from his pressman's job at Standard Gravure because of psychiatric problems. The printing company is situated next door to the Louisville Courier-Journal in a building owned by the newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: British Court Issues Temporary Book Ban
DOC.TEXT: A High Court judge on July 27 issued a temporary injunction banning a book that reportedly gives intimate details about Britain's royal family. Justice Michael Wright banned author Malcolm Barker from publishing ``Courting Disaster'' anywhere in the world, but stayed the ban until July 30, pending an appeal. The injunction also forbids Barker's Nova Scotia-based publisher, Fleetwood Publications, from selling the book in Britain. The book is on sale in Canada, the United States and Bermuda, said Barker's lawyer, David Fowell. Lawyers for Barker and Fleetwood Publications said they would appeal against the part of the court order that bans Barker from publishing outside Britain. Barker worked from 1980 to 1983 as a storeman-clerk to the Master of the Royal Household at Buckingham Palace. The book makes disclosures that lawyers for Queen Elizabeth II claim breach a confidentiality agreement signed by Barker when he joined the palace staff. If Barker, who lives in Nova Scotia but is currently visiting Britain, disobeys the order he could be jailed and face heavy fines for contempt of court. Angered by behind-the-scenes revelations by former employees, the palace in recent years has increasingly reverted to legal action to suppress a succession of spicy memoirs.
DOC.HEAD: Private Eye and Editor Fined for Contempt
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court fined the magazine Private Eye and its editor $18,100 each July 26 for publishing articles that prosecutors said could have affected the outcome of the notorious Yorkshire Ripper murder case. They also alleged the articles were intended to discourage the defendant's wife from pursuing a libel case against the satirical magazine. Outside court, Private Eye Editor Ian Hislop said: ``I'm disappointed. We will pay the fines and it's a slap on the wrist.'' The Court of Appeal panel upheld the Attorney General's appeal against a High Court ruling that favored the magazine in March. The High Court found that two February 1989 articles did not pose a threat to the administration of justice in the trial of Peter Sutcliffe, who became known as the Yorkshire Ripper. Those articles claimed the defendant's wife, Sonia Sutcliffe, had provided her husband with a false alibi and defrauded the Department of Health and Social Services. Sutcliffe was jailed for life in 1981 for killing 13 women and attempting to kill another five. Mrs. Sutcliffe was not implicated in any of the crimes.
DOC.HEAD: Soviet Media Censorship Abolished, but Censor Remains
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has a new law forbidding state censorship of the media, but the main censorship agency won't be abolished, its director said in an interview published July 26. Chief Soviet censor Vladimir Boldyrev said the Glavlit censorship agency will continue to check foreign publications, and audio and visual materials mailed to the Soviet Union for calls to overthrow the government or to commit crimes, and for pornography, war propaganda, and material promoting racial or ethnic superiority. The press law, debated for months before it was passed by the Soviet legislature on June 12, takes effect Aug. 1. It also gives any Soviet citizen the right to establish a media outlet. The law forbids publication of state secrets, but the penalties are to be imposed on whoever leaks them rather than on the journalist reporting them. It also forbids slander and abuses of privacy. Scores of unofficial papers have appeared in the Soviet Union. Their publishers must scramble to reach agreements with state-run printing houses to supply paper.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Official Comments on Ban on Journalists
DOC.TEXT: The government said banning The Asian Wall Street Journal and the Far Eastern Economic Review from covering the Asia-Pacific Economic Conference would not keep other Asians from getting news about the meeting. Goh Chok Tong, first deputy prime minister and defense minister, said more than 100 correspondents from foreign news agencies, newspapers and magazines had received permission to attend the conference July 30-31. He made the comment July 23 in a written reply to a letter from Dow Jones & Co. Inc. of New York, owner of the Hong Kong-based publications, which are widely circulated in Asia. In a letter to Goh, Dow Jones vice president Karen Elliot House had questioned the ban, saying the government previously had asserted a right to control coverage of Singapore's internal affairs that might be read by residents of the island state. Since the conference is a meeting on international issues, House wrote, ``it appears that the government of Singapore is now asserting its right to control what other Asians are permitted to read about major international meetings that happen to occur in your country.'' Singapore has accused the Journal and weekly Economic Review of interfering in its domestic politics, a charge the two publications deny. The government has refused to let the Review base a reporter here since mid-1987 and the Journal since mid-1988. In 1987, the government required the Journal to reduce its daily circulation here to about 500 copies from 5,000. The Review was ordered to cut back to 400-500 copies a week from 10,000 but the magazine refused to continue selling in Singapore.
DOC.HEAD: Ingersoll Reaches Agreement With Irish Newspaper Workers
DOC.TEXT: Unions at Irish Press newspapers reached a last-minute agreement with Ingersoll Publications Ltd. to accept longer work weeks, layoffs and the introduction of new equipment. The Ingersoll-managed group, Irish Press Newspapers Ltd., is half-owned and managed by Ingersoll Publications, a British company controlled by Ralph M. Ingersoll II. Management reached the agreement with the National Union of Journalists and the Irish Print Union on July 22, just before the deadline it had set for closing the Irish Press, Evening Press and Sunday Press. The settlement calls for 200 voluntary layoffs, the immediate introduction of new technology and a shift from a four-day, 28-hour work week to a five-shift, 35-hour schedule. The 750 workers had rejected the same proposals on July 19. Ralph Ingersoll, burdened by a heavy debt load of mostly junk bonds and a downturn in the U.S. newspaper industry, relinquished ownership of his American newspaper company, Ingersoll Publications Co., in early July. The investment firm E.M. Warburg Pincus and Co. took ownership of the U.S. newspapers, while Ingersoll acquired Warburg's 50 percent interest in Ingersoll Publications Ltd. The British company also owns the Birmingham Post and Mail, Coventry Evening Telegraph and other British newspapers.
DOC.HEAD: Israel Gives Green Light To Build VOA Station
DOC.TEXT: The National Planning Board reversed its decision to delay construction of a Voice of America relay station after U.S. officials pleaded for an immediate go-ahead despite environmentalist protests. Israel's Nature Protection Society said it would appeal the July 24 reversal to the Supreme Court. The board initially voted in June to halt the project in Israel's Arava desert for a two-year ecological study of bird migrations, which environmentalists said could be disturbed by the transmitter. Environmentalists also spoke of possible radiation health hazards. The U.S. government runs VOA. The approval of the $300 million facility came a day after Washington repeated assurances the transmitter would cause no harm. The station is to transmit VOA broadcasts to Eastern Europe and Africa. It was conceived as a Cold War tool, but U.S. officials said it was also valuable in the era of detente.
DOC.HEAD: Morris To Endow Chair in Newspaper Management
DOC.TEXT: William S. Morris III, chairman of Morris Communications Corp., pledged $500,000 to endow a chair in newspaper management at the University of Georgia's Henry W. Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication. Morris, a graduate of the journalism school, said July 23 that the chair will be named the William S. Morris Chair of Newspaper Strategy and Management in memory of his father. He said the university would raise a matching sum to match his gift, putting the chair's endowment at $1 million.

DOC.HEAD: Viewers Vote on What News Show Covers
DOC.TEXT: Viewers of CNN's ``Newsnight'' began experimenting with an interactive format July 24, phoning in their choice of stories they wanted to see. They chose reports on the anti-depression drug Prozac and an Alabama marijuana eradication program. About 1,400 callers to a 900-code number paid 75 cents to choose their favorite story from six choices. The four other reports dealt with Washington Mayor Marion Barry's drug trial, a sailing program designed to keep Indian teen-agers off drugs, summer jobs, and efforts to save the spotted owl. ``This was the shakedown cruise,'' executive producer Joshua Loory said after the show. ``I think there were some minor production problems but all in all, it went pretty well. I'm tickled right now.'' Near the beginning of the hour-long show, which begins at midnight EDT, viewers were presented with a menu of the six stories and the 900 number. The calls were tabulated by computer and the two most popular stories were fit into the newscast. The story on Prozac received 35 percent of the vote while the drug eradication program received 26 percent. The rest of the show was taken up with other news stories chosen by the editors. Loory said the show's producers are content to leave viewer selection at only two stories. ``We're still very much in control of what's going into the show,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: TBS Could Lose $26 Million on Goodwill Games
DOC.TEXT: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. could lose as much as $26 million on the Goodwill Games, the same amount it lost on the inaugural games in Moscow in 1986, Ted Turner says. The company's board of directors will decide whether to hold another Goodwill Games after this year's events are over and the financial results are in, Turner said July 23. Speaking to shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Seattle, Turner would not detail the reasons for the expected loss. A $26 million loss would double the company's earlier projections, he said. Nevertheless, Turner, who is TBS chairman, said he was optimistic about this year's Goodwill Games, which end Aug. 5. He said the international Olympics-style competition is increasing world exposure for TBS and helping the Atlanta-based company market its Cable News Network and other services abroad.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Head Says Cities Should Allow Cable Competition
DOC.TEXT: Municipal officials too often slam the door on companies that could provide head-to-head competition for cable TV operators, a federal regulator said July 27. Federal Communications Commission Chairman Alfred Sikes rejected the notion that, like utility monopolies, communities are best served by exclusive cable TV franchises. He said competition will drive down both costs and prices. A new FCC study shows that cable operators face head-to-head competition in only a handful of communities, resulting in high prices and poor service, Sikes told a news conference. ``Head-to-head competition places an exceptionally high premium on cutting costs and putting the customer first,'' Sikes said. ``Competitive markets and competitive markets alone will in the final analysis force prices toward true costs.'' Rather than reregulate cable prices, which Congress is preparing to do, Sikes said laws are needed to ease the way for multiple-cable franchises and more competition from technologies such as satellite broadcasters and microwave cable systems. On July 26 the commission voted to forward a report to Congress urging legislation that ``limits municipal authority to erect barriers or sustain entry barriers and which prohibits an unreasonable refusal to grant a second (cable) franchise.''
DOC.HEAD: Former TV Anchor, Women's Rights Activist Found Dead
DOC.TEXT: Kim Thomas-Friedland, a women's rights activist and a former news anchor for Financial News Network, was found dead at her home July 27, and police were conducting a murder investigation. The cause of death had not been established, police said. Ms. Thomas-Friedland's husband, Edward Friedland, told police he found her body on his return from work. Ms. Thomas-Friedland, 32, was a leader in the Charlotte chapter of the National Organization for Women and a former anchor for cable television's Financial News Network. She also was the co-author of an advice book for pregnant women.
DOC.HEAD: Networks Ban Tabloid-Bashing Commericals
DOC.TEXT: Jeans commercials showing Marla Maples dumping two supermarket tabloids into a trash can have been banned from CBS and NBC. The 15-second spots feature Maples, who has been romantically linked to developer Donald Trump, in a pastoral setting wearing No Excuses jeans and holding copies of the National Enquirer and Star. An Enquirer headline reads: ``Trump Mistress Close to Suicide.'' ``The most important thing we can do today is clean up our planet. And I'm starting with these,'' Maples says as she tosses the papers. ``Things look better already.'' Beth Bressan, a CBS vice president in charge of program practices, said the ad was rejected as ``unduly disparaging towards those newspapers.'' ``Our longstanding policy is not to sell ad time for the airing of private disputes,'' said Rick Gitter, NBC vice president of ad standards. Neil Cole, president of New Retail Concepts, which makes the jeans, said he doubted his company would change the commercials. ABC made no immediate decision. The Fox network and the Turner Broadcasting System have decided to air the ads beginning Aug. 15

DOC.HEAD: ABC News Shows Offered Overseas
DOC.TEXT: ABC News, seeking new overseas markets for its programs, said July 25 it has been showing European broadcasters ``Nightline'' and will do the same with four more programs, including ``World News Tonight.'' The programs are being sent via satellite to cable and TV companies in 23 countries in Western and Eastern Europe, including Rupert Murdoch's new Sky Television direct broadcast satellite operation, based in London, ABC said. Once the European television officials have had a chance to look at ABC's programs, the network's executives will hold discussions with the companies interested in carrying the programs, an ABC News spokesman said. The evening newscasts of NBC and CBS, and ABC's ``Nightline'' already are carried in some overseas markets, including Japan. However, the top-rated ``World News Tonight'' isn't yet broadcast overseas, said the ABC spokesman, Scott Richardson. All three U.S. network news divisions have been seeking new markets and revenues as they lose audiences to cable and other viewing alternatives. Ted Turner's 24-hour Cable News Network, an early entry in the global news market, is seen in 90 countries, according to CNN.
DOC.HEAD: CNBC President To Leave Company
DOC.TEXT: The first president of NBC's consumer and business cable channel, CNBC, is leaving to form an independent company that manages broadcast properties. No successor was immediately named for Michael Eskridge at the Consumer News and Business Channel. He was named president of CNBC in July 1988 and the service began in April 1989. Eskridge said July 23 that he would stay at CNBC until his replacement is found, and denied published speculation that he was forced out. NBC executives have said they expect to lose money on CNBC for three years but predict it will have 30 million subscribers and will start making a profit in its fourth year.
DOC.HEAD: NBC Union Rejects Contract for Second Time
DOC.TEXT: A major union at NBC has rejected the company's four-year contract offer for the second time since April, but is trying to arrange new negotiations, a union spokesman said. Members of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians voted 1,290 to 516 to reject NBC's offer, NABET spokesman John Krieger said July 27. ``We're trying to arrange further bargaining talks,'' he said. There was no immediate comment from NBC. The union says it has 2,373 members at NBC, and at NBC-owned facilities here and in Burbank, Calif., Washington, D.C., Chicago and Cleveland, and at NBC news bureaus throughout the United States. The union, which represents local and network newswriters and technical employees, struck NBC in 1987 in a bitter walkout lasting 17 weeks. Krieger said no strike vote had been taken, and NABET members continued to work. Their previous contract expired March 30. He said main issues in contract talks include jurisdiction, the use of people hired by the day rather than permanently, and ``four-walling'' proposals under which outside producers could rent NBC facilities to make shows without being required to use NABET crews employed by NBC.
DOC.HEAD: Victoria Corderi New CBS Co-Anchor
DOC.TEXT: Victoria Corderi was named July 25 as the permanent co-anchor with Charles Osgood of the ``CBS Morning News'' and the news segments of ``CBS This Morning.'' Corderi transferred to New York from CBS' Miami bureau in January. She succeeds Faith Daniels, who left CBS in March to join NBC as anchor of ``NBC News at Sunrise'' and the news segments of the revamped ``Today'' show.
DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Motion for Videotape in `Hard Copy' Trial
DOC.TEXT: A city prosecutor's bid to force a television program to turn over a videotape made during a report on underage gambling was denied July 25. Municipal Judge Bruce Weekes said New Jersey's shield law prevents prosecutor Steve Smoger from getting the videotape made for the syndicated television program ``Hard Copy.'' Smoger sought the videotape from Paramount, producers of ``Hard Copy,'' to use in the prosecution of Ellen Gussenberg and Daphne Pinkerson, who work as field directors for the program. The women are charged with two misdemeanor counts of inducing minors to gamble. Two teen-agers were arrested last Aug. 18 at TropWorld Casino and Entertainment Resort and charged with underage gambling. They pleaded guilty to falsifying a driver's license application and are testifying for the prosecution.
DOC.HEAD: Station Cuts Jobs, Blames Economy
DOC.TEXT: WHIO-TV said July 26 it will cut 17 jobs because of a soft economy. Neil Pugh, vice president and general manager, said five of those losing jobs were department heads. The station has 145 full-time workers.

DOC.HEAD: Amoss Named Editor at Times-Picayune
DOC.TEXT: Jim Amoss was named editor of The Times-Picayune on July 24 to succeed Charles A. Ferguson, who took early retirement. Amoss had been an associate editor since 1988. Before that, he served as city editor and metro editor. Amoss came to The Times-Picayune in 1980 when it absorbed the afternoon States-Item, where he started as a reporter in 1974. Ferguson had been editor of The Times-Picayune for 10 years. Before that, he was editor of The States-Item.
DOC.HEAD: Murray to Anchorage Times
DOC.TEXT: Former Chicago Tribune news editor J. Randolph Murray was appointed editor of The Anchorage Times on July 24. Murray, 44, replaced Hugh Cunningham, who was hired as interim editor shortly after Veco International, an oil-field services company, bought the newspaper in December, said Publisher Bill Allen. Murray was news editor of the Tribune's Washington bureau from 1986 until last year. Before that, he was an assistant managing editor at the Chicago daily and had worked for the Tribune-owned Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel. Murray joined the Times as a consultant in January to help redesign the newspaper. Cunningham, 69, is a former University of Florida journalism professor with more than 50 years in the newspaper business.
DOC.HEAD: Balcom Named Publisher, Editor in innesota
DOC.TEXT: David H. Balcom, editor and vice president of The Natchez Democrat in Natchez, Miss., has been named publisher and editor of the Faribault Daily News. Balcom, 43, succeeds Larry ``Leo'' Dorschner, who is joining Townsend Publishing in Kansas City, Mo. The appointment was announced July 25 by Jim Huckle, president of Huckle Publishing, the Daily News' parent corporation. Balcom has been editor and vice president of The Natchez Democrat for the past year. In his 16-year career he has also held top newsroom positions with papers in Carlisle, Pa., South Haven and Ionia, Mich., and Corning, N.Y.
DOC.HEAD: Sanders to General Manager at Hastings
DOC.TEXT: Carl Sanders, advertising director of The Napa Register in Napa, Calif., will become general manager of The Hastings Tribune on Aug. 1. Sanders succeeds Don Heath, The Tribune's general manager the past seven years, who is moving to Longmont, Colo. Sanders previously worked at the Norfolk (Neb.) Daily News and The Grand Island (Neb.) Independent.
DOC.HEAD: Jim Wynn Named Executive Editor of Rome News-Tribune
DOC.TEXT: Jim Wynn, executive editor of The Meridian (Miss.) Star since 1982, was named executive editor of the Rome News-Tribune on July 28. Wynn began his journalism career in 1956 as sports editor of the Waycross Journal Herald. He later worked as city government reporter for The Macon News and as Atlanta bureau chief for the Macon Telegraph and News before being named press secretary to Lt. Gov. Garland Byrd in 1960. He served as editor of the Marietta Daily Journal from 1963 until 1965, and has also worked for newspapers in Florida and Alabama.
DOC.HEAD: Wells to Managing Editor in Victoria, B.C.
DOC.TEXT: John Wells, an editorial consultant with Thomson Newspapers in Toronto, was named managing editor of the Times-Colonist on July 24. The Times-Colonist is owned by Thomson Newspapers. Wells will succeed Gordon Bell, who is retiring Aug. 17 after a 42-year newspaper career. Wells began his career as a legislative reporter for the Medicine Hat (Alberta) News in 1974. He later worked at The Toronto Star, The Edmonton (Alberta) Journal and The Cambridge (Ontario) Reporter, where he was managing editor for six years. Bell worked for The Edmonton Journal and the Calgary Albertan before joining the Victoria Times as business editor in 1960. He was appointed managing editor of the Times in 1968 and was named managing editor of the Times-Colonist in 1980 when the Times and the Colonist merged.
DOC.HEAD: San Jose's Rawlings To Be Editor of Sporting News
DOC.TEXT: John Rawlings, executive sports editor of the San Jose Mercury News, has been appointed the new editor of The Sporting News effective Aug. 20. He succeeds Tom Barnidge, who will assume the new position of national staff columnist and write editorials and opinion pieces for the St. Louis-based national sports weekly publication. ``These important editorial moves help strengthen this company's leadership role as America's sports authority,'' said Thomas G. Osenton, president and chief executive officer of The Sporting News Publishing Co. Rawlings, president of the Associated Press Sports Editors association, also has worked at The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Miami Herald. The Sporting News is owned by Times Mirror Inc.
DOC.HEAD: Johnson Named CNN President
DOC.TEXT: Ted Turner named Tom Johnson, former Los Angeles Times publisher, as the new president of his Cable News Network, effective Aug. 1. Johnson will succeed Burt Reinhardt, 70, who has been with the network since its start 10 years ago and has been president the past eight years. Johnson called himself ``a strong champion of hard news'' who will try to expand CNN's overseas bureaus. He said he plans no sweeping changes at CNN. Johnson, 48, was a special assistant to President Johnson in 1968. He joined the Times in 1977 and now is its chairman, and vice chairman of the parent Times Mirror Co. He was the Times' publisher for nine years until he was replaced last August by David Laventhol, president of Times Mirror Co. Johnson has served as a director of The Associated Press for six years. Johnson also will serve as Turner Broadcasting System's vice president for news and as a member of TBS' executive committee. CNN said Reinhardt will become vice chairman of the company and serve as an interim adviser before retiring.
DOC.HEAD: Stone Named GM of WSB-TV; Baker Moves to WSOC-TV
DOC.TEXT: Gregory J. Stone, vice president and general manager of WSOC-TV in Charlotte, N.C., has been promoted to vice president and general manager of WSB-TV in Atlanta. He succeeds Andrew Fisher, executive vice president for Cox Enterprises broadcasting. Fisher is leaving the station to devote full time to his Cox position, which he assumed earlier this year. Bruce R. Baker, station manager for WSB, will replace Stone at the North Carolina station.
DOC.HEAD: Gehrig Named Chief Editor of AP German Service
DOC.TEXT: Peter Gehrig was named the new chief editor of the AP's German-language news service on July 27, succeeding Uli Renz, who asked to step down for health reasons. Gehrig, 43, previously was editorial chief of the German service's foreign news department. He joined the AP in 1968 and worked as a sports writer, special correspondent and editor on the German AP operation's domestic news desk. Renz joined the AP in 1972, beginning as an editor in the foreign news department and later becoming the head of the German service's domestic news desk in Frankfurt. Renz became chief editor of the service, which serves 116 newspaper and broadcast subscribers in West Germany, in 1985. He will continue with the service, returning at his request to its foreign news desk.
DOC.HEAD: Fairbank Named AP South Carolina News Editor
DOC.TEXT: Katie DeBo Fairbank has been named news editor in the Columbia bureau of The Associated Press. Ms. Fairbank, 30, succeeds Eva Parziale, who has been promoted to assistant chief of bureau in Kansas City. Ms. Fairbank joined the AP last year in Indianapolis. She previously worked as a copy and design editor for the Charleston (S.C.) News and Courier. She also was a copy editor at the Dallas Times Herald and city editor at the Del Rio (Texas) News-Herald.

DOC.HEAD: John R. Bond
DOC.TEXT: John R. Bond, former publisher of Road & Track magazine, died July 20 after a long battle with emphysema. He was 77. Bond bought Road & Track in 1949 when it was two years old and struggling to survive. He instituted such staples of automotive journalism as the technical road test, and the magazine became a popular success. Bond, an automotive engineer who once designed motorcycles for Harley Davidson, sold the magazine to CBS in 1972. He is survived by his wife, a son, a daughter, a sister and a brother.

Donald A. Burton, an Indiana radio pioneer who started his own station in 1926 in his parents' parlor, died July 24. He was 84. Burton was 20 when he founded WLBC-AM at his parents' Muncie home. He became chairman of the board of Tri-City Communications, which owned WLBC and its sister FM station until DRMS Communications bought them in 1986. Burton added a television station to his holdings in 1953 and sold it to the Ball State University Foundation in 1971, when it became public television station WIPB. He also was a play-by-play sports broadcaster for 40 years. Burton was inducted into the Indiana Journalism Hall of Fame in 1986 and was a past president of the Indiana Association of Broadcasters.

Gerald J. ``Jerry'' Liska, an Associated Press sportswriter in Chicago for 31 years, died July 26 after a long illness. He was 78. Liska was named a sportswriter in the AP's Chicago bureau in 1944 after three years with the news cooperative in Lansing and Ann Arbor, Mich. He retired from the AP in 1975. He was a past president of the Football Writers Association of America. Liska is survived by his wife, a son, a daughter and a sister.
DOC.HEAD: Maxwell Newton
DOC.TEXT: Maxwell Newton, an Australian-born financial writer for the New York Post, died July 23 of a stroke at the age of 61. Newton joined the Post in 1980 after years of work in his native Australia. His columns ranged from frequent attacks on Federal Reserve policy to early predictions of the 1987 stock-market crash. He once appealed to Walt Disney Co. to administer New York City. He is survived by his wife, Valerie, a brother, a son, four daughters and five grandchildren.

Art Seidenbaum, editor of the Los Angeles Times' Opinion section and an Emmy winner for the public television program ``Citywatchers,'' died of cancer at home on July 24. He was 60. Seidenbaum came to the Times as a columnist in 1962 after writing for Life magazine and the Saturday Evening Post. The veteran newsman became editor of the Book Review section in 1978 and Opinion editor in 1985. In 1972, Seidenbaum won an Emmy for ``Citywatchers,'' a KCET program. Times arts editor Charles Champlin was its co-host. He is survived by his wife and five children.
DOC.HEAD: Albert G. Smith
DOC.TEXT: Albert Gray Smith, a former Associated Press writer and public relations executive, died July 23 after a brief illness. He was 77. Smith worked as a reporter and sports writer for the Waycross (Ga.) Journal-Herald and was the University of Georgia's first sports publicity director before joining the AP in Atlanta in 1934. He later served as sports publicity director for Louisiana State University and was a vice president at the public relations firm Carl Byoir & Associates in New York and Toledo, Ohio. He is survived by a sister.

Jules Waldman, founder of Venezuela's English-language newspaper, The Daily Journal, died of a stroke July 25, one month after an armed gang bound him up and looted his home. He was 77. Waldman founded the newspaper in Caracas in 1945. He also wrote articles for Harpers magazine and the New Republic. He helped set up the Venezuelan-American Center, the focus of Caracas' English-language community. He wrote intermittently for The New York Times for about 25 years, and befriended some of Venezuela's presidents. After he was attacked and robbed June 30, he was hospitalized for shock. He contracted pneumonia but seemed on his way to recovery when he suffered the stroke, the Daily Journal reported.
Waldman is survived by his wife, two children and four grandchildren.
DOC.HEAD: Richard Goodman West
DOC.TEXT: Richard Goodman West, who spent more than three decades as a city editor and writer for the New York Herald Tribune, died of cancer July 21. He was 82. West worked for the Herald Tribune, now defunct, from 1929 to 1961. He later taught journalism at the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University. From 1961 to 1972, he was a senior editor for Grolier Inc.'s Encyclopedia Americana. He is survived by his niece and a sister-in-law.

Sarah McClendon, known for her tough questions at presidential news conferences during nearly 50 years of reporting, says she's not ready to quit. ``Being a Texan means you use your individuality and have enough guts and courage to stand out and be a good citizen,'' she said at a July 26 party for her 80th birthday. ``I'm not quitting, because I have a lot of questions I want to ask George Bush.''... Time Warner Inc. has produced two dummy issues for a possible switch of Life magazine from monthly to weekly publication, The Wall Street Journal reports. The dummy issues were done in regular magazine size, rather than Life's current large format, and had editorial content similar to the defunct 7 Days, the Journal says. ... Deborah Norville got a New York taxi driver fined $100 for cursing at her during a ride last December. The co-host of NBC's ``Today'' show told New York magazine she didn't think the driver knew who she was.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: A man rescued Monday 14 days after an earthquake buried him in the basement of a luxury hotel said that while trapped in the darkness he often wished he were dead and even tried to kill himself. Pedrito Dy, a cook and part-time fitness instructor, was the third survivor pulled since Friday from the ruins of the Hyatt Hotel in the northern resort of Baguio. He is one of the longest survivors of an earthquake on record. Dy, 27, was flown to Manila for medical treatment. One doctor, Raul Morena, said Dy's athletic build protected him from serious injury in the July 16 quake that killed about 1,600 people. Doctors said he suffered only from dehydration and low blood sugar, which caused disorientation. Speaking from his hospital bed, Dy said that while trapped he lay on his back beneath a cushion, which protected him from the debris that shifted repeatedly in aftershocks.

As New Hampshire's attorney general in 1976, Supreme Court nominee David Souter submitted a brief in which the state argued against paying for Medicaid abortions and referred to abortion as ``the killing of unborn children.'' In an earlier case, argued in 1972 when Souter was the state's deputy attorney general, New Hampshire defended its strict anti-abortion law against a constitutional challenge by arguing: ``The maintenance of an unborn child's right to birth is a compelling interest which outweighs any rights of a mother to an abortion except when necessary to preserve her life.'' In both cases, the extent of Souter's personal involvement is unclear.
