DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ Garage sales, people unloading the unwanted, have developed into a multimillion-dollar industry. No one has a good handle on the scope of the nation's driveway economy, but there's a whole lot of secondhand retailing going on.

Comedian Phyllis Diller used to cruise garage sales searching for treasures among trash. ``I bought eight guitars at a St. Louis garage sale once,'' she says. ``At that same sale, I bought a blonde wig and I used that as my fright wig in all my shows. Boy, it's ugly.'' Diller and people like her support nation's driveway economy, in which millions of dollars change hands every season. Summer's here and so are garage, tag, rummage and yard sales. Call them what you want. They're put on by people who want to unload the unwanted. Take a look at the classified section of this newspaper. Chances are you'll find a separate listing just for garage sales. Thursday is a big day for newspaper ads since the sales frequently run Friday through Sunday. There's a whole lot of retailing going on. Just ask Chris Stevenson, author of ``Garage Sale Mania: How to Hold a Profitable Garage, Yard or Tag Sale.'' ``There is so much money in this just for a weekend,'' he said from Huntington Beach, Calif. ``It's a multimillion-dollar business.'' Getting an accurate fix on garage-sale revenue is impossible. In Michigan, for example, the state Treasury and Commerce Department doesn't track money changing hands at the sales. All those dusty bicycles, flower vases and sets of three matching glasses aren't subject to state sales tax since they're used items and not sold in a licensed business. To help get an idea of how much money passes through these private flea markets, look at Livonia, a bedroom community of about 105,000 people west of Detroit. Last year, Livonia issued 2,792 garage sale permits at a buck apiece. Forgetting that some sales escaped the permit process, that works out to .03 garage sales per person, per year. Now for the money. The fuzz factor gets kind of heavy here but Stevenson says a typical garage sale nets about $100. That means that garage sales shoppers in Michigan fork over about $28 million a year for other people's junk. That's slightly more than the annual budget for the entire state park system. Take that nationwide, and the driveway economy adds up to about $720 million annually. Where there's money, there's a whole lot of advice on how to deal with it, including some from Diller. A few years ago, she made a videotape called ``How to Have a Moneymaking Garage Sale.'' It's just now being distributed. ``I realized that people were not being efficient,'' she said from Chesaning, Mich., where she was appearing in a play. ``They're good for the environment because you don't throw it away or bury it.'' Some tips from her video: _Check with your insurance company. _Plan on one-tenth of the original price for clothes and one-fifth for working appliances. _For security, never publish a phone number in advertisements. The latest edition of ``Books in Print'' lists four titles beginning with the words ``Garage Sale,'' including Stevenson's. Stevenson says weapons are hot sellers. ``We bought some rifles for $39.95 and re-varnished the stocks and blued the barrels and sold them for $69.95,'' he says. Tools and tool chests, exercise equipment and clothing also do well. Stevenson says mattresses and box springs are losers, as are jigsaw puzzles, which often are incomplete. Inventory arrangement can help at the cash box. Sometimes it's beneficial to arrange male- and female-oriented items on separate tables with gender-neutral items such as luggage in between. Stevenson also has some strategies for people who are serious about becoming garage sale barons like him. Stevenson's brother-in-law got him hooked on other people's castoffs. ``We learned how to run around and buy out other garage sales in a `bid-out,''' he says. ``We would take the total inventory of a sale for a set price. Usually we would do this early in the morning. ``If they refused us, we would hit them early in the afternoon and see if they would take our price, usually lower than in the morning.'' The deals usually were accepted. Garage sale prowlers usually fit into one of four general categories. _The Idly Curious. Fair-weather shoppers, usually traveling in couples, who fork over a dime here or a quarter there. Big spenders they're not. _The Jokesters. The next time you get a gag gift at a birthday party or a family get-together, it probably was picked up at a garage sale by one of these characters. Some considerable money, maybe $5 or so, can be involved in a transaction. _The True Bargain-Hunters. These are a seller's dream. Frequently these are people with REAL money, looking for bicycles or big-ticket baby stuff such as cribs, swings or high chairs. Sometimes they're hunting for true moneymakers such as washing machines and dryers. _The Hard-Core Garage Sale Prowler. The bane of all hosts. These solo shoppers come armed with large bags for little stuff. They'll quibble over a nickel on a 15-cent, one-time family heirloom, unconcerned or oblivious that they're asking for a 33-percent discount. Making money despite deep discounts may be the second-most important factor in evaluating the success of a garage sale. ``It's not the money,'' one garage sale host says. ``It's the cubic yards removed.''
Editor's Note: ``Garage Sale Mania: How to Hold a Profitable Garage, Yard or Tag Sale.'' is published by Betterway Publishing, P.O. Box 219; Crozet, Va., 22932.

DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE _ Carnegie Hall, once doomed to destruction, celebrates its 100th birthday this season. Thank Isaac Stern, the virtuoso violinist who has been president of the New York concert hall for the past 30 years. Rarely has a musician been so closely associated with a place.

To Isaac Stern, Carnegie Hall is a mystical place, the Mount Olympus of American music. For good reason. The storied New York concert hall is where Stern first vaulted into preeminence as a virtuoso violinist. He returned the favor years later by saving Carnegie Hall from oblivion. That was 30 years ago. Today, as Carnegie Hall prepares to celebrate its 100th birthday, Stern reflects on its rich history as the cradle of American culture in the 20th century. ``Carnegie Hall is entwined completely with the artistic, emotional, intellectual, political growth of this country,'' Stern says. ``It's astonishing.'' Carnegie Hall, he adds, ``was the place where you came to prove whether you belonged or not. It has been the crown proving place for every single orchestra, every conductor, every pianist, singer, violinist, cellist. ``You walk in there, you think of all the people who've been there. It's the center from which the entire development of American music came. Nothing happened in this country that didn't come through Carnegie.'' As a performer, the violinist says, ``Carnegie Hall makes a performance larger than life. It's an enormously powerful hall and it does give even average performers a glamour and power they wouldn't have in other halls.'' With its coming 1990-1991 ``blockbuster season,'' Carnegie Hall celebrates its 100th anniversary. Stern, who celebrated his 70th birthday on July 21, says, ``The important thing is to make sure it'll be here for the next 100 years. ``It's something to hold on to, some connection with man's involvement with education, with the quality of civilization.'' As for his own birthday, he says, ``I very honestly feel as if I'm reaching a good time of my middle age. Of course I'd be a little more sure of it if I knew very active people who were 140.'' At a birthday celebration concert in San Francisco, actor Gregory Peck called Stern ``an irresistible one-man cultural force.'' Surely no virtuoso instrumentalist has been as allied with a place as Stern with Carnegie. He'd played in New York twice at Town Hall, receiving mild notices, before performing at Carnegie for the first time, at age 22, in January 1943. Reviews glowed. ``That was the start of the career, really,'' he says. ``From then on, things really took off.'' At home in Manhattan, wearing a short-sleeved shirt on a 90-degree day, his glasses pushed atop his white hair, Stern agrees to pose for a picture holding his Guarneri violin. But he doesn't follow the photographer's suggestion to hug the instrument with crossed arms. ``Unlike a woman, you embrace a violin with great care, not with great abandon,'' he explains. ``It's more like a baby.'' Stern muses that 1943 in Carnegie Hall saw the start of ``the Leonard Bernstein era,'' when the young assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic substituted on short notice for the ailing Bruno Walter. It was the year the Duke Ellington Band played ``Black, Brown and Beige,'' starting Ellington's annual Carnegie concerts, premiering his extended compositions which often expressed racial pride. Stern recalls some of the historic concerts he attended at Carnegie: the great return of pianist Vladimir Horowitz after his absence, the American debut of Soviet violinist David Oistrakh, the last performances of violinist Fritz Kreisler. ``It was clear Kreisler was going to go into retirement at that time. I remember particularly his last orchestral concert. Eugene Ormandy wrapped him in musical cotton to take care of him during that whole performance. It was moving. Touching. Very dear.'' He remembers the time pianist Arthur Rubinstein gave 10 recitals in a row, all of them for charity, Marian Anderson's farewell, Eleanor Roosevelt coming to listen to a high school graduation performance. In 1960, when Lincoln Center was being built and the New York Philharmonic about to move from Carnegie to the new Philharmonic Hall in the new music and theater complex, the plan was to tear down the privately owned Carnegie Hall and build an office tower. Starting with meetings in friends' apartments, Stern began raising money to mount a campaign to save the hall. Did he really think he could save it or was he making a symbolic gesture? ``I never was a Don Quixote,'' Stern says. ``I don't tilt at empty windmills. I was completely convinced I was going to win. If I had been less innocent I might have been afraid of how possible it was to lose. ``I wasn't entirely innocent politically. I knew I had to work politically. ``After we knew we had won the fight and they were drafting the legislation that let the city buy Carnegie Hall, I left as a member of a group to do a tour. While we were in Europe they voted me in as president of Carnegie. I haven't quit yet.'' Being president of Carnegie Hall for 30 years has taken more time than most concert performers would be willing to sacrifice from their musical careers. He hasn't minded, Stern says, ``because the violin gave me the impetus and power to work for Carnegie and that gave me a different set of tensions to make going back to the violin even more pleasurable.'' Stern has long worked to help fledgling musicians. ``Being of service has always seemed very natural to me. I can't give you a reason. I never thought of it as being of service. People have been very nice to me. I've been very fortunate. A long time ago, without being philosophical or creating a credo, I just figured one has been fortunate so one has to give something back. You don't just take. So I do that. ``I'm interested to tell young people why you play, what happens between the notes where the music is made, and to teach teachers how to get excited about how music is part of our lives.'' A movie, ``From Mao to Mozart,'' in which Stern shares music with youngsters in China, won an Oscar for best full-length documentary in 1981. Stern and his wife, Vera, have two sons who are conductors, one married to a violinist, the other engaged to an oboist. Their daughter and her husband, who have three sons, are both rabbis, with synagogues 12 miles apart in New Jersey. ``Vera and the children have helped me always,'' Stern says. ``We're a very close family. We believe in loving and touching and that's a help.''

DOC.TEXT: Don't be surprised if Jane Curtin loses control occasionally in her role as a divorced mother in the NBC fall show ``Working It Out.'' In the pilot for the new Saturday night comedy, which co-stars Stephen Collins, she had wanted to show that she was not reprising her Emmy-winning role from ``Kate & Allie.'' ``It was important for me to show that she was very different from Allie, that she had everything under control,'' she says. ``But the pilot seemed to be too one-note. She was too much in control. ``In the future we'll show that beneath that she's lava _ liquid rock. You'll see her control crumble from time to time. It makes her more human.'' Curtin stars as Sarah Marshall, the divorced mother of a 9-year-old. She isn't looking for any new relationships until she meets David Stuart (Collins) at a cooking class. Stuart is a photographer who has finally gotten his own daughter out of the house and isn't interested in anyone with a young child. Of course, that all goes out the window as they start ``working it out.'' Curtin's last regular character, Allie, had considerably less control of her life. Curtin co-starred with Susan Saint James for five years in ``Kate & Allie.'' Allie was a homebody, with two children, who preferred standing over a hot stove to dating. She was a great cook, who could never get a grip on things, although in the final season in 1988 she got married. This fall, NBC has all half-hour comedies on Saturday, including three new shows. ``Parenthood,'' based on the hit movie, begins the night, followed by ``Working It Out,'' the returning hit shows ``The Golden Girls,'' ``Empty Nest'' and ``Carol & Co.,'' and another new comedy, ``American Dreamer.'' CBS counters with a mixture of comedy, drama and news, while ABC has three one-hour dramas, including ``Twin Peaks'' at 10 p.m. ``Working It Out,'' like ``Kate & Allie'' and ``Saturday Night Live,'' is produced in New York. Other than a few movies, Curtin has worked mostly in New York to be near her husband and daughter. She talked about the show during a brief visit to Los Angeles to promote the series. ``I was looking for a project and was in contact with Bill Persky,'' she said. Persky had been the executive producer of ``Kate & Allie.'' ``He was doing a film, and I thought I should go off and do something different. Then at the last minute we felt we should do something together. He sent me a pilot script he had written, and many lunches and calories later we decided to go with it. Billy didn't write it for me, and originally he only wanted me to look at it. But I liked it and wanted to work with Billy again. ``If you have the same rhythm as Billy and I do, it's the best condition for working. You just fly through. He's very open to suggestions. You never feel inhibited.'' Prior to ``Working It Out,'' Curtin had spent some time developing a comedy news show with Buck Henry and others. ``It would have been like one of those pontifical round-table shows,'' she says. ``We kept trying to get something on as a segment of the Connie Chung show. It didn't work out. That was last November, and every time we did anything the events changed.'' Curtin had been an anchor on Weekend Update on ``Saturday Night Live'' after the departure of Chevy Chase. She had been with The Proposition, an improvisational theater group, before joining ``Saturday Night Live'' in 1975 as an original member of the Not Ready For Prime Time Players. ``The Proposition would occasionally perform on television,'' she says. ``Usually after each performance we'd never be invited back because we'd manage to offend them in some way.'' Curtin reportedly said on leaving ``Saturday Night Live'' that she would never return. Asked if she would ever return for a guest role, she flashes a grin and replies, ``If it were on earlier. Say 9 or 9:30 p.m.'' She left the late-night show in 1980 and went on to continued television stardom. She won two Emmys for her role in ``Kate & Allie.'' She did not achieve the feature film success of such SNL alums as Chase, Dan Aykroyd and John Belushi, and later Billy Crystal, Bill Murray and Eddie Murphy. One of her first movies was ``How To Beat the High Cost of Living,'' which went nowhere. The movie, however, did team her for the first time with Susan Saint James, which may have figured in their pairing later in ``Kate & Allie.'' Garrett Morris, also from ``Saturday Night Live,'' was also in the movie, as was Dabney Coleman, her co-star in the TV movie ``Maybe Baby.'' She starred with Tom Selleck in ``Divorce Wars.'' This past season she played Alice McGoff, a widow with seven children who fought school integration in Boston in the miniseries ``Common Ground.'' That was the first blue-collar role for Curtin and a change of pace. ``It's so hard to hide good breeding,'' she jokes. ``It's a curse.''

DOC.TEXT: Don't look for one-shot guest stars at the Guthrie Theater. No television personalities and movie names brought in for marquee value or to give the box office a boost. The Guthrie is a company of actors _ 23 at last count _ who have made a nearly year-round commitment to the regional theater and its artistic director Garland Wright. That was one of the reasons Wright took the job in the summer of 1986. It was a chance to build a permanent troupe of performers able to jump from Shakespeare to Shaw, from Wilde to Wilder with ease. The classical company's current challenging efforts are good examples of giving actors and audiences a stretch. Three Shakespeare history plays _ ``Richard II,'' ``Henry IV'' and ``Henry V'' _ are being performed in repertory all summer. ``The emphasis in doing these plays was the acting company,'' says Charles Newell, who co-directed the trio of Shakespeare epics with Wright. ``The plays were chosen with the company in mind. We didn't go to New York to get the leads and then cast the secondary parts locally, which has been the case in the past.'' Casting from New York or Los Angeles or Chicago is common practice among a lot of regional theaters. Most performers can't afford a steady diet of regional theater work. ``When actors work mainly on a free-lance basis, they can do a soap opera for maybe 10 weeks at $3,000 a week and then do a play at a regional theater for $300 a week,'' says Edward Martenson, the Guthrie's executive director. ``In other words, the commercial side of their existence is subsidizing the art side,'' he says. ``It's a question of at what level can actors afford to give up that commercial side in order to do what they'd like to do.'' The Guthrie, which has a yearly operating budget of about $9.5 million, has tried to snare actors with two promises most performers can't resist _ good roles and more money. The money is linked to an ambitious $25 million endowment plan, which was started in the spring of 1987 and which Martenson hopes to have closed out by the end of 1991. So far, more than $16 million has been raised, much of it in large gifts from corporations and donations from several individuals. ``Our reasoning was that we could not hope to compete with the resources they have in Hollywood or on Broadway in terms of a weekly salary,'' Martenson says. ``Instead, what we're looking for is the ability of an actor or actress to settle here and make a full-time commitment.'' One actress who has done just that is Brenda Wehle, who plays small roles in ``Henry IV'' and ``Henry V'' and will have a major part in ``The Skin of Our Teeth'' and the title role in ``Medea'' when they open later in the season. Wehle first came to Minneapolis five years ago for five months with a production of Eric Overmyer's ``On the Verge,'' directed by Wright. She was living in Philadelphia at the time and going where she had to _ places such as Hartford, Conn., and Seattle _ for acting jobs. ``Garland called seven months later when I was back in Philadelphia, and he said, `Can you be here in two weeks for longer than five months?''' she recalls. ``I moved out, bought a house with a white picket fence, bought a car _all the dreams you have _ put my two children in school and began as a member of the new company four seasons ago.'' Charles Janasz, who plays Richard II, Ned Poins in ``Henry IV'' and the Dauphin in ``Henry V,'' arrived at the Guthrie last year. He had been in a similar acting company at Arena Stage in Washington and loved it. He also had tried New York and found he had to go out-of-town to get work. ``Unless you're dead set on making a career move into film and television, I see no reason for not moving here unless you like instability,'' he says. ``I'm happy when I'm working, and I'm not happy when I'm not working. So when I was living in New York, the only time I was happy was when I was away from home.'' Other actors in the company came from as far away as across town, local actors Wright has pulled into his troupe. Stephen Yoakam, who plays Bolingbroke in ``Richard II'' and later the title character in ``Henry IV,'' went to college in Minneapolis and, for the most part, stayed. In 1986, the Guthrie had only six actors under contract for a year. But the most any actor could earn then in a full season at the Guthrie was $24,000, Martenson says. ``On that, you can't buy a house, settle down and have a family,'' he says. ``Our objective was to get to an average of $950 a week, which would work out, for a 45-week season, to a little more than $42,000 a year. That would put our highest salary at something like $50,000 for a full-time actor. On that, we feel people can afford to make a full-time commitment to us.'' Those levels haven't been reached yet. ``We've still got two steps to go, phased in over a period of six years,'' Martenson says. ``But the progress that we've made so far and the commitments that we've gotten from people make it clear that the money increase has been a very significant factor.'' The variety and quality of the roles offered these actors have been just as important in compelling them to stay at the Guthrie. ``There's been a steady upward climb in terms of the size of the roles we've been undertaking and the responsibility that has been given to us as members of an ensemble,'' Yoakam says.

DOC.TEXT:
``Blue Steel'' (MGM@UA Home Video. VSH-Beta, $89.98. Rated R)
``Blue Steel,'' the story of a rookie cop in New York City who unwittingly falls in love with a crazed killer, might better be titled ``Aww! Come On!'' after the chorus of incredulous groans it provokes. Viewing this movie is an exercise in good faith gone bad, with scene after unbelievable scene that would force even the most gullible to get annoyed. ``Blue Steel'' revolves around Megan Turner, played by an ever locked-jawed Jamie Lee Curtis, in her quest to become a top cop and maybe even get a date once in awhile. But in one of her first nights on the beat she blows away a grocery store robber in vicious fashion _ emptying a whole round into the guy. Since the robber's gun can't be found, Megan is suspended and told to give her trigger-happy fingers a rest. Enter the embodiment of seductive evil, Eugene Hunt (Ron Silver), who witnessed the shooting and suddenly realizes Megan is a kindred killer spirit. Hunt, a wealthy commodities broker, is the kind of smooth operator who takes his dates out to ritzy restaurants and then up for helicopter rides around Manhattan's glittery night skyline. He wins over the lonely Megan without telling her he saw the robbery and when he's not seducing the lady cop, he's out randomly killing people on the streets of New York. To declare his love for Megan, he scratches her name in the bullets. This brings Megan back on duty, working with a team of homicide detectives who are trying to figure out why the killer is so obsessed with her. What follows is a series of implausible plot developments _ the crack homicide team essentially lets the rookie Megan run the investigation; Hunt, a prime suspect, is never given so much as a powderburn test to determine if he's involved in the spate of murders; and at one point Megan, severely dazed and in shock, is back on the streets to hunt down the killer. Aww! Come on! To its credit, ``Blue Steel'' does have a number of ``boogie-man-in-the- closet'' type thrills _ short bursts of cheaply orchestrated terror. And Silver does a fine job playing the psychotic devil in an Italian suit. His blood lust is so well done he somehow seems to revert to a primal, evil animal state. But in addition to the plot problems, the dialogue is often slow and insipid. Here's an exchange after Megan handcuffs her partner to a car's steering wheel so she can run after the killer by herself: ``I almost got you killed,'' Megan says. ``Yeah, that you did,'' her partner responds, adding, ``you get some rest.'' Aww! Come on!

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Lineage'' (Blue Note) _ Benny Green
Jazz pianist Benny Green is just 27, but he demonstrates a veteran's appreciation and feel for classic jazz and bebop in his first solo title album, ``Lineage.'' Green plays strong and spunky on every selection chosen for this compact disc, from Bobby Timmons' ``Dat Dere'' to Monk's ``Ask Me Now.'' He also stretches his talents from fusion to show tunes. He has included a wonderfully syrupy version of Lerner and Lowe's ``If Ever I Would Leave You,'' and adds a light fusion number of his own called ``Trust,'' although his other three compositions steer closer to classic jazz. Green, who has played with Frank Morgan, Betty Carter and Freddie Hubbard, is backed solidly by bassist Ray Drummond and Victor Lewis on drums. But the album is clearly Green's chance to shine. The selection and order of numbers flow smoothly, making for an impresive first album by an ascending new talent. _ By Thomas Ginsberg, Associated Press Writer.

Carmen Suite; L'arlesienne Suite No. 1; Symphony No. 1, by Georges Bizet (Telarc) _ Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, Jesus Lopez-Cobos, conductor
Oh well, one might say, here are a couple more war horses by a middle-rank orchestra and ambitious conductor. One might also be very much mistaken, because this is a stunning recording. Lopez-Cobos draws out fresh-sounding, vivid and supple performances with beautifully shaped lines and tight rhythmic control. The orchestra glows and the winds play superbly. A worthy compact disc. _ By Daniel Wakin, Associated Press Writer.

Masses No. 2 and 6, by Franz Schubert (Telarc) _ Atlanta Symphony Orchestra & Chorus, conducted by Robert Shaw (Telarc)
Shaw conducts detailed, nicely phrased and well-balanced _ if a little bland _ performances of a good sampling of Schubert's sacred music on this compact disc, generously timed at 77:45. Schubert wrote No. 2 at the age of 17, and it is quite a bit simpler than No. 6, which was composed in the final year of his pathetically short life. The contrast is interesting. In fact, the straight-forward innocence of the earlier work makes it more appealing. The soloists are generally admirable, particularly soprano Dawn Upshaw in No. 2 _ By Daniel Wakin, Associated Press Writer.

``Blazing Away'' (Island Records) _ Marianne Faithfull
This mostly live offering by one of rock's legendary survivors carries a warning label about its lyrics but ought to caution listeners to beware its emotional punch. Twelve of the 13 songs were recorded during two 1989 concerts in a Brooklyn, N.Y., cathedral. In effect, the collection is a musical autobiography of Faithfull, who burst onto the pop scene as a teen-ager in the 1960s, faded away in a heroin haze in the 1970s and returned in the '80s with the critically acclaimed but hard-to-enjoy album ``Broken English.'' I bought ``Broken English'' in 1981, and gave it away not long after, unable to bear the ragged voice that once had sung so sweetly on ``As Tears Go By.'' Faithfull sings ``As Tears Go By'' on ``Blazing Away'' and it is beautiful. Her voice is still harsh but the ache in it feels real and the spare arrangement, featuring an accordion solo by Garth Hudson, gently colors the melancholy mood. The album also contains powerfully moving readings of John Lennon's ``Working Class Hero,'' and the Rolling Stones' ``Sister Morphine,'' a song for which Faithfull wrote the lyrics during her long-ago union with Mick Jagger. Another highlight is the ``Ballad of Lucy Jordan,'' a song of middle-age madness by Shel Silverstein that Faithfull has made one of her signature tunes. Her band on the live numbers boasts, in addition to Hudson, New Orleans piano king Dr. John and guitarist Marc Ribot, who also has played on recent Tom Waits and Elvis Costello recordings. But despite the fine sound and Faithfull's evocative vocals, she's still a difficult act to enjoy. Many of her best songs are downers and the timbre of her voice reveals as much about pain and hard times as the lyrics. There are rewards here, but only for listeners willing to open their minds and drop their preconceptions. _ By David Dishneau, Associated Press Writer.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: How ``Becket'' Launched a Star
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When Julia Roberts was 16, she saw the movie ``Becket,'' the Richard Burton-Peter O'Toole masterpiece about the stormy relationship between King Henry II and Archbishop Thomas Becket, and her future was instantly determined. ``That movie had a more profound effect on me than any I had ever seen,'' she remembers. ``To see performances like the ones Richard Burton and Peter O'Toole deliver, it made me want to be that wonderful _ or, at least really try. ``It set a kind of standard somewhere in the back of my mind, and it was something that in my lifetime I hoped I'd get a moment to achieve. That's real absolute greatness. If I could do that for a second, I'd be a real happy actor.'' At 23, she has come a long way toward achieving that goal, faster than even she had hoped. Amid the gaggle of superstars in ``Steel Magnolias,'' only Roberts was nominated for an Academy Award. Next came ``Pretty Woman,'' as a Hollywood hooker to Richard Gere's takeover tycoon. The movie astounded everyone with a $160 million gross, and still counting. She has a new film coming in August. In ``Flatliners,'' Kiefer Sutherland, Kevin Bacon, William Baldwin and Roberts are medical students who try to probe the afterlife by stopping their vital signs. It's a thriller that scared even the actress. ``It gets the heart pumping.'' So does Robert's beauty. With her long auburn hair, Raphael-like face, wide mouth and all-knowing eyes, she is a stunner, off-screen and on. Add to the look a languorous voice shadowed by her youth in Smyrna, Ga. It's no wonder that she has climbed into the $1 million-per-picture category. ``Pretty Woman'' has no doubt raised the ante. She scoffs at claims she is an overnight sensation. ``It's kind of interesting how they can make five years seem like a long weekend,'' she said. ``It was a road traveled. It wasn't quick, although it came in a way I never anticipated. But I also never predicted the outcome of what I was attempting to do. I just delighted in the opportunities to keep doing it. That's where the real excitement comes from: every time you get a job, you think you get another chance to show something.'' Roberts' career as an actress was determined long before she saw ``Becket.'' Both her parents were actors. Her brother, Eric Roberts, preceded her into films and won an Academy Award nomination for ``Runaway Train.'' Julia admits that she might have enrolled at the University of Georgia, gotten married and become a housewife if she hadn't left Smyrna for New York after high school. She attended acting classes and endless auditions before landing her first role at 18 in a ``Crime Story'' segment. After a few low-budget films, she tried out for ``Mystic Pizza.'' The role called for a Portuguese waitress, so she dyed her hair black. She got the role. She terms ``Mystic Pizza'' a ``nice surprise.'' ``None of us on that movie had really done very much. It was a chance to show somebody something.'' Producer Ray Stark liked what he saw. He planted Julia amid the high-powered women of ``Steel Magnolias'': Sally Field, Shirley MacLaine, Dolly Parton, Olympia Dukakis. The anticipated battle of temperments never developed. ``They were all so available, loving, supportive, giving, tremendously caring women,'' Roberts said. ``I had such an immediate rapport that I never really got a chance to think how scary this might have been or should have been, really. It was just very familiar from the start. ``I never expected the nomination. It's a nice moment where they're saying to you, `We accept you; when you're saying you're an actor, we believe you; we trust that you can do what you say you can do.' That's a momentous honor.'' As to the smash success of ``Pretty Woman,'' Robert said, ``I don't ever look for the results of a piece of work. When I'm working, that's what I'm doing that particular day: trying to make that work within the structure of the piece. I don't take a movie thinking that it's going to end up doing this particular amount of sales or that people will accept it in a certain way. ``You can never know. That's the unpredictable, the reason all kinds of movies are made. If there was a formula for the kind of movies people would go to see, that's the only kind that would be made. I don't dwell on something you can't figure out.'' ``Flatliners'' proposes the theory that another experience exists post-mortem. Roberts goes along with it: ``I think there is. How could it all just turn black? I don't believe that will happen. Something's there.''

The Artists: Restoration Sparks Hope Among Conservators
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The restoration of an abandoned shopping mall to its turn-of-the-century elegance has sparked hopes that other aging architectural gems may be preserved rather than knocked down or allowed to crumble. Galerias Pacifico covers an entire city block along the Florida Street pedestrian walkway that cuts through the heart of Buenos Aires' commercial district. Modeled on Vittorio Emanuele II gallery in Milan, it was a showpiece from its marble halls to glass roof when it opened 100 years ago. ``I remember going there when I was a girl. It was marvelous, wonderful,'' said Nene Martinez Castro, director of Casa F.O.A., a group that redecorates interesting buildings and sells admission tickets to raise money for charity. ``As an adult, I thought it was a glory, and then a shame when it went to waste,'' she said. Galerias Pacifico received a facelift of sorts in the 1940s. Huge frescoes by some of Argentina's most gifted painters _ Spilimbergo, Urruchua, Berni _ were added as decoration around a central dome. But the glass roof was covered by an arch of reinforced concrete. The building eventually was taken over by the state, which tried beginning a decade ago to sell it. Services deteriorated, and discouraged tenants left one by one. In recent years, Galerias Pacifico _ whose well-kept neighbors include the Plaza Hotel, Harrods Department Store and the glittering Naval Officers Club _ became an eyesore of broken windows, sagging marquees and boarded-up entrances. It was home no longer to boutiques for leather, fur, toys and books, but to pigeons, rats and decrepit men and women with no other place to call their own. This capital city of 10 million has a lot of buildings that date back to when beef and grain exports made Argentina one of the richest countries in the world, and money was lavished on homes, offices, plazas and boulevards. Retiro train station, inaugurated in 1915, was inspired by London's Victoria Station. The facade of La Prensa, once the biggest newspaper in Latin America, recalls the Paris Opera. Many buildings boast Art Deco touches such as columns molded in the shape of giants who appear to sustain the structures on shoulders and backs of bulging muscle. Others have towering lobbies of Italian marble, stairways of German oak, elevators with wrought iron grillwork and wooden benches, interior patios with statues and fountains, windows big enough to stand in, balconies, turrets, gables, cupolas. The central hall of the National Library is lined by bookcases of polished wood that stretch up several stories to a dome that allows in enough light to read by. Such buildings ``add to a city's culture, a city's affluence ... its spirit,'' said architect Elizabeth Kries. ``I'm not against new things ... but there are some buildings that have values you should not lose.'' While pleasing to the eye, such buildings often are drafty, awkward to organize and deficient in plumbing, heating, air conditioning and access for the handicapped. The library, train station and La Prensa are in advanced states of deterioration. When owners of other buildings were faced with finally doing something, many concluded in the 1960s and '70s that it was easier to tear down than remodel. ``Everyone believed modern was better,'' Kries said. ``The United States put a man on the moon. ... People saw old buildings as old things, old ideas. They didn't appreciate them.'' Such thinking has begun to change. Casa F.O.A. last year redesigned an abandoned textile factory into spacious loft apartments that helped start a trend. Plans are afoot to do the same with warehouses along Buenos Aires' decaying waterfront. Another group converted a derelict central market into an open-air theater whose first production was Federico Garcia Lorca's ``Bodas de Sangre'' (``Blood Wedding''). When it bought the Alzaga Unzue Palace in downtown Buenos Aires several years ago, the Hyatt corporation reportedly intended to demolish the 76-year-old mansion. Now, company officials plan to use it as a lobby for what will be a five-star hotel. Jose Maria Pena, director of the City Museum and a conservator who helped draft zoning laws to protect old buildings, said it's too soon to say if all that amounts to a trend. ``In general, builders still think it's easier to take down a building and put up something new.'' he said. But Pena added, ``There are a lot of examples of restorations and ... there is a trend of people wanting to live in old buildings that have more space and privacy.'' And buildings that look a little more distinguished. ``A majority of buildings built in the 1960s and '70s ... have prematurely aged,'' said Pena. ``They look more worn out than buildings built at the turn of the century that wear their age with dignity.''

Music Makers: Sean Penn's Big Brother
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Michael Penn carries the heaviest of show business burdens _ family connections. And when one of your relatives has a reputation as a hotheaded bully, the load of expectations doesn't get much lighter. The older brother of actors Sean and Christopher Penn has caught the public's attention with his debut album ``March,'' a collection of songs about failed relationships set to a folksy sound that has been compared to the Beatles. At 30, Penn knows a thing or two about failure. He's now coming into his own after 12 years of trying to land a record deal. After graduating from Santa Monica High School, Penn spent seven years kicking around the Los Angeles club scene with a band called Doll Congress. At the same time, his former sister-in-law, Madonna, was becoming the pop sensation of the 1980s. ``I know that I may be possibly too patient of a person. We kept getting so close to getting a deal where labels were interested and giving us money to go into the studio. It never happened, and yet we still stayed together because it was enough of an encouragement to keep plugging away,'' he said. ``I think it was when I came to the realization that I was not completely happy with the way things were going that it finally broke up.'' Penn departed the band in 1987 and took keyboardist Patrick Warren with him. The pair met when Warren answered a newspaper advertisement placed by Penn. ``Patrick showed up to audition with a keyboard that didn't work, and so the audition was basically us just talking,'' he said. Their collaboration peaked in Penn's four-track home studio, where he wrote the songs that eventually would end up on ``March.'' He turned the results over to his manager, who brought the tape to the attention of RCA. ``Unlike every other time where there was like a lot of anticipation around a tape, this time I just sort of said, `Here's some new stuff. I'm going to go back and work on some more stuff, do with it what you will.' In a couple of weeks, we started to get phone calls,'' he said, unfolding a tobacco-filled bandana to roll cigarettes. ``No Myth,'' the album's first single, rose to No. 13 on the charts, and the video received major exposure on Music Television. Two other singles, ``This and That'' and ``Brave New World,'' have received extensive airplay. ``I sort of smiled the most about the fact that it popped its head into all different formats. There were people in all these little camps that responded to it, which I thought was kind of cool,'' said Penn, whose casual attire of a tank top, blue jeans and cowboy boots kept him out of a restaurant's dining room during a recent dinner. The album's title doesn't have anything to do with the month of March either. ``It was a realization while making the record that I have this subconscious tendency to write marches. I'm not sure why, but a lot of the beats on the record just felt like a march beat,'' he said. ``I think there's a lot of humor in the album. It's not something I really think about; it's just the way the songs come out. Certain lines make me laugh.'' Penn managed to keep his sense of humor during the 12 years he waited for his big break. ``I was fully prepared to keep working the day jobs that were going nowhere to house and feed me to keep making music.'' One of his worst jobs was as a customer service representative for a photography company that specialized in shooting debutante balls. ``My job was answering phones and talking to the parents of these debutantes down South who were telling me the photographs didn't look like their daughters _ she wasn't that overweight or whatever,'' he recalled with a chuckle. Eventually, he was fired. ``What got to my boss was my creative working hours. I kind of wandered in a little after the first coffee break.'' Despite his resemblance to Sean, it's the family name that brings up the comparisons and inevitable jokes about his brother. Instead of getting mad, though, Penn admits to a perverse pleasure in seeing the frustration of reporters who want to fuss about his bloodlines. ``What's been interesting to me is that a lot of the press gets frazzled by the fact that they couldn't make an issue out of it. The fact that it wasn't an issue became the issue they wrote about because they had to find some way to include it,'' he said. Even David Letterman couldn't resist. Penn sat down to chat in his second appearance on the show and immediately got zinged. ``So, how old were you when Sean threw his first punch?'' Letterman teased as Penn managed a half-smile. ``Letterman knew it was just a stupid comment and that's kind of his job,'' he said. Penn says his family has rallied together in the face of a hostile celebrity press and public. His father, Leo, is a veteran television director and his mother, Eileen Ryan, is an actress. ``I don't think you can be Irish, Italian and Jewish without being a close family,'' he said. He hasn't ruled out the possibility of having his father direct him in a video. And his youngest brother is singing, too. ``Lately, Christopher has been doing a lot of blues singing, which is actually kind of cool. He's got a great whiskey voice, and he's pretty good at it.'' While the rest of the family was acting, Penn was busy practicing guitar licks in the garage with his first band in junior high. ``I knew I wanted to do music when I was 8 years old. The songs are the things that appeal to me most about music,'' he said, alternating a bite of curried chicken with a drag on another cigarette. ``That's what I did as a kid. I never got into sports or anything else. I just bought records and played guitar,'' he said. ``I'm actually glad that I didn't get signed until I was 29. If I had to live with a legacy of records of the music I was writing when I was in my early 20s, I would probably get embarrassed.'' Penn began the summer as Tears for Fears' opening act in a tour of outdoor venues. This month, he'll wrap up the club tour with Lloyd Cole that brought him to Indianapolis. He's got half the songs written for his next album, and he and Warren might head out on an acoustic tour in October. His biggest exposure yet may come this fall at a music festival in the Baltic republic of Estonia. ``The whole thing has basically taken me by surprise. I just kind of felt lucky to have gotten a deal. I just really wanted it to sell enough so I could make another one,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: John Edgar Wideman Sees MOVE as Metaphor
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: ``Forget the fire,'' a character says in John Edgar Wideman's new novel. ``Play with fire you know what happens. You'll get burnt like the rest of us.'' Wideman, not known for sticking to safe topics, can't forget the 1985 MOVE confrontation that killed 11 people and destroyed a Philadelphia neighborhood. ``I don't think it's something that should be put to rest,'' he said in a telephone interview from his home in Amherst, Mass. ``I think it should be kept alive, and used creatively, no more than the Holocaust should be put to rest.'' The acclaimed author of ``Brothers and Keepers'' and ``Sent for You Yesterday'' makes his case in ``Philadelphia Fire,'' scheduled for September release by Henry Holt. The MOVE confrontation becomes a complex metaphor for black America, urban decay, love, power and justice. In the unconventional, earthy narrative, Wideman alludes to the slave trade, Shakespeare's Caliban, the birth of the blues and the drumbeat call of a basketball game in a West Philadelphia park. The book's central character searches for a survivor of the fire, but finds a reflection of himself instead. The narrator's son is in prison, as is Wideman's, though the author said the account is not strictly autobiographical. ``All these characters merge,'' he said. ``They flow in and out.'' Wideman and his wife, Judy, lived during the late 1960s on Osage Avenue, two miles from where the MOVE radicals later spent a year harassing their middle-class black neighbors and broadcasting obscenities and calls for revolution from a public address system day and night. The narrator of ``Philadelphia Fire'' registers shock when he learns police bombed the radicals' fortified row house May 13, 1985, and let a neighborhood burn in a bungled eviction attempt. The narrator thinks he's looking at a war zone or ``a Third World shantytown where there's no water, no machines to extinguish a fire,'' when the scene erupts on television. Wideman felt similar shock when he learned of the conflagration, he said in the interview. He had played basketball with people in the neighborhood and wondered how the crisis evolved. ``Something in a way had been done to me,'' he said. ``Something had been done to my past. As I learned more about the MOVE people, I recalled also that if I didn't know those particular people, I knew people like them. People who were around me. People who had been dropouts, who had been radicals in the '60s. People who had given up on the system in the '60s, black and white.'' At the same time, he said, he shared the feelings of people who had been subjected to abuse by MOVE members. ``I have great sympathy and understanding of them, because that's more or less the kind of world I come from,'' he said. ``They're my people.'' The fact that Philadelphia had a black mayor, W. Wilson Goode, made the story more complex, he said. ``That's another factor in the whole situation that made it worth writing about, worth attempting to get to the core of,'' he said. ``First of all, it was a little confusing, another source of anger. `How could he do that? How could one of us do that to us?' That was my immediate response, my visceral response. It became clear as I learned more and more that the mayor was in a sense a victim like everybody else.'' In the fictional account, there is just one survivor instead of two. And the leader of a ``family'' similar to MOVE is called King, not John Africa. Cudjoe, the central character, returns to his native Philadelphia from Greece to search for the survivor, a boy named Simba. In an exchange with Margaret Jones, a former follower of King, he explains he wants to write a book about the fire, its cause and meaning. ``Don't need a book,'' she says. ``Anybody wants to know what it means, bring them through here. Tell them these bombed streets used to be full of people's homes. Tell them babies' bones mixed up in this ash they smell.'' Cudjoe's response: ``I want to do something about the silence.'' Wideman said in the interview he believes people have tried to forget MOVE out of fear. He recalled a Quaker memorial service he attended to which the mayor, governor, president, police and others had been invited. No officials showed up and just a handful of ``the convinced,'' he said. ``For it to be buried that way means that nobody really could understand the application, what's at stake,'' he said. ``Everybody's individuality and hope for any kind of decent life is at stake. All citizens of Philadelphia. Because if MOVE can be wiped out today, who tomorrow?'' The MOVE confrontation offers a special historical insight, Wideman said. ``It's not an isolated event,'' he said. ``To me, it's the culmination of the '60s. It's our society's, our culture's answer to the question, `What do you do with people who are different?''' When the mainstream is confronted by something as different as MOVE, democracy is tested, he said. ``MOVE people were in lots of ways (part of the) '60s, alienated, turning away from the system, reacting against excesses of big business, corporations, governments. But this was 20 years later. ... So what do you do with them? Well, smash them, murder them, because there was no room for the option that they hold.'' The story also concerns fathers and sons, a topic of poignancy for Wideman whose brother, Robert, and son, Jacob, are in prison for murder. The narrator meditates on a legal system that he says allows his son to rot in confinement without treatment for mental illness. Wideman declined to answer questions about Jacob. The victim's parents have sued the author for damages. Jacob also has confessed to a separate murder in Wyoming. But ``Philadelphia Fire'' suggests the anguish Wideman has felt as it describes the difficulty of telephone conversations between a father and his imprisoned son. ``I've learned the hard way that I've always known next to nothing about him,'' the narrator says. ``Except I do know the danger of the place where he's incarcerated, the depth of the trouble he's in, the innocence and terror and guilt he must cope with day after day and little on the horizon but more of same.'' The narrator later says, ``A child lost cancels the natural order, the circle is broken.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Aug. 10-12

DOC.HEAD: Adv10-12
DOC.NOTE: For Release Weekend Editions, Aug. 10-12, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Nashville Sound: Billy Joe Royal Hits Four Decades
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Billy Joe Royal marvels that he can still sing his hit record ``Down in the Boondocks'' in the same key as he did in 1965. ``Some other singers who've been around as long as me have dropped down a step,'' Royal says. Royal was a rock 'n' roll star in the 1960s with such hits as ``Down in the Boondocks,'' ``I Knew You When,'' ``Cherry Hill Park'' and ``Hush.'' He kept singing through the '70s and '80s and had recording contracts much of the time. And now that the 45-year-old is going into his fourth decade behind the mike, he has established a solid career in country music and even recently received his first gold record. ``I was stubborn,'' he says. ``I just thought I had something left to say. Plus, I thought there was a place for me in country music.'' In the past five years, his country hits include ``Love Has No Right,'' ``Burned Like a Rocket,'' ``I'll Pin a Note on Your Pillow,'' ``It Keeps Right on a Hurtin''' and this summer's ``Searchin' for Some Kind of Clue.'' His first gold album, for sales of 500,000, was ``The Royal Treatment.'' ``In my era, in the '60s, if you sold 50,000-100,000 albums that was a big album,'' Royal said reflectively in his Music Row office. ``This album was a milestone for me.'' His recent resurgence marks a remarkable comeback after a lean period in the late '70s and early '80s. Although he continued to sing, he was away from the national limelight and at times was reduced to performing in hotel lounges. ``You're sitting in a lounge just a few years after singing at the Greek Theater,'' he recalled. ``You wonder what happened.'' His explanation is that ``records became group oriented, then acid rock came along. I didn't understand all that.'' He sang in enough lounges and clubs to pay his bills at home in Marietta, Ga., and periodically visit Nashville looking for a decent recording contract. ``I used to stay at a motel (outside of town) because it was just $20 a day and I could make my money last longer,'' Royal said. ``I could have picked up the phone and got work, but the level I was on ...'' He finally signed with Atlantic Records, the fourth major label of his career, and moved comfortably into the country music market. ``It's not something foreign to me,'' he said. ``I knew as much about country as anything.'' One key to his recent success has been four top-rated music videos _ a part of the music business unheard of in his earlier performing years. ``It means a lot to put a face with the music,'' Royal said. ``And people saw that I wasn't 112 now, using a walker.'' These days he's on concert bookings with country kings such as George Strait and Alabama. In the 1960s, he was a member of Dick Clark's Cavalcade of Stars, appearing with acts such as Herman's Hermits and Paul Revere and the Raiders. ``I felt like a fan on the bus,'' he said, reminiscing about his first months as a rock 'n' roll star. ``It all happened in six weeks' time.'' The centerpiece was ``Down in the Boondocks,'' a song still heard on oldies radio stations and to this day the closing song at his concerts. It's about a poor young man in love with a rich girl. ``I guess people related to poor people,'' he said about the tune's appeal. ``Plus the sound of it was different. We cut it on a three-track machine _ the most primitive thing in the world. How it sounded like a record, I don't know. ``Once in a while I hear it on the radio, and it still stands up. The song meant everything to my career. I was making about $125 a week before that.'' Royal, a native of Valdosta, Ga., doesn't listen much to rock 'n' roll music anymore. But he did like the recent hit songs ``The Living Years'' by Mike + the Mechanics and ``Talk It Over'' by Grayson Hugh. ``I listen to country stations and oldies stations and some gospel stations,'' he said. In view of his recent success, he says he plans to keep plugging away on stage and on record. Five decades is within reach. ``They are going to have to carry me off. As long as somebody shows up, I'll be there.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Aug. 10-12

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
At the Movies: ``The Unbelieveable Truth'' and ``Flatliners''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds new new material in review for ``The Unbelievable Truth'' following 11th graf, ``The film is...,'' to add rating and producer. ``The Unbelieveable Truth'' has opened in New York and opens in 10 additional cities on Aug. 3 adding others through the month; ``Flatliners'' opens Aug. 10
DOC.TEXT: ``The Unbelieveable Truth'' _ ``The Unbelieveable Truth,'' made for a whopping $200,000, is a relative bargain in this summer of million-dollar adventures. It's a debut film, irreverent and unpredictable, but less self-assured when it tries to get serious. The movie was written and directed by Hal Hartley, who graduated from the film school of the State University of New York at Purchase in 1984, and is a pretty irreverent sort himself: He raised some of the money by telling the bank he was buying a word processor. The actors are all virtually new to film, and shooting _ on location at Lindenhurst, Long Island _ took just 11{ days. Josh Hutton (Robert Burke) is released from prison after serving time _ we're told _ for raping and killing a girl and then killing her father. Dressed in black, the soft-spoken Josh is continously mistaken for a priest and must admit, instead, that he's merely a mechanic, and a prison mechanic at that. When Josh isn't working on cars, he's discussing life with Mike, a fellow mechanic, heavy metal guitarist and self-styled philosopher. ``You start cleaning yourself a lot better,'' Mike says about what happens to a man when he has a girlfriend. ``Suddenly, you're buying underwear up the whazoo.'' Audry Hugo (Adrienne Shelly) is a doe-eyed high school senior who spends much of her free time thinking about nuclear war. Her parents want her to go to college but the way Audry sees it, ``We'll all be lucky to be alive in September.'' Josh and Audry meet after Audry's father gives him a job at his local garage; Josh may be a mass murderer but he's the only who knows how to fix a foreign car. Audry has dumped her nerdy boyfriend after he greets her one morning in a jacket and tie, and she is immediately attracted to Josh. There are, of course, other complications. Audry's father (Christopher Cooke) objects to the relationship, offering Josh a raise in return for leaving her alone. And Audry, unable to get Josh to sleep with her, leaves Lindenhurst to pursue a modeling career. Hartley shows a nice touch for deadpan humor, and as black comedy, the film works. Cooke is especially funny, ranting and fuming like a stressed-out Ward Cleaver, ready with a parental cliche for all occasions. The director also takes full advantage of the low budget, even switching from one scene to the next by showing a flash card that reads, ``Meanwhile.'' But Audry's reflections on nuclear war wear thin and Hartley's message about ``emotional capitalism,'' the way relationships are conducted like business, seems forced. The film is simply too detached to make anyone really worry about the characters' achieving emotional truth. After all, they'll be lucky to be alive in September. ``The Unbelievable Truth'' was produced by Hartley and Bruce Weiss, with Jerome Brownstein as executive producer. The film is rated R for language and adult situations. _ By Hillel Italie, Associated Press Writer.

``Flatliners'' _ No, ``Flatliners'' is not a movie about pioneer farmers scrabbling for a living on the limitless Midwest plains. The flat line referred to in the title is that oscillograph, much used in hospital scenes, that indicates vital signs. When the line goes flat, the lights are out. Kiefer Sutherland is an ambitious medical student obsessed with learning what lies beyond the flat line. ``Philosophy failed, religion failed, now it's up to physical science,'' he propounds. Sutherland's messianic zeal wins over three fellow students: Julia Roberts, William Baldwin and Oliver Platt. A more reluctant Kevin Bacon agrees to go along. In an abandoned part of the university hospital, they rig up a lab Dr. Frankenstein wished he'd had. Starting with Sutherland they wander into the twilight zone. What they discover is not the stairway to paradise, but scary reminders of their past transgressions. The demons pursue them after their return to life. In less able hands, ``Flatliners'' might be an overwrought exercise in science fiction. Thanks to Joel Schumacher's astute direction and ingenious production design, the film is a heart-grabber. Schumacher (``Cousins'') has an expert feel for the macabre, and he makes good use of the vitality of his young cast. Rarely has the look of a film proved so important. Eugenio Zanetti has created a world where sunlight rarely enters. The gothic murals and sculpture of the crumbling hospital, full of skulls and death masks, provide the perfect backdrop for the bizarre goings-on. Peter Filardi's script is brilliantly inventive, even if logic flies out with ghosts of things past. James Newton Brown's music contributes inestimably to the somber mood. Although Kiefer Sutherland is the dominant figure, the five leading roles are almost equal. Julia Roberts is not merely a pretty woman but a convincing actress as well. Kevin Bacon asserts his rightful position as a character actor of real strength. As the girl-chasing charmer, William Baldwin exhibits the star quality of his brother, Alec. Rotund Oliver Platt has the best lines as the wry conscience of the reckless quintet. The Columbia picture was produced by Michael Douglas and Rick Bieber. Rated R for language and scariness. Running time: 111 minutes. _ By Bob Thomas, Associated Press Writer.

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Shanghai Stock Market to Open in December
DOC.TEXT: China's first full-fledged stock market since the Communist takeover will open in Shanghai in December, a newspaper report said Monday. The port city will begin operating a national securities exchange in a new building equipped with computer terminals linked to trading counters inside the city and around the country, Shanghai's official Liberation Daily reported. Shanghai Mayor Zhu Rongji, during a recent visit to the United States, told the Los Angeles Times that the new exchange would first concentrate on government securities and later develop trading in shares of Shanghai companies. He said the city planned to lift a ban on foreign purchases of shares ``very soon'' and to allow foreign-owned banks, which now are restricted to settling foreign currency accounts, to handle deposits and loans. Shanghai, which had one of Asia's largest stock exchanges before the 1949 Communist takeover, opened a small stock trading counter in 1989 for cash purchases and sales as well as resales of government bonds. The exchange, which is capitalized at 50 million yuan, or $10.6 million, remains small because most shares rest with enterprises and securities houses that rarely trade their holdings.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 17.57 points to 2,880.94 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by nearly 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 246 up, 710 down and 468 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: Number of Working Rigs Plunges by 26
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States dropped by 26 this week to 996, according to a widely-watched index of drilling activity released Monday. Baker Hughes Inc., the oil toolmaker, said that despite the plunge, the figures remained well above the 870 working rigs a year ago. Last week, the number of working rigs was 1,022, up 21 from the previous week. Baker Hughes' rig count reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. The company has kept track of the rig count since 1940. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, Louisiana posted the largest decline, losing 10 rigs for the week. Other states reporting losses were Oklahoma, down nine; Wyoming, down seven; Pennsylvania and Kansas, which each lost three; and New Mexico and North Dakota, each of which lost one rig. Of states reporting gains for the week, Colorado had the largest increase, adding five rigs. Among other states with gains, Michigan jumped by three rigs; California added two and Ohio increased by one rig. The number of rigs in Texas remained unchanged for the week.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Spending Jumps 1.0 Percent, Personal Incomes Rise 0.4 Percent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 6th graf, Americans' savings ... to change ``rose'' to ``fell''. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Consumer spending jumped 1.0 percent in June, the largest gain in five months, while personal incomes rose 0.4 percent, the government said today. The Commerce Department said consumer spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.64 trillion after being unchanged in May. It was the biggest advance since a similar 1.0 percent increase in January. Consumer spending is considered a barometer of economic health since it accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Spending has been weak in recent months. The Commerce Department reported earlier this month that retail sales rose 0.5 percent in June, the first increase since last January. The department reported last week that personal spending fell 0.3 percent during the three months ending June 30. Personal income totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.63 trillion following identical 0.3 percent gains in April and May. Americans' savings rate _ savings as a percent of disposable income _ fell to 4.9 percent. It had been 5.4 percent in May and 5.1 percent in April. A higher savings rate means less dependence on foreign capital since funds thus would be available domestically for business investment. The report said Americans' income after taxes increased 0.5 percent, up from 0.3 percent a month earlier. The key component of the income category _ wages and salaries _ rose $13.0 billion after a $10.1 billion increase in May. On the spending side, the increase in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, rose $34.5 billion, including $9.6 billion for durable goods expected to last more than three years. It was the first increase in durable goods spending since January. A Commerce Department spokesman said automobile sales accounted for a large share of the gain. Non-durable goods spending rose $8.2 billion for the first advance since February, while spending for services advanced $16.7 billion, the largest jump since a $20.4 billion increase in March.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Near-term soybean futures were slightly higher while grain futures were a little lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. The soybean market was rebounding modestly after last week's sharp decline. But analysts said the week's weather outlook for the Midwest _ mild temperatures and above-average rainfall _ remained bearish for soybean and corn prices. The National Weather Service's 30- and 90-day outlooks, which were issued Friday, also predicted favorable weather for Midwestern crop development. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., traced some of the support in the soybean futures to high soybean prices at Gulf of Mexico delivery points. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 1\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.97{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1} cents lower with September at $2.61 a bushel; oats were { cent to 1} cents lower with September at $1.29 a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents lower to 1\ cents higher with August at $5.86 a bushel. Cattle futures were narrowly mixed while pork futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .12 cent lower to .07 cent higher with August at 77.90 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent lower to .10 cent higher with August at 89.07 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .58 cent higher with August at 60.02 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .58 cent to 1.83 cents higher with August at 50.30 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Withdraws From UAL Buyout: Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, ``Greenwald declined ... with 5 new grafs to include spokesman's comments; DELETES now outdated 12th graf: ``A call ...
DOC.TEXT: Chemical Banking Corp., one of five banks that expressed interest in financing the $4.38 billion employee buyout of UAL Corp., has opted out of the deal for now, a newspaper reported today. The bank's withdrawal less than two weeks before a deadline to secure financing for the deal was described as temporary and subject to change, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing sources it did not identify. UAL is the parent of United Airlines. Ken Herz, a Chemical spokesman in New York, would neither confirm nor deny the report when reached by telephone this morning. ``We just don't comment on deals that are in negotiation,'' he said. Hank Krakowski, spokesman for United Employees Acquisition Corp. _ the entity formed by United's unions to handle the buyout _ also declined comment. The group has until Aug. 9 to secure financing. Earlier this month Chemical and four other New York-based banks _ Citicorp, Chase Manhatten Corp., Bankers Trust New York Corp. and Manufacturers Hanover Corp. _ expressed interest in becoming the lead lenders for the deal. The banks had been expected to offer about $500 million each, or a total of $2.5 billion. The unions need more than $4 billion to complete the cash portion of the $201-per-share buyout, refinance existing debt and provide working capital for the airline. Gerald Greenwald, who would become United's chairman if the buyout is completed, told the Journal the group is close to agreement to obtain additional debt financing from some of United's aircraft and engine suppliers. Greenwald declined to comment on Chemical Banking's reported withdrawal, but told the Journal the financing talks likely ``will go all the way to the wire.'' Steven Matthews, a spokesman for Greenwald, would not confirm nor deny the report about Chemical Banking when reached this morning at his New York office. Matthews said a number of issues remain to be resolved before the Aug. 9 deadline, but he predicted the deal would be completed in time. ``Not only are we trying to work them out, but we're trying to work them out under a very tight deadline,'' Matthews said. ``We have not requested an extension'' of the deadline, he said. The deadline was set in the merger agreement the unions signed with UAL's board of directors in April. The lack of extra equity investment so far was one of the reasons for Chemical's decision, the newspaper said, citing a source it did not identify. A previous employee takeover effort ended when the group failed to secure financing last October.

DOC.HEAD: Control Data Completes Sale of Printed Circuits Operation
DOC.TEXT: Control Data Corp., said Monday it has completed the sale of its Printed Circuits Operation for an undisclosed price. The business is being sold to Acsist Associates Inc., a privately held company whose principal shareholders are Carl V. Reynolds, former manager of manufacturing technology and operations at ETA Systems, a Control Data subsidiary that was shut down last year, and Frank H. Voigt, former partner in the Dorsey and Whitney law firm in Minneapolis. Acsist Associates will continue to supply Control Data's requirements for complex printed circuit boards, Control Data said. It also will market its products and services to commercial and military customers with certain needs. Reynolds said the operation will remain in its St. Louis Park location and all 128 employees will be employed by Acsist Associates. Control Data said the Printed Circuits Operation had revenues of $11 million in 1989. Control Data provides data solutions that integrate hardware, software, and services to meet customers' data collection, processing and communications needs.
