DOC.HEAD: First Saturn Rolled Off Assembly Line
LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: The ceremonial first Saturn automobile was driven off the Spring Hill assembly line today by Roger Smith, the retiring chairman of General Motors Corp., the automaker announced. In a ceremony that was closed to the news media, Smith drove the car off the line at 10:57 a.m. local time, accompanied in the metallic red, four-door ``Job One'' sedan by Owen Bieber, president of the United Auto Workers union. Smith, whose retires Tuesday, was followed in ``Job Two'' by incoming GM Chairman Robert Stempel. They were joined by GM executive vice president Lloyd E. Reuss and UAW Region 8 Director George H. Smith, plus Saturn President Richard G. LeFauve. ``Today's milestone signals both the determination and enthusiasm of Saturn team members to achieve our mission _ to market a high value, world-class quality car which will compete in the small car market against the best of the Japanese competition,'' LeFauve said. ``Production is coming on line, retail facilities are under construction, and we can't wait to get to the marketplace this fall,'' he said. He said the ceremony was private because of Saturn's plans to focus national attention on the car's launch this fall. He said it also provided a chance for team members to talk with Smith. The public in October will get its first authorized look at the Saturn line, GM's first new nameplate since Chevrolet joined up in 1917. GM has tried to cloak the Saturn project in secrecy since its inception eight years ago. Pictures and details about the Saturn project have leaked, prompting GM to offer a reward at one point for information about the leaks. Smith introduced the project in 1983 as a boxlike subcompact car that would sell for $6,000 to $8,000. GM planned to challenge Japanese imports with a peppy, 60-mpg small car. Early plans called for a production capacity of 500,000 cars a year. Today's Saturn has more interior room, a longer wheel base and more features. It now is aimed to compete with the Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla _ with a $10,000 to $12,000 price tag and a smaller 35-mpg rating. Saturn employees call themselves ``team members,'' a reminder of the new labor-management system at the sprawling plant 35 miles south of Nashville. Production workers operate under a separate contract from that being negotiated by the UAW and the Big Three automakers. Only 120,000 cars a year will be built at first, with a peak production level of 240,000 a year. Saturn now is producing three models _ the two-door 2+2, a basic four-door and a more expensive four-door _ but could expand the lineup in the future. LeFauve said.

DOC.HEAD: Layoffs, First-Half Losses For French Computer Firm
DOC.TEXT: The French computer firm Groupe Bull SA announced Monday plans to cut 3,000 jobs during 1990 and said losses for the first six months this year were three times larger than in the same period in 1989. The troubled computer maker said in a statement it would lay off 3,000 workers to streamline manufacturing and research operations in North America, Ireland and France. The state-owned company predicted earlier this year that only 1,200 layoffs would be necessary. Bull said losses from January through June 1990 totaled 1.88 billion francs, or $355 million, up from a loss of 537 million francs in the first half of 1989. The latest loss stemmed in part from Bull's acquisition of the data-processing units of Zenith Electronic Corp. last year, the company said. Consolidated revenue rose to 15.9 billion francs, or $2.8 billion, in the first half from 14.0 billion francs in the same period in 1989. Bull's loss comes amid a general downturn among mainframe-computer makers. Standardization has cut demand for costly proprietary systems and has sliced profit margins for companies that haven't adapted. The French concern said earlier this year that it planned to cut 1,200 jobs from its work force to cope with the slowdown and changes in the industry. Bull said sales picked up in June after declining for five straight months and noted it normally earns about 60 percent of its revenue in the second half of the year. The company posted a loss of 267 million francs in 1989, following a profit of 303 million francs the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: Otis Enters Joint Agreement With Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Otis Elevator Co. has signed an agreement with a Soviet company to make, install and maintain elevator equipment in the Soviet Union, the company said Monday. ``This agreement strengthens Otis' leadership position in the elevator industry worldwide by establishing a partnership in the important Soviet market,'' Otis President Karl Krapek said in a statement. The Soviet company, Shcherbinka Lift Plant, is a unit of Liftmash, the national agency responsible for making elevators. The new company will be called Shcherbinka Otis Lift. Otis, the world's largest elevator company, will own 55 percent and Shcherbinka 45 percent. A new facility is being built at the existing Shcherbinka Lift Plant near Moscow to produce elevator equipment for offices and small hotels for the Soviet domestic market. Otis will provide manufacturing equipment, management personnel and training for Soviet workers. ``This joint venture, which was organized with the active involvement of Liftmash, will give Otis a manufacturing presence in the Soviet Union, enabling us to participate more fully in this large and growing market,'' said Pierre Fougeron, president of Otis European and Transcontinental Operations. Otis is a wholly owned subsidiary of United Technologies Corp., which is based in Hartford.

DOC.HEAD: Dealing With a Big Mac Attack
DOC.TEXT: The professor was very hungry for a hamburger, but then, as sometimes happens to professors, he reached into his pocket and found no money. He would have to do without. He didn't think it was fair. Just a few minutes before, he had paid for a doctor's visit with a credit card, receiving in return a bill marked ``paid in full.'' His health insurance company would reimburse him. He mused: ``If I had hamburger insurance I would not have this problem. I could have had my hamburger, already eaten it, without a dime in my pocket.'' He thought the idea had promise. ``Everyone eats hamburgers,'' he thought. And so, with tongue in the cheek where he had hoped to have a hamburger, he devised a plan to allow all Americans in need of a patty to have one. Free and open access to hamburgers! ``A rather basic right,'' he mused. The professor, an economist named William Dunkelberg, who also is dean of the School of Business and Management at Temple University in Philadelphia, decided to explore the idea. It might relieve his craving. ``The plan is simple,'' he explained. ``It would work like all the other insurance programs: We just add up total burger expenditures, divide by the number of people and arrive at an average premium.'' Any individual who paid this premium, perhaps $40 a year, would receive a wallet-size Hamburger Insurance Card. The money would go into a Hamburger Insurance Trust, which would repay the burger joint. As he drove back to the office, the notion grew. He saw millions of people signing up, and multimillions of dollars pouring into the Hamburger Trust. It would be a whopping success. Then the bills arrived from the hamburger providers, and it was very clear that the bills exceeded the insurance premiums collected. ``How could this be?'' asked Trust officials. ``We charged each person the average amount spent on hamburgers in the United States, plus $5 for overhead expenses, such as maintaining our respectable but by no means posh offices.'' Congress established the Hamburger Commission to investigate and report. It found people who didn't eat hamburgers didn't sign up for the program. Thus, revenues were less than projected. The commission recommended that Congress make hamburger insurance mandatory so that no one could escape responsibility for funding such important coverage. Some commission members thought this was not enough. Why? Because those who originally signed up for the program bought even more hamburgers than they had before they had the insurance. These heavy eaters not only were buying more hamburgers but more expensive ones as well. A number of beneficiaries were using the insurance card to buy burgers for their pets. And drive-through customers were ordering an extra burger for the road, in case they got hungry. They could always throw it away. Producers innovated too. Triple deckers became the norm, and burgers made of ground filet were especially popular as business lunches and among the tennis and garden club set. At higher prices, of course, and delivery extra. The Hamburger Trust was endangered. Without insurance, many people would be unable to afford hamburgers. Business people warned that a failure of the Trust would destroy jobs and force small companies out of business. It was decided that a tax subsidy was needed to save the program. ``No one,'' declared an heroic cattle-state senator, ``should escape responsibility for maintaining this American institution.'' Premiums were raised and made mandatory. Taxes were raised too, reducing consumer disposable income and making people more reliant on the hamburger program for basic food. The impact was immediate. More expensive hamburgers were introduced. More companies entered the business, and they offered more ``services,'' fully covered by premiums. Fewer people ate at home; they couldn't afford to. The federal budget deficit grew, and it was urgently suggested by some throwbacks to another time that the program be curtailed to save the economy. Not a chance. It was an election year. At that point the professor dropped the idea as a very dangerous one. The idea, he confessed, had lost its appeal, quite a contrast to his original pride in thinking it up. He had lost his taste for a hamburger. ``Forget it,'' he said, swallowing his pride instead.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Finish Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished lower Monday in light trading on London's Stock Exchange. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-shares index fell 13.6 points, or 0.58 percent, to 2,316.5. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 4.0 points at 1,838.1. Volume came to 341.7 million shares compared with the 344.7 million issues which changed hands on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Special Charges, Divestment Spurs LTV Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Defense and steel contractor LTV Corp. reported Monday a 153 percent jump in second-quarter net earnings, mainly because of the sale of an interest in a company and special charges a year ago. The Dallas-based company, which is operating under bankruptcy court supervision, reported net income in the quarter ended June 30 was $76.6 million, or 59 cents per share, compared with $30.3 million, or 18 cents, in the same period last year. Revenue declined from $1.66 billion to $1.59 billion. The company said the 1990 quarter included a $44.3 million gain from the sale of its stock in a maker of stainless steel. The year-ago quarter was reduced by a $30 million special charge on the writedown of costs on a facility for manufacturing advanced aircraft compounds. For the first half of the year, LTV reported net income of $120.8 million or 81 cents a share, compared with $106.9 million or 73 cents last year. Revenues fell from $3.28 billion last year to $3.08 billion this year.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 6:30 p.m. EDT
Group's Consumer Confidence Index Virtually Unchanged in July
DOC.TEXT: Confidence in the nation's economy among consumers was about the same in July as in June, according to a monthly private study released Tuesday. Consumers were slightly more positive about present conditions than in June but a little less positive about their expectations for the months ahead, the Conference Board reported. The conclusions were based on a monthly survey of 5,000 households nationwide conducted by the Board of Family Opinion Inc. in Toledo, Ohio. ``Consumer confidence has been losing ground since the beginning of the year, but the experience has been markedly different in various regions of the country,'' said Fabian Linden, executive director of the board's consumer research center. Linden said confidence was sharply lower in New England in the second quarter of 1990 compared with the same period a year earlier. Expectations in the Middle Atlantic states also were lower, while consumer confidence was up in the west central and mountain regions. Confidence was lower in the Pacific states than a year ago but above the level in the rest of the nation. Of those surveyed, 23.2 percent said business conditions were good in July, up from 22.6 percent the previous month, and 25.6 percent said jobs were plentiful, up from 23.4 percent in June. But more respondents _ 11.7 percent in July compared with 10.4 percent in June _ said they expected business conditions to worsen in the next six months. Also, 17.9 percent said they expected there would be fewer jobs available in the next six months, up from 16.5 percent in June. Buying plans were mixed. Eight percent said they planned to buy a car and 4.3 percent a home in the next six months, both up from June. But overall plans to purchase major appliances declined to 26.8 percent from 28.8 percent in June. The Conference Board is a nonprofit business research organization.

DOC.HEAD: Mannesmann-Led Consortium to Develop East German System
DOC.TEXT: Mannesmann AG on Monday was selected to establish a privately operated mobile telephone system for East Germany. The post and telecommunications ministries of the two Germanys said in a joint statement that Mannesmann Mobilfunk GmbH, the telecommunications division of the diversified West German engineering group, will be asked to present a proposal to build and operate a so-called D-2 mobile telephone network in East Germany. A consortium led by Mannesmann is already preparing to operate such a network in West Germany. Both systems are scheduled to begin operating next year.

DOC.HEAD: Circle K Reports Quarterly, Annual Loss
DOC.TEXT: Circle K Corp. on Monday reported a net loss of more than $747 million in the fourth quarter of the fiscal year ending April 30, due largely to a $639.3 million reorganization and restructuring charge. The Phoenix-based convenience store chain said its losses for the fiscal year came to $772.9 million or $17.91 per share, compared with earnings of $15.4 million or 20 cents a share for the previous year. Fourth-quarter revenues were $907.9 million, compared with $932 million in the same period a year earlier, when the company lost $23 million. The loss for the fourth quarter amounted to $17.19 per share, compared to a loss of 57 cents a share in the 1989 period. Circle K filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code on May 15, eight days after the resignation of Karl Eller as the company's chairman and chief executive officer. Eller had taken charge of the company in 1983. Under his control, it grew from 1,000 stores to the nation's second-largest convenience store chain, with more than 4,600 stores in 32 states, and almost 1,300 stores under license or joint venture agreements in 14 foreign countries. The company also had more than $1.5 billion in debt. A Cincinnati lawyer, Bart A. Brown Jr., was named in late June to succeed Eller, while Robert Dearth Jr., also of Cincinnati, had been named president in January. Dearth had been vice president and chief administrative officer of United Brands Co., which is controlled by Cincinnati investor Carl Lindner, who also is a major Circle K stockholder. At the time of the bankruptcy filing, Circle K listed assets of $1.94 billion and liabilities of $1.58 billion. The company sought protection in bankruptcy court after announcing it had been unable to reach agreement with its creditors to restructure the debt. Monday's announcement said Circle K expected to file a list of all liabilities and assets around August 28. ``At this time, the company cannot predict the scheduling or ultimate outcome of the bankruptcy proceedings nor the effect upon the value of any of its outstanding securities,'' the announcement said. ``The company expects to file a bankruptcy reorganization plan as soon as practicable.''

Stock prices came under persistent pressure today in selling attributed to worries about weakness in the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 62.63 points last week, fell 16.58 to 2,881.93 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 431 up, 987 down and 505 unchanged. Analysts said traders were still unsettled by Friday's report that the gross national product grew at a 1.2 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the second quarter of the year. The increase was smaller than expected, and reflected a buildup in inventories rather than gains in final demand among consumers and business purchasers. That was taken as an inauspicious sign for production and corporate profits in the months ahead. Brokers said that gave investors little incentive to buy stocks, especially given the tendency of individual issues to sell off sharply of late in any instance of disappointing earnings. Losers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, down ] at 111; General Electric, down } at 71\; McDonald's, down \ at 31{, and Boeing, down 1] at 57~. UAL lost 4] to 158|. The Wall Street Journal reported that New York's Chemical Bank withdrew as a lead bank in the proposed buyout of the airline holding company. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.18 to 192.14. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.76 at 352.73. Volume on the Big Board came to 89.53 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Ball Corp. Buying Interest in Continental Can
DOC.TEXT: Ball Corp. announced plans today to pay $1.025 billion in cash and stock for the European packaging interests of Continental Can Co. Inc. and another $65 million for the remaining interest in a glass packaging joint venture. Richard M. Rigeon, chairman and chief executive officer of Ball, said the acquisitions would make Ball more competitive worldwide in packaging. ``The new ventures will combine the best of North America with the best of Europe, and will be an excellent opportunity to leverage Ball's process and management technology over a much larger business base.'' Ball said it will pay $625 million in cash and $400 million in Ball preferred and common stock for the two Continental Can businesses. Continental Can is a privately-held business of Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc. of Omaha, Neb. Under the agreement Ball will pay Kiewit $200 million in common stock, $129 million of voting and $71 million of non-voting convertible exchangeable preferred stock. The Kiewit stock will represent a 29 percent voting interest in Ball. Kiewit will be restricted from purchasing additional Ball shares. Ball will pay $65 million cash for the 50 percent it does not already own in the Ball-InCon Glass Packaging Corp. joint venture between Ball and Holland-American Investment Corp. Both will be operated as wholly owned subsidiaries of Ball Corp., with Ball In-Con retaining its own financing. Continental Can operates in Europe collectively as Continental Can Europe and principally as Continental Can U.K. Ltd., Schmalbach-Lubeca A.G., Thomassen & Drijver-Verblifa N.V., Continental Can France, SNC, and Continental PET France, SNC. Continental Can Europe, which employs 10,000 people in 33 locations, had sales of $1.47 billion in 1989. The company projects 1990 sales of $1.66 billion. The company makes food, beverage and general metal containers, metal closures and plastic containers. Ball Corp. entered the metal beverage container industry in 1969. It is now the nation's fifth largest producer of bear and soft drink cans. In the last 20 years the product line has become Ball's largest, with 58 percent of total 1989 sales coming from aluminum and steel beer and soft-drink cans and easy-opening ends. Last year 63.9 percent of Ball's sales, or $780.9 million, was from packaging products. Combined packaging sales of Ball, Continental Can Europe and Ball-InCon last year would have been $2.78 billion, officials said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Showing Signs of Stabilizing, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: Spending for new construction dipped lower in June but showed signs of stabilizing following a volatile first half, according to a study released Monday. F.W. Dodge, a financial information division of McGraw-Hill, said its index of new construction contracts fell in June to 153 from 156 in May. Spending for new construction totaled $240.72 billion in June, compared with May's $245.71 billion. Dodge said new non-building construction, which includes public works and utilities, fell 14 percent from May, when three public works contracts totaling $300 million had inflated spending in that category. Contracts for new non-residential construction, which includes commercial building, increased by 5 percent, while residential construction spending fell 1 percent. Despite the overall decline, Dodge found evidence that construction spending was leveling off after having fallen to a four-year low in April. The Dodge index reached 181 in September, but then began to tumble, eventually dropping to 147 in April, as builders found financing harder to come by. The index rebounded to 155 in May. George A. Christie, Dodge's chief economist, said most of the volatility in construction now appeared to be in the past. Recent figures show the building market is stabilizing, Christie said in a statement. Through the first half of the year, total new construction spending fell 8 percent from the same period a year earlier, to $121.3 billion from $131.37 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Climb, Grains Retreat
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose moderately Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting strength in the soybean oil market, while corn and wheat futures fell amid slack export demand for those grains. Forecasts for continued beneficial crop weather in the Midwest also weighed on the corn market and limited soybean gains, analysts said. Strength in the soybean complex was centered in the soybean oil pit, where the contract for delivery in August closed up 61 cents at 24.42 cents a pound. Martyn Foreman, grains analysts with AgriVisor Inc. in Bloomington, Ill., said recent government reports have indicated soy oil stocks are shrinking. ``The market's showing some response to that,'' he said. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said lighter-than-normal monsoon rains in parts of India had reduced yield prospects for certain nuts that are traditionally crushed for their oil. Soybean oil could provide a substitute, he said. At the close, wheat futures were 2} cents to 4{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.94 a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to 1{ cents higher with September at $2.61{ a bushel; oats were { cent to 2 cents lower with September at $1.28 a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 6{ cents higher with August at $5.88{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates on Short-term Treasury Securities Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were mixed in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $9.3 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.50 percent, up from 7.49 percent last week. Another $9.2 billion in six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.37 percent, down from 7.40 percent last week. The three-month bill rate was the highest since they sold for 7.62 percent on July 16. The six-month bill rate was the lowest since averaging 7.30 percent last Dec. 4. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.75 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,810.40 and 7.76 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,627.40. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.85 percent last week, down from 7.87 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Brokerage Founder Leading Candidate To Become New Chairman
DOC.TEXT: William H. Donaldson, a founder of the securities firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., is the leading candidate to become chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, sources said Monday. The current chairman, John J. Phelan Jr., is retiring at the end of 1990 after six years heading the nation's largest stock exchange. A final decision by the NYSE's board is expected to be made within two weeks. Donaldson may not emerge as the final selection but is considered the leading candidate, according to people familiar with the selection process who asked not to be named. An eight-member search committee has been meeting since Phelan announced his retirement in February. Donaldson, 59, now heads Donaldson Enterprises Inc., a merchant banking and money management firm in New York. He did not return telephone calls Monday seeking comment. New York Stock Exchange spokesman Richard Torrenzano would neither confirm nor deny whether Donaldson would be recommended to succeed Phelan to the full exchange board. Torrenzano said the search panel has been ``diligently and thoughtfully talking to people throughout the securities industry as well as key corporate leaders for their input.'' Donaldson was one of three founders of the securities firm that bears his name. He left Donaldson Lufkin in 1973 to become an undersecretary of state to Henry Kissinger. He later founded and was the first dean of Yale University's School of Organization and Management. Phelan has been widely praised for leading the exchange successfully through the 1987 stock market crash that devastated investor confidence. Among the issues to be faced by a new leader are the NYSE's slowly shrinking market share, increased competition from other exchanges the introduction of new technology.

Blue-chip stocks staged a late rally today, but the rest of the market settled for mixed results in an erratic session on Wall Street. Analysts said investors were still unsettled by Friday's report that the gross national product grew at a 1.2 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation, in the second quarter of the year. The increase was smaller than expected, and reflected a buildup in inventories rather than gains in final demand among consumers and business purchasers. That was taken as an inauspicious sign for production and corporate profits in the months ahead. Nevertheless, brokers said many of the big-name blue chips attracted buyers looking for ``bargains'' after the market's sharp decline last week.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Computer Company Agrees to Buy Britain's Top Computer Maker
DOC.TEXT: Fujistu Ltd., the second largest mainframe computer maker in the world, announced Monday it has agreed to buy Britain's top computer manufacturer, International Computers Ltd., for $1.2 billion. The buyout will make Fujitsu the second largest computer group in the world after U.S.-based International Business Machines Corp., officials with the Japanese company said at a news conference. Analysts have said the purchase would give Fujitsu a major sales and manufacturing foothold in Europe ahead of the creation of the single European market in 1992. It also makes the Japanese giant a player in the European mainframe market for the first time. IBM now dominates that market. Michio Naruto, Fujitsu's managing director and vice general manager of international operations in Tokyo, said the acquisition illustrates the emergence of the $16.8 billion Japanese company as a truly global computer maker. He acknowledged that the purchase might renew fears of Japanese buyouts in some parts of Europe. But he sought to allay concerns by saying that ICL would continue to be European-run. ICL, which currently does 60 percent of its business in Britain, ``already has said its intention was to expand to Europe. Fujitsu intends to support this intention,'' Naruto said. For ICL's part, the deal provides the mainframe manufacturer with the funds and technology for research and development and for its planned thrust in Europe. ``ICL's ability to grow will be significantly enhanced as a member of the Fujitsu family,'' said Arthur Walsh, chairman and chief executive officer of STC PLC, the parent company of ICL, at a London news conference. Fujitsu Chairman Takuma Yamamoto said his company intends to seek a separate listing for ICL on London's International Stock Exchange ``as soon as practicable.'' Under the agreement, Fujitsu will pay ICL's parent company, STC PLC, 700 million pounds, or about $1.2 billion, for an 80 percent stake in the British computer firm. ICL itself will pay STC an additional 42.8 million pounds, or about $73.4 million. There had been rumors for about a year about a possible equity tie between ICL and Fujitsu, which already have technology links, according to London analysts. ICL uses Fujitsu's computer chips and disks under a nine-year-old agreement. Analysts consider ICL to be Europe's most profitable mainframe computer maker. Yet in the first six months of the year, the company suffered a 7.4 percent decline in operating profit to $107 million, on sales of $1.4 billion. Analysts said Fujitsu has the financial strength to help ICL withstand what is expected to be an increasingly competitive European market. ``We have come to respect ICL in the course of our technological collaboration in the last nine years and this agreement builds on that relationship,'' said Yamamoto. He said ICL's chairman and managing director, Peter Bonfield, would continue in that position. Fujitsu's major activity in Europe is selling semiconductor computer chips, although it makes office computers in Spain and semiconductors in Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Finish Higher
DOC.TEXT: Most energy futures prices climbed Monday on the back of a bullish OPEC agreement aimed at boosting crude oil prices and cutting the oil glut. Trading activity was moderate on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract for September delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, rose 17 cents to $20.21 a 42-gallon barrel after losing 26 cents on Friday. Contracts for crude delivery during October through December also settled higher. Among refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, unleaded gasoline for August delivery jumped 1.00 cent to 65.88 cents a gallon after falling 0.38 cent on Friday. Later contracts also posted substantial increases. The August contract for wholesale heating oil, which lost 0.35 cent on Friday, edged 0.04 cent lower to 56.93 cents a gallon. The September through November contracts posted price gains, however. Meanwhile, in natural gas trading, the September contract settled at $1.430 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.439 on Friday. Later contracts were mixed. An agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to restrain crude oil production set a positive tone in the market, energy analysts said. But the advance was held in check by profit-taking and skepticism that OPEC will achieve its goals. The accord signed Friday by all of the cartel's 13 ministers raises OPEC's target price to $21 a barrel from $18. To achieve its price increase the cartel set a new daily output ceiling of 22.5 million barrels, a bit above the current cap but lower than its actual production. In all, OPEC will have to rein in production by about 700,000 barrels a day.

DOC.HEAD: Developing Nations Deplore Lack of Progress at Trade Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: Developing countries of Southeast Asia deplored the lack of progress in international trade negotiations and said Monday that they feared being left out in the economic cold. In a strongly worded statement criticising developed nations, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand said,``We are concerned that deals will be struck among the principals in the fall and developing countries will be left out in the cold. ``There seems to be no point in going further if this is going to be the scenario ... We call on developed countries to show leadership in the market access negotiations,'' said the statement by the four countries, which together with Brunei make up the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, known as ASEAN. Stating that the group places special emphasis on market access it added, ``ASEAN views progress in this area as the gauge by which to measure the seriousness of developed countries in taking developing country concerns into account.'' The global negotiations are called the Uruguay Round of Trade Negotiations, aimed at better market access and freer trade. The round is scheduled to conclude in December. ``... The possibility that the round will end as a failure does not seem unthinkable,'' the statement said giving details of how the developed nations were attaching conditions for tax concessions and quotas for tropical products, textiles, agricultural and farm products and other goods. The ASEAN nations are attending the nine-month-old Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting here Monday and Tuesday where they differed with the developed nations in discussions on the trade talks. The other members of the 12-nation APEC are the United States, Japan, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and South Korea. Two separate statements were issued on their discussions, a mild one by APEC and a strongly worded one by ASEAN. Asked why there were differences, Singapore's Trade Minister Lee Hsien Loong told a news conference there were ``differences on naunces of views.'' But, he said, they were united in wanting faster progress. But a senior ASEAN official, who spoke on condition he would not be identified by name, said,``Of course there are deep differences. At the rate we are going they will give us nothing or very little ... That is why our views were expressed so strongly.'' The APEC statement said the trade talks had not made enough progress and it ``was the single most important issue on the international agenda''. Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama asked APEC to admit China, Taiwan and Hong Kong, which want to be members. But conference officials said they doubted they would be admitted here although membership was possible later. Malaysian Foreign Minister Abu Hassan and others spoke about developments in Eastern Europe and the single European market coming in 1992. Fears were expressed that international funds might be diverted to Eastern European development resulting in less aid, trade, and investment for the Asia-Pacific region. Conference officials said Singapore's Foreign Minister Wong Kan Seng asked for an expert group to be set up to study how this could be avoided and how stronger relations with Europe could be established.

DOC.HEAD: Fujimori Orders Two-Day Banking Holiday in Peru
DOC.TEXT: President Alberto Fujimori on Monday ordered a two-day nationwide banking holiday to give his two-day-old goverment time to begin implementing a new economic program. Banks were closed throughout Peru Monday, as the mandatory holiday was effective immediatrely. Fujimori told reporters Monday that the economic measures planned by his government will not affect savings. ``Quite the contrary,'' he said. ``We want to encourage Peruvians to save and the measures are aimed at that goal.'' Fujimori was sworn into office last Saturday for a five-year term, suceeding moderate-leftist Alan Garcia. The president said the economic platform will be announced to the country Thursday or Friday by Prime Minister and Economy Minister Juan Carlos Hurtado. Fujimori inherited a critical economic situation from Garcia, with rampant inflation, high unemployment and a deep recession.

DOC.HEAD: Ralph Nader Sends 11-Page Letter to Incoming GM Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Consumer advocate Ralph Nader, who took on General Motors Corp. and its Corvair 25 years ago, sent an 11-page letter to the incoming GM chairman Monday, outlining how the automaker can ``correct some of Roger Smith's mistakes.'' Smith steps down Tuesday as chairman of GM, a post he held Monday and had not had a chance to read it. ``Mr. Stempel usually reads his correspondence,'' Crellin said. Nader said he did not send a similar letter to Ford Motor Co. Chairman Harold Poling when he took over from Donald Petersen on March 1. ``I focus on the big boy, General Motors,'' Nader said. In the GM letter, Nader discussed 13 recommendations he says can benefit GM and consumers. They include safety, quality, corporate democracy and recycling. ``This is a plea for Robert Stempel to start a clean slate in all directions,'' Nader said. ``The key test in that letter is meeting with consumer and environmental groups. ``It's something their culture has kept them from doing.''

DOC.HEAD: Copper Futures Drop Sharply, Ending 4-Day Rally
DOC.TEXT: Copper futures prices fell sharply Monday on New York's Commodity Exchange, ending a four-day rally amid speculation that London warehouse stocks of the metal have grown. On other commodity markets, precious metals were mixed; grains and soybeans were mixed; energy futures rose; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. Copper futures settled .80 cent to 2.35 cents lower in New York with the contract for delivery in August off 2.3 cents to $1.244 a pound. The copper market had risen strongly in five of the six previous sessions, including the last four, on concerns about relatively tight supplies and a strike that began Thursday against the state-owned Peruvian mining and refining company Mineroperu. But the strike was settled over the weekend and analysts believe demand for copper may be easing, based on indications that warehouse stocks documented by the London Metal Exchange rose in the past week. The London exchange's report on warehouse stocks was due out Tuesday. An early decline of more than 20 points in the Dow Jones industrial average also prompted selling of copper futures on the belief that a weakening economy would translate into weaker copper demand. The market recovered, though, and ended the day with a gain of nearly 19 points. Frederick D'Agostino, president of Metal Resources Inc., a Riverside, Conn., dealer in scrap and refined copper, said the recent runup was not justified by actual supply-and-demand factors. ``Everything I know, everything I've read, says the market's about 15 cents overpriced,'' D'Agostino said. He said market players who are not involved in the physical copper trade can sometimes bid prices up to unrealistic levels, but ``ultimately, supply and demand do determine price.'' In precious metal trading on the Commodity Exchange, gold futures finished 20 cents lower to 20 cents higher with August at $367.80 a troy ounce; silver was 3 cents to 4.5 cents lower with September at $4.84 a troy ounce. Soybean futures rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting strength in the soybean oil market. Wheat futures fell and corn futures were mixed amid slack export demand for those grains. Forecasts for continued beneficial crop weather in the Midwest also weighed on the corn market and limited soybean gains, analysts said. After the close, the National Weather Service released a new six-to-10 day outlook predicting normal temperatures and normal to above-normal rainfall for the Midwest during the first half of next week. A 30-day forecast predicted above-normal rainfall for the region through August. Also after the close, the Agriculture Department released a weekly crop-progress report that showed development of the corn and soybean crops still lagging far behind the normal pace. The slow crop development is a function of heavy spring rains that delayed planting. Fears have begun to surface in the markets that some late-planted crops could suffer frost damage. Wheat futures settled 2} cents to 4{ cents lower with September at $2.94 a bushel; corn was 1{ cents lower to 1} cents higher with September at $2.61 a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2 cents lower with September at $1.28 a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 6\ cents higher with August at $5.88 a bushel. Most energy futures prices climbed on the New York Mercantile Exchange on the back of a bullish OPEC agreement aimed at boosting crude oil prices and cutting the oil glut. Analysts said last week's agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to restrain crude oil production set a positive tone in the market. But the advance was held in check by profit-taking and skepticism that OPEC will achieve its goals. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents to 34 cents higher with September at $20.21 a barrel; heating oil futures were .04 cent lower to .51 higher with August at 56.93 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .80 cent to 1 cent higher with August at 65.88 cents a gallon. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle were unchanged to .40 cent higher with August at 77.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent to .32 cent higher with August at 89.27 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .70 cent higher with August at 60.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .50 cent lower to 1.65 cent higher with August at 49.22 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Continues Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `Traders said... to recast time of low level against mark; PICKS UP 5th graf, `Chris Mendell...
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell broadly against major foreign currencies Monday, continuing a drop prompted by a weakening U.S. economy and the prospect of lower interest rates. Gold prices were mixed. ``Global investors don't think the dollar is very attractive right now,'' said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president with Harris Trust & Savings Bank in Chicago. Traders said the dollar closed at its lowest level in more than two years against the West German mark and at about a two-year low against the British pound. Chris Mendell, a vice president with Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles, said that as differences in global interest rates have narrowed, rates of return for investors in Europe and Japan have become higher or comparable to those in the United States. Monday's market activity was largely a carryover from Friday, when the dollar tumbled in reaction to reports of slow growth in June of the gross national product, which measures the nation's total output of goods and services. The financial markets believe that with the U.S. economy continuing to slump, the Federal Reserve will push interest rates lower to help stimulate growth. But such a move would come at the expense of the dollar. Currencies are supported by higher interest rates, so a drop in U.S. yields makes the dollar less competitive. ``The market since the GNP report Friday has increased its conviction that the dollar will go back down,'' Mendell said. The British pound climbed against the dollar, following up on a more than 2 cent rise on Friday. Sterling rose to $1.8465 in New York from late Friday's $1.8375. In London earlier, the British pound rose to $1.8440 from $1.8350 late Friday. Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.6040 West German marks, down from 1.6120; 1.3602 Swiss francs, down from 1.3620; 5.3725 French francs, down from 5.3990; 1,174.25 Italian lire, down from 1,180.00; and 1.15245 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15195. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.6085 West German marks, down from 1.6145; 1.3653 Swiss francs, down from 1.3680; 5.3885 French francs, down from 5.4080; 1.8125 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8205; 1,177.50 Italian lire, down from 1,182.00, and 1.1525 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1521. The dollar fell to 147.83 Japanese yen in New York from 149.10 late Friday. In Tokyo earlier, the dollar tumbled 2.15 yen to a closing 148.60 Japanese yen and it was quoted in London at 148.15 yen. Gold fell 20 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $367.80 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $367.70, up 40 cents from Friday. In London earlier, gold rose to a late bid of $367.25 a troy ounce, up from $367.15 late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $367.50 an ounce, down from $367.15 late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong fell 18 cents to close at $367.86 a troy ounce. Silver prices were mixed. Silver for current delivery slipped 2.9 cents to $4.803 a troy ounce on New York's Comex. Silver rose in London to a late bid of $4.83 a troy ounce from $4.80 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Wang Reports $496.7 Million Fourth Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Wang Laboratories Inc. reported Monday it lost $496.7 million in the April through June period as the computer firm continued to accumulate charges from a restructuring that included a 30 percent workforce cut. The loss, which came to $3.01 per share, was more than 30 percent greater than the $374.7 million, or $2.29 a share, loss in the same period last year. Revenue for the fourth fiscal quarter was $652.2 million, compared with $750.9 million for the same period last year. Securities analyst Casey Stern of the New York-based Altman Brenner Wasserman and Co., said Monday that Wang Chairman Richard W. Miller's drastic moves to restructure the company were paying off. Despite the fourth quarter losses, he predicted that the company would post a profit in fiscal 1991 on revenues of $2.5 billion. Miller had reduced a $575 million bank debt last August to the current $30 million and cut about 10,000 employees, from 29,200 to 19,000. In a statement, Miller said, ``Although this re-evaluation has resulted in substantial restructuring charges and non-recurring balance sheet adjustment, we believe the decisions that have been made position the company for future profitability in a changing industry.'' Miller said the restructuring costs stemmed from the continuing implementation of Operation Customer, Wang's attempt to reorient itself to changing markets and new customer needs. Stern said Wang had made headway in reducing the bureaucracy that had alienated customers. The company reported a net loss for fiscal 1990 of $715.9 million, or $4.35 per share, on revenues of $2.497 billion. In fiscal 1989, the net loss was $424.3 million, or $2.59 per share, on revenues of 2.910 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Unocal Net Up 38 Percent for 2nd Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Unocal Corp. said Monday its second-quarter profits rose 38 percent, in part because of an after-tax gain from the sale of a Norwegian subsidiary and higher domestic natural gas prices. Second-quarter revenues were down, however, falling to $2.72 billion from $3.07 billion in 1989, the company said. For the April-June quarter, the energy company earned $165 million, or 70 cents per share, compared with $120 million, or 51 cents per share, in second-quarter 1989. For the first six months of 1990, Unocal's net earnings were $242 million, or $1.03 per share, compared with six-month 1989 earnings of $207 million, or 88 cents per share. Unocal Chairman Richard Stegemeier said the latest results reflected a $132 million after-tax gain from the sale of the company's wholly owned Norwegian oil and gas subsidiary. He also cited higher gas prices and production, and lower deferred income taxes and net interest expense. Six-month revenues were $5.36 billion, compared with $5.70 billion last year. Unocal attributed the drop primarily to the absence of petroleum product sales by Unocal's Midwest Marketing Division, now part of a joint venture.

DOC.HEAD: Natural Gas Distributors Unite
DOC.TEXT: The parent company of Minnegasco Inc. has agreed to become part of Arkla Inc.'s natural gas operations in a stock swap valued at about $630 million, the two companies announced Monday. The boards of Diversified Energies Inc. and Arkla agreed to the merger, which is subject to approval of each firm's shareholders and government regulators, the companies said in a statement. If completed, the deal would create the nation's third largest gas distribution system with 2.6 million customers and 1 trillion cubic feet in annual volume, the companies said. The combined company's estimated combined revenues would total $3 billion. Thomas F. Mack McLarty III, president and chief executive officer of Arkla, and Albert D. Etchelecu, DEI's president and CEO, said the transaction probably would be completed by the end of the year. McLarty would continue as Arkla's chairman, president and CEO under the agreement. Etchelecu would serve as vice chairman of Arkla's board of directors and continue as chairman and chief executive of Minneapolis-based natural gas distributor Minnegasco. Under the agreement, DEI stockholders will receive between 1.575 and 1.752 shares of Arkla common stock for each share of DEI common stock. Monday's news release said the exact number of exchanged shares would be based on Arkla's trading price immediately prior to completion of the transaction. Based on recent trading prices, the release said, owners of approximately 16 million DEI common shares would get about $39 worth of Arkla stock for each share of DEI stock they own. DEI wwould pay Arkla $3 million and reimburse expenses of up to another $3 million if the deal falls through. Arkla, based in Little Rock and Shreveport, has the nation's sixth largest pipeline operations and about two million customers in an eight-state region. Arkla's serves southwestern Illinois and all or parts of Arkansas, Kansas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas. Its service area includes such major metropolitan areas as St. Louis, Houston and Wichita. Minnegasco serves about 650,000 customers in an area extending from Minnesota to Nebraska. Principal cities served by Minnegasco are Minneapolis; Sioux Falls, S.D., and Lincoln, Neb. Meanwhile, in a report issued Monday, DEI said it had a loss of $2.9 million, or 18 cents per share, on revenues of $127.8 million for the second quarter ended June 30. That compared with a loss of $400,000, or 3 cents per share, on revenues of $136.4 million for the same quarter last year. The company attributed reduced earnings in its radio communications unit, E.F. Johnson, for the loss.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Metropolitan Promotes Peter Thompson
DOC.TEXT: Grand Metropolitan Food Sector has put Peter M. Thompson in charge of its division that oversees Pillsbury International, Haagen-Dazs and Grand Met Foodservice USA. Thompson, whose new title is chief executive of the Sector Brands Division, was also named an executive vice president of Grand Met's Food Sector, the company said Monday. Thompson, formerly president and chief executive officer of Grand Met's Paddington Corporation, a New Jersey-based importer and marketer of distilled spirits, joined Grand Met in 1983. Thompson had been president of Pepsico Produtos Ltda. in Brasil and worked for J. Walter Thompson Co. and General Foods Corp. ``Peter's 20 years experience in the consumer foods industry, with a focus on international markets, also fits well with our plans to make Haagen-Dazs, Pillsbury and Green Giant major players in the international marketplace,'' Ian Martin, chairman and chief executive of Grand Met's Food Sector, said. Grand Metropolitan PLC, one of the largest international companies in the United Kingdom and a world leader in drinks, retailing and food, has sales in excess of $15 billion. U.S. subsidiaries include ALPO Petfoods, Burger King, Carillon Importers, Haagen-Dazs, Heublein, The Paddington Corp., Pearle Inc., Pillsbury Brands, and Grand Met Foodservice USA.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Continues Downward, But Nikkei Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued to retreat against the Japanese yen during early trading Tuesday morning and the Nikkei Stock Average reversed its seven-day decline. The dollar opened at 147.75 yen, down 0.85 yen from its close Monday at 148.60 yen. It fell to 147.83 Japanese yen in New York overnight from 149.10 late Friday. The dollar has taken a beating against most major currencies since last Friday, when it tumbled in reaction to the U.S. gross national product's slow growth in June. Financial markets believe the Federal Reserve will push interest rates lower to help stimulate growth. But Chizuko Satsukawa, a currency trader with Chemical Bank in Tokyo, said Tuesday's lower opening in Tokyo reflected more a demand for yen in cross trading with the German mark than any inherent weakness in the dollar. ``Many dealers thought that with the end of the month, there would be an increased demand for dollars, but that seems not to have materialized,'' she said. Nevertheless, she predicted the dollar would not fall much further, bottoming out somewhere around 147.40 yen. On the stock market, the closely watched Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 436.64 points, or 1.43 percent, to 30,879.59 points 30 minutes after trading began. The Nikkei average has lost 2,176.03 points, or 6.58 percent, since July 19. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond also reversed its direction Tuesday morning, rising to 85.23 points from 85.14 points at the Monday close. Yields fell to 7.585 percent from 7.605 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Army Awards Potential $700 Million Computer Contract
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Army has awarded a Herndon, Va., firm a contract worth potentially $700 million to produce an office computer system, officials said Monday. Electronic Data Systems received the indefinite delivery, indefinite quantity contract Thursday from the Army's Information Systems Selection and Acquisition Agency. The computers will be used for administrative tasks by the Army, Navy and the Defense Logistics Agency, Army spokeswoman Helen Garamone said. Each 32-bit modular unit will be able to handle from four to 16 users, she said. The government expects to buy between 40 and 20,000 units worldwide by 1995, she said. The contract also includes a wide range of peripherals, software and networking products. Electronic Data is responsible for engineering, installation, training and maintenance. The contract also requires Electronic Data to construct the system so it can interact with the Army's many existing computer systems and some planned ones, Ms. Garamone said. Electronic Data plans to subcontract 25 percent of the work to small businesses. The government first asked for proposals for the system in March 1988, Ms. Garamone said. Award of the contract was postponed because more bids than expected were received and resulted in a longer evaluation period, according to Barbara Johnson, a contracting officer.

DOC.HEAD: Varity Corp. Wants Shareholders To Support Move To U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Varity Corp., one of the world's largest farm equipment makers, plans to ask shareholders for permission to move its headquarters to Buffalo, N.Y., company officials said Monday. Varity is ``already a U.S. company with a Canadian address'' because over 80 percent of its shareholders live in the United States, said Victor Rice, the company's chairman and chief executive officer. Most of Varity's North American employees work in U.S. plants and U.S.-based customers will account for some 50 percent of 1990 revenues, displacing Europe as the company's biggest market, Rice said. He said Varity, as a U.S. company, would rank among the country's top 130 publicly traded enterprises. Varity is considering a headquarters move to Buffalo to make its stock more widely available to U.S. investors and to relieve them of the Canadian government's 15 percent withholding tax on dividends, company officials say. But Canadian officials have said their government will sue if necessary to block the move. The move would violate a pledge Varity, then known as Massey-Ferguson, made in 1986 in return for a $169.1 million government bailout, according to officials of the Ontario Development Corp. a quasi-public agency that funnels government loans to businesses. The officials say Varity agreed to maintain or create 1,500 jobs in Canada by 1993 and also keep its headquarters there. Varity recently purchased a mansion in Buffalo and won an $11.5 million package of tax exemptions from the Erie County Industrial Development Agency. Those actions prompted public warnings from Canadian officials that Varity would face a court fight if it moved its headquarters.

DOC.HEAD: Blinder, Robinson & Co. Files Chapter 11
DOC.TEXT: Blinder, Robinson & Co. Inc., once the nation's largest penny-stock brokerage firm, on Monday asked U.S. Bankruptcy Court for protection from creditors while it reorganizes. In a brief news release Monday night announcing the filing under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws, the firm said it plans to transfer its customer accounts and brokerage operations to another broker-dealer. Earlier this month, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged the troubled Colorado brokerage of overcharging investors by more than $20 million in 21 months. According to a lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court, Blinder, Robinson marked up prices as high as 140 percent on penny stocks when selling them to investors. The SEC claimed the activity took place from June 1985 through February 1987. Last April the SEC suspended Blinder Robinson from trading in penny stocks for 45 days and from underwriting such offerings for two years. The SEC also barred the firm's founder and chairman, Meyer Blinder, from associating with any registered broker-dealer for at least two years. Blinder, 69, of Denver, and four associates were indicted in February on racketeering and securities fraud charges by a federal grand jury in Las Vegas. The indictment followed a 1988 Internal Revenue Service raid on Blinder Robinson's Denver office. Penny stocks are low cost, high risk securities, usually trading for less than $3 per share. They are not listed on stock exchanges and typically are used to raise capital for new or small companies.
